desc: A survey and critique of archaeological theory from the   nineteenth century through the 1970's, with emphasis on   shifting paradigms and the implications for research.
name: Classical Archaeological Theory

desc: Interdepartmental research practicum in evolutionary psychology, biology, and anthropology for students and faculty planning or working on evolutionary research projects. Focus on experimental design, cross-cultural methods, organism design theory, new adaptationist hypotheses, and the criteria for testing them.
name: Advanced Theory and Method in Evolutionary Psychology

desc: How to design a fieldwork project and write a dissertation research proposal; the search for funding agencies; how to deal with funding institutions, professional organizations, publishers and employers; issues of a career inanthropology.
name: Research Design and Writing in Archaeology

desc: Designed to give students a solid grounding in basic   research methods in cultural anthropology. Focus on the   role of fieldwork, preparation for field research (ethics,   health, and gender), systematic data collection,   qualitative data base management and analysis.
name: Research Methods in Cultural Anthropology

desc: Open to graduate students in biological anthropology and   allied fields, this course reviews research findings in   human evolutionary studies.
name: Current Findings in Biological Anthropology

desc: Primarily for graduate students in other subfields of   anthropology, to help them master effective methods for   teaching biological anthropology at the undergraduate level.
name: Pedagogical Methods and Strategies in Biological Anthropology

desc: A discussion of general problems in anthropology. Consult   with departmentoffice for faculty designation.
name: Method and Theory in Anthropology

desc: Exposes incoming graduate students to the theoretical   interests and current research being conducted by the   department ladder and affiliated faculty. First-year   students are required to enroll and participate fully in  weekly meetings.
name: Faculty Graduate Proseminar

desc: The course, designed to meet the needs of the graduate student who serves as a teaching assistant, includes analyses of texts and materials, discussion of teaching techniques, conducting discussion sections, formulation of topics and questions for papers and examinations, and grading papers and examinations under the supervision of the instructor assigned to the course.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Introduction to the planning and implementation of full-scale   research projects. The opportunity will be given to formulate   and carry out designs and to direct crews in data collection.
name: Field Research Training

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations

desc: Individual tutorial for graduate students writing the research paper and/ordissertation proposal for advancement to candidacy.
name: Master's Thesis and Pre-Candidacy Preparation

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: The nature of culture: survey of the range of cultural phenomena, includingmaterial culture, social organization, religion, and other topics.
instructors: RARESHIDE E, PENA J, BROWN K M, MONROE S L, GORMAN A J, LAMON S E, KAPLAN J D, SMITH G L, GONZALEZ T A, WEIGLER E A, SMYTH L M, STEINHARDT J
name: Introductory Cultural Anthropology

desc: An introductory course in human evolutionary biology.  Natural selection and its genetic basis are used to highlight a variety of human traits.  The fossil record is addressed, but the course takes more of an "adaptationist" than a paleontological perspective.
instructors: GAULIN S J, BAILEY-STEINI, BEIERSCHMITT, AGEY E R, MCCOOL W C, GARCIA ANGELA, BIWER M E, SANTY J K
name: Introductory Biological Anthropology

desc: Introduction to research in Anthropology. Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group.
name: Independent Studies

desc: We look at different educational projects, such as Indian   boarding Schools, English-only laws, the "indirect rule" of   the British colonies. We address the not-always-clear line   between education as a form of social control or as a form   of liberation.
name: Educating the Native

desc: The cross-cultural study of gender from a feminist perspective. Topics may include gender and nature, gender and the division of labor, gender and kinship, gender and subjectivity, gender and sexuality, gender and the state, gender and knowledge/discourse.
name: Anthropology of Gender

desc: Interrogation of ethnographic research, its development and   its ethical implications. Weighing approaches such as   participatory action research, engaged and collaborative   research, and decolonized methodologies. Students will develop projects based on a critical reading of these models.
name: Ethnographic Research Methods: Ethics and Engagement

desc: A thorough introduction using a behavioral ecology approach to the diversity of behaviors found among foragers in Africa, South America, Southeast Asia, and Australia. Topics include: diet and subsistence, mating, demography,social behavior, mobility and settlement patterns, gender, indigenous rights, and conservation.
name: Behavioral Ecology of Hunter Gatherers

desc: An overview of how ceramics are used in archaeology. Topics include potterymanufacture, classification, stylistic and functional analysis, scientific analysis, chronology, production and exchange, ceramic consumption and socio-political organization.
name: Ceramic Analysis in Archaeology

desc: Human adaptations and population dispersals during the Ice   Age (Pleistocene epoch). Course focuses on Stone Age   cultures and the evidence for early human occupation of the   Americas and the Old World between three million and 10,000   years ago.
name: People of the Ice Age

desc: Regulation of reproductive function by diet, energy balance,   lactation, and social context. The role of hormones in the   regulation of human reproduction, behavior, and physiology.   Hormonal changes with parenting and pregnancy in men and   women.
name: Human Reproduction Ecology and Endocrinology

desc: Interns serve as assistants in the department's Central Coast   InformationCenter or Repository for Archaeological   Collections or both.
name: Internship in Archaeological Record-Keeping and Collections

desc: This course gives students an introduction to the anthropology and archaeology of making and using stone tools. Practical experience in making tools and using them experimentally is emphasized.
name: Introduction to Lithic Analysis

desc: Interns serve as assistants or trainees in the archaeological programs of agovernmental agency, a museum, or a private firm in the local area. In collaboration with the instructor and an extramural archaeologist, the student conceives a set of activities for the internship.
name: Internship in Archaeological Resource Management

desc: Students serve as interns in various settings such as museums,   governmental agencies, and health organizations to gain   exposure to different cultures. In collaboration with the   instructor and an extramural anthropologist, the student   conceives a set of activities for the internship.
name: Cultural Anthropology Internship

desc: 2-unit course for Anthropology majors (and minors) with   upper-division standing, with a preference for seniors. The   goal of this course is to guide students in choosing and   applying to graduate programs.
name: Anthropology Capstone: Preparing for a Graduate Career in   Anthropology

desc: Introduction to design of research projects and techniques of   data collection in archaeology. The number of units taken in   one course will depend on the amount of training and   experience received.
name: Field Training Archaeology

desc: An applied course emphasizing acquisition of practical skills   in archaeological field work and laboratory analysis. Projects   will vary depending on the type of archaeological research in   progress and may include artifact processing, cataloguing,   field excavation and preparation of research results.
name: Practicum in Field and Laboratory Analysis

desc: Independent research under the supervision of an   anthropology faculty member which will result in senior   thesis. This course concentrates on reading and gathering   of materials for thesis.
name: Senior Honors Program: INDEPENDENT STUDY PART I
prequisites: Admission to senior honors program; consent of instructor; ANTH 195A

desc: Independent research under the supervision of an   anthropology faculty member which will result in senior   thesis. Writing the thesis will be completed in this   course. Final course in progress series.
name: Senior Honors Program: INDEPENDENT STUDY PART II

desc: Intended for students who know their own reading needs. Normally requires regular meeting with the instructor.
name: Independent Readings in Anthropology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Anthropology.

desc: Students must execute a limited research project on their own initiative.
name: Independent Studies in Anthropology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Anthropology.

desc: Student gains research experience through assisting faculty member in research project.
name: Undergraduate Research Assistance Training in Anthropology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Anthropology.

desc: Supervised teaching of Asian American studies lower-division courses.
name: Laboratory for Teaching Assistants
prequisites: Appointment as a teaching assistant in an Asian American Studies course.

desc: A reading course in a general area of history specifically designed to prepare M.A. candidates for their comprehensive examination fields, but also appropriate for Ph.D. students seeking broad preparation. Introduces the student to the sources, historiography, and general literature of the field in question.
name: Historical Literature: Europe

desc: A reading course in a field of the professor's specialty. Introduces the student to the sources and literature of the field in question. Written work as prescribed by the instructor. AM. America.
name: Advanced Historical Literature

desc: A general introduction to selected historiographical issues and historical methods.
name: Historical Methods

desc: A two-quarter course.
name: Seminar in Medieval History

desc: This year long interdisciplinary colloquium brings together   graduate students who study Japanese history and culture. It   introduces current scholarship on Japan via readings,   discussions and presentations by visiting scholars, UCSB   scholars and graduate students. The colloquium meets bi-  weekly. Students will prepare readings for discussion, write   a seminar-length paper and present their paper to the   colloquium once during the year.
name: Reinventing "Japan" Colloquium

desc: A colloquium introducing the important issues, themes, and   literature in the history of the United States, from 1917   to the present. Historiographical in nature, the course   assumes a basic familiarity with the period.
name: Foundations of U.S. History, 1917-Present

desc: Hosts leading scholars of the nineteenth- and twentieth-century U.S. whose work touches upon the history and character of work, employment, labor, poverty, race, ethnicity, political economy, and public policy. The colloquiummeets three to four times per quarter.
name: Colloquium in Work, Labor, and Political Economy

desc: Writing workshop, professionalization seminar, and guest lecture series forgraduate students working in area of environmental history.  Meets monthly throughout the academic year, and includes occasional campus events and field trips.
name: Workshop in Environmental History

desc: Writing/reading workshop, professionalization seminar, and   guest lecture series for graduate students working in area of   history of science/technology. Meets monthly throughout the   academic year.
name: Workshop in the History of Technology and Science

desc: Subject oriented, designed to relate directly to the teaching of a particular course in progress, to improve the skills and effectiveness of the department's teaching assistants.
name: Laboratory for Teaching Assistants

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
instructors: T B A, ALAGONA P S
name: Special Topics

desc: Independent study in one or more languages required for   student's research and/or field examinations. Intended   for advanced language study and notas preparation for   satisfying the department-wide foreign language   requirement. Maximum 4 units per quarter; may be   repeated. Each faculty member has a unique letter   designation available from staff graduate advisor.
name: Foreign Language Preparation

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor usually student's major professor. Each faculty member has a unique letter designation available from graduate secretary.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Independent study for Master's comprehensive examinations and Ph.D. examinations.
name: Independent Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations

desc: Only for writing the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee. Each faculty member has a unique letter designation available from graduate secretary.
name: Ph.D Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Survey of the peoples, cultures, and social, economic, and political systems that have characterized the world's major civilizations in Europe, Asia, Africa, the Americas, and Oceania from prehistory to 1000 CE.
instructors: RUDOLPH A K, FRANKE T S, STEVENSON B H, BOCCHINO A J, MINOR R H, DOU L, JOHNSON JULIE, CRISLER J F, MORLAND P
name: World History

desc: 1715 to present. History 4A-B-C is a general survey course,   designed to acquaint the student with major developments   that have influenced the course of western civilization   since the earliest times. These developments are as likely   to be in religion, the arts, and sciences as in the more   traditional political field. Weekly discussion sections are   an important feature of this course, enabling the student to   develop and expand upon material presented during the   lecture hour.
instructors: ROBERTS C G, SPRANDIO S R, SCHMIDT E M
name: Western Civilization

desc: Through studying a particular topic in history, students gain   insight into historical methods and skills. Course designed   for freshmen and sophomore history majors or prospective   majors. Others may enroll by permission of instructor. Topics   vary by quarter and instructor.
name: Historical Investigations: Methods and Skills

desc: Colonial through Jacksonian era. A survey of the leading issues in Americanlife from colonial times to the present. The course focuses on politics, cultural development, social conflict, economic life, foreign policy, and influential ideas. Features discussion sections.
instructors: TYRRELL B P, AHN E, HUGHES D L, JOHNSON N R, MACMAHON C M, GILLERAN S W, ELROD A Y, JENSEN A M, WARDEN P M, DUNNE S C, DE SILVA N B, BELTRAN F, GENENS D W
name: The American People

desc: Course themes include rise of Islam, development of Islamic civilization, the Western impact, and current struggles and conflicts.
instructors: CONTRERAS A L, TUMEN M E
name: Survey of Middle Eastern History

desc: A basic introduction to the history of Japanese culture from its origins tothe present day, with particular emphasis on the evidence of architecture and painting (presented through audiovisual modules). Selectedexamples of fiction and poetry will also be used.
instructors: SCHMIDT B S, THORNBURG M E
name: Japanese History Through Art and Literature

desc: An introduction to the history of the South Asian   subcontinent, with emphasis on the period from 1500 CE to   the present.
name: Survey of South Asian History

desc: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member. Exceptional students are offered an opportunity to undertake independent or collaborativeresearch or to act as interns for faculty-directed research projects.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: Reading seminar focused on special topics dealing with   science, technology, and the modern period. Topics include:   computers in society; history of space exploration;   histories of the future; nuclear war in history & film.
name: Readings in the History of Science and Technology
prequisites: HIST 4C or 17C or 105A or 109 or 109S or 109T or Upper Division Standing

desc: The history of Christian communities and doctrines from the first through the eighth centuries. Special emphasis on Christians' evolving relationshipswith pagan and Jewish communities throughout the Mediterranean world.
name: History of Christianity: Beginning to 800
prequisites: History 2A or 4A or Religious Studies 80A or upper-division standing.

desc: Students will conduct historical research in a seminar   context, using both primary and secondary source materials.    Topics addressed: defining a research problem, identifying   an original topic, conducting research, citing sources, and   presenting results.  Intensive writing required.
name: Undergraduate Research Seminar in Medieval European History
prequisites: Any one of the following: History 115, 115X, 118A, 118B, 125 or 130 or   upper division standing or consent of instructor.

desc: Explores medieval European politics and culture through a look at notoriousscandals: Pope Joan, Heloise and Abelard, the persecution of the Templars, and the Fourth Crusade.
name: Medieval Scandals

desc: Assesses the more than seven centuries of Muslim, Christian, and Jewish coexistence (convivencia) in the Iberian peninsula, examing intercultural and interfaith relations from the time of the Visigoths (fifth century) to the expulsion of the Moriscos (Muslim converts to Christianity) in 1609.
name: Muslims, Christians, and Jews in Medieval Spain: Conquest,   Colonization, and Coexistence

desc: This course will be a discussion, reading of a single document, and   critique of your peers' papers. Certain principles and rules for the study   of history will be discussed. The main thrust of the course, however, is   theanalysis and writing of one or two short (500 to 600) word papers on   someexcerpts translated from one of Richelieu's most famous writings, The   Political Testament.
name: Readings in Early Modern Europe
prequisites: HIST 129A or 129B or 129C or 129D or 129E or 129F or upper division   standing

desc: 1800-1917. A survey of Russian history from the reign of Alexander I to theRussian revolution.
name: History of Russia

desc: A history of England from the late middle ages to the eighteenth century.
name: Early Modern Britain
prequisites: History 2A or 2B or 4A or 4B or upper division standing.

desc: Examines the social and cultural construction of the United   States and Mexico border.
name: Social and Cultural History of the U.S. - Mexico Border
prequisites: HIST 17A or 17B or 17C or 8 or upper division standing.

desc: A seminar on a topic in African history. A research paper   is required.
name: Undergraduate Research Seminar in African History

desc: Explores the major socio-economic and political history of the Southern African region from around 1000 CE to the 1880s.   Focuses on state making, economic systems, regional mobilities and international connections through trade before the advent of European colonialism.
name: Pre-Colonial Southern Africa

desc: Early precolumbian states; the Inca empire; the Spanish   conquest of the Incas; the formation of a colonial Andean   society; movements toward independence to the end of the   colonial period.
name: Andean History: Pre-Hispanic and Colonial Periods
prequisites: Any History 2 series course, or any History 4 series course, or History   8, or any History 151 series course, or History 154LA or LAIS 100 or LAIS   101 or upper-division standing.

desc: Socioeconomic history of colonial Mexico with special   attention on the indigenous peoples.
name: History of Mexico

desc: Research seminar on the history of women in America. Topics   addressed: defining a research problem, identifying an original   topic, conducting research, citing sources, and presenting results.   Intensive writing required.Students will conduct historical research   in a seminar context, using both primary and secondary source   materials, to produce an original and substantial research paper.
name: Undergraduate Research Seminar in Women's History
prequisites: History or Feminist Studies 159B or 159C or History 159Q or upper   division standing.

desc: Political, cultural, social, and economic development of the United States from 1900 to the present: A. 1900-1929
name: United States in the Twentieth Century

desc: A survey of American workers from the turn of the century to   the present period. Topics include workers and American   socialism, the 1919 steel strike, the rise of the CIO, labor   and the cold war, and deindustrializationand workers.
name: Capital and Class in 20th Century America
prequisites: History 17C or sophomore or junior or senior standing.

desc: Traces the history of American attitudes and behavior toward nature. Focus on wilderness, the conservation movement, and modern forms of environmentalism.
name: American Environmental History

desc: A lecture course on the history of the indigenous peoples of North America from European contact to Cherokee removal. The course stresses comparative cultural responses to European colonization and from American history from a native point of view.
name: Native American History to 1838

desc: A survey of Japanese social and cultural history from the   mid-sixteenth century to the nineteenth century.
name: Japan Under the Tokugawa Shoguns
prequisites: History 2A or 2B or 2C or 9 or 87 or upper-division standing.

desc: The history of Japan since World War II, dealing with the   American occupation, economic recovery and growth, social   change, and political development.
name: Recent Japan
prequisites: History 2A or 2B or 2C or 9 or 87 or upper-division standing.

desc: Students taking part in departmental honors program will write a senior thesis on a research topic of suitable depth under close supervision of faculty mentors.
name: Senior Honors Seminar

desc: A two-quarter individual research project, under the direction of a historyprofessor selected with the advice of the departmental adviser to public policy students.
name: Senior Thesis
prequisites: A major in History of Public Policy; senior standing; consent of instructor

desc: A two-quarter individual research project, under the direction of a historyprofessor selected with the advice of the departmental adviser to public policy students.
name: Senior Thesis - Public Policy
prequisites: Major in History of Public Policy, and completion of junior-year studies; consent of instructor.

desc: Course enables students to obtain credit for history-related internship experience, such as in the Capitol Hill or Sacramento programs.
name: Internship in History

desc: The description of any one 199 must not be identical to any existing coursedescription.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in History; consent of department.

desc: Faculty supervised research. Written work is usually required.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in history;consent of instructor and department.

desc: Overview and introduction to topics in cognitive science.
name: Seminar in Cognitive Science

desc: In-depth consideration of interdisciplinary humanistic topics, issues, and concerns through tutorial format. Students may affiliate with Interdisciplinary Humanities Center's Research Focus Groups (www.ihc.ucsb.edu/research).
name: Ancient Borderlands

desc: Graduate Affiliates will design and offer a 10 week course in the humanities for inmates of   North Kern State Prison (NKSP). They will devote fall quarter to creating the curriculum for   the course, which will consist of brief foundational readings in the humanities along with   response worksheets for the participants. In winter and spring, Graduate Affiliates will   offer the course to inmates in NKSP, via mail correspondence. Each Graduate Affiliate will   work with two participants from NKSP throughout winter and spring quarter.
name: Prison Pedagogy

desc: An introduction to the interdisciplinary field of Native American Studies. The   course familiarizes students with the variety of disciplinary approaches to   Native American Studies (Religious Studies, Chicano Studies, Anthropology,   History, Literary Studies, etc.). More importantly, the course seeks to create   an understanding of Indigenous theories and methodologies that transcend   disciplinary boundaries and that are derived from an Indigenous and non-western   epistemology.
name: NATIVE AMERICAN AND INDIGENOUS STUDIES PROSEMINAR

desc: In-depth consideration of interdisciplinary humanistic topics, issues, and concerns through tutorial format. Students may affiliate with Interdisciplinary Humanities Center's Research Focus Groups (www.ihc.ucsb.edu/research).Topic is Selected Topics.
name: Selected Topics

desc: Integrative overview of media arts and technologies,   emphasizing the   interconnections between technologies and humanities   (means and ends),   engineering and mathematics (concrete and abstract), and   arts and science  (synthesis and analysis). The THEMAS model proposes a   continuum across disciplines previously separated by   narrow specializations. It builds upon the successes of   STEM/STEAM, with greater emphasis on the humanities,   creativity, and synthesis. “Worldmaking,” in nature,   fiction, and culture provides the unifying framework   for this 21st century fusion into a new whole.
name: Mediated Worlds/THEMAS Pilot: Introduction to Media Arts   and Technology for   Undergraduates in all Colleges and Schools

desc: Provides an introduction to research and scholarship on   current issues ofnational and/or international concern.
instructors: GANS P B, MONTELLO D R, LINZ D G, FOGU C, WELTER V W, STOPPLE J, WELDEAB S, ALAGONA P S, COWHIG F Y
name: Introductory Honors Seminar: Special Topics
prequisites: Enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program; lower-division standing.

desc: Freshman seminars that provide opportunity for students to   investigate a single topic from two different disciplinary   perspectives (Discovery), orin significant depth (Linked).
name: Freshman Seminars - Discovery & Linked

desc: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group discussions which emphasize activeclass participation. Topics will vary each quarter.
instructors: SINGER G H S, FULBECK L K, MCCRACKEN E, AWRAMIK S M, SCOTT V, JAMIESON A E, SMITH S R, REICH N O, DUFFY A E, STUART D D, BAILLARGEON K, MITCHELL G M, DONELAN J H, BROWN M, HARLOW D B
name: Freshman Seminars

desc: Examines the mission of the modern research university and introduces   students to different kinds of work that faculty and staff are engaged in   atUCSB, from the administration of the University to faculty research and   the production of creative projects. Lectures and TA sections explore   opportunities for undergraduate research, internships, the Honors Program,   studying abroad, as well as discussing the various resources available to   excel as a student.Designed for first-generation college   students.
name: The Modern Research University

desc: Introduction to research for College of Letters and Science students participating   in the Faculty Research Assistance Program (FRAP) under the guidance of a   faculty mentor.  Course offers students the opportunity to work in a research   group.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: Advanced group studies in focussed topics in an interdisciplinary area.
instructors: TYLER C M LAVERMAN L E, SMITH S R

timeslots.instructor: TYLER C M LAVERMAN L E

name: Advanced Group Interdisciplinary Studies

desc: Environmental Ethics probes questions of duty and policy regarding human impact on the natural world. Topics such as climate change, sustainable economics, population explosion, and the standing of non-human animals are examined from various perspectives.
name: Environmental Ethics

desc: An interdisciplinary approach to topics of national and world concerns. Readings   will be assigned from several disciplinary perspectives.
instructors: TANIMOTO T, BLAIN S M, WELTER V W, LABUTIN D A
name: Honors Seminar: Special Topics
prequisites: Enrollment in Letters and Science Honors Program; upper-division standing.

desc: “Community Matters” is a 2-unit course and will place 10-15 UCSB   studentsin local public schools to serve as tutors for 2-4 hours   per week during the school day and in after school programs. In   addition to their work inthe public schools, UCSB students will   meet twice weekly to read and discuss texts about civic   responsibility and review models of community engagement, relating   their readings to their experiences as tutors.
name: Community Matters

desc: The Catalyst Writing Lab is a collaborative,   interdisciplinary space for producing /The Catalyst   Literary Magazine/. Those enrolled will take partin   producing three issues of /The Catalyst/.
name: Catalyst Writing Collective

desc: Interactive, collaborative, & interdisciplinary space where members   prepare for competition in and out of state. Competes in AMTA   Regionals and opening round of Championship Series in winter quarter,   with semi- and final rounds held early spring. Students theorize,   strategize, summarize, write, edit, present, debate, and discuss all   aspects of case preparation and oral argument, focusing on opening   statements, witness direct and crossexaminations, rules of evidence   and closing argument. Oratory/persuasive abilities, general writing,   editing, collaborative skills will be developed.
name: Mock Trial

desc: This course produces a quarterly magazine committed to exploring and improving cultural life   in Isla Vista. Working under professional deadlines, students complete writing, design, or   layout assignments in their areas of expertise. Active participation in distribution, ad   sales, event planning, and editing allows for a well-rounded experience in print magazine   production. Attendance at all scheduled classes is mandatory.
name: Word Magazine

desc: This creative writing workshop is for veterans and loved ones   of veteranswho wish to write about their military   experiences. Participants will share and discuss their work   with each other in an informal setting.
name: Interdisciplinary Humanities Seminar

desc: Selected topics of interest to students pursuing various   degrees in the College of Letters and Science. Small group   discussions which emphasize active class participation.   Topics will vary each quarter.
name: Transfer Exploration Seminars

desc: Development of proposals for research in collaboration with faculty and McNair   staff.  Group discussion of research approaches, post-baccalaureate career   preparation, and planning for entrance to doctoral study.
name: Junior Seminar for McNair Scholars
prequisites: Admission to McNair Scholars Program; junior standing.

desc: Students gain familiarity with the key elements of the graduate school   application process, apply to selected graduate schools, engage in collaborative   reading and writing, and prepare research for presentation at academic and   professional meetings.
name: Senior Seminar for McNair Scholars
prequisites: Admission to McNair Scholars Program; senior standing.

desc: Courses designed for students to obtain credit for internship while at the Washington Center.
name: Washington Center Internship
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Washington Center.

desc: Independent research for those enrolled in the Washington Center. Enrolled students will complete a research project related to the students' internship and   drawing on the special resources of the Washington area.
name: Independent Research At Washington Center
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; acceptance to Washington Center.

desc: Independent studies for students in the College of Letters   and Science Honors Program under the auspices of the Dean   of Undergraduate Education
name: Honors Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division Letters & Science Honors Program students only.

desc: Advanced group studies in focussed topics in an interdisciplinary area.
name: Advanced Group Interdisciplinary Studies

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division Italian courses.  Includes orientation workshop, weekly meetings with supervisor, preparation and correction of examinations, preparations of discussion sections, class observations.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Introduction to the most basic elements of Italian grammar. Articles, adjectives, gender. Verbs in the present tense.
instructors: BORROMEO C, DE SIMONE T, FIORINA C P, ARNOLD L B, CRICKETTE M E
name: Elementary Italian

desc: Intended to develop the linguistic skills of students who have completed the first year. Review of basic grammar structures with emphasis on exceptions, enrichment of vocabulary, reading comprehension, and discussion of modern short stories. In Italian.
instructors: CRICKETTE M E, PADULA V, ARNOLD L B
name: Intermediate Italian

desc: Interdisciplinary introduction to modern Italian culture, art, and society from unification (1870) to the present, through readings, oral presentations, and composition. Advanced grammar topics are coordinated with cultural themes, such as nationalism, war, religion and politics.
name: Advanced Reading and Composition: Modern Italy

desc: An intensive workshop exploring the theory and practice of   translation. Students work at translating literary texts from   Italian to English and vice versa.
name: The Art of Translation

desc: An analysis of the relationship between narrative fiction and film in modern Italy ranging from the great works of Antonioni, Visconti, and Rossellinito recent versions of "literary classics" shot for television. In English.
name: Fiction and Film in Italy

desc: Individual investigations in literary and related fields to   Italian Studies in fulfillment of senior honors thesis.   Limited to honors students only.
name: Senior Honors Independent Studies in Italian
prequisites: Senior standing; completion of 24 upper-division units in Italian.

desc: Individual investigations in literary fields.
name: Independent Studies in Italian
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Italian.

desc: This year-long interdisciplinary colloquium brings together   graduate students who study Japanese history and culture. It   introduces current scholarship on Japan via readings,   discussions and presentations by visiting scholars, UCSB   scholars and graduate students. The colloquium meets bi-  weekly. Students will prepare readings for discussion, write   on seminar-length paper and present their paper to the   colloquium once during the year.
name: Reinventing "Japan" Colloquium

desc: This course consists of supervised teaching practice in japanese language.
name: Apprentice Teaching
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor. Employment in this department teaching assistant or linguistic informant.

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by department chair and filed with graduate division.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Study for master's comprehensive examinations and Ph.D examinations.
name: Preparation for Comprehensive Examinations

desc: For research underlying the thesis writing the thesis. Instructor should bethe chair of the student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Terminal preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: An introduction to modern Japanese. Students will develop   basic communicative skills based on the fundamentals of   grammar, vocabulary, and conversational expressions. Emphasis on both oral-  aural proficiency andwriting-reading skills. Introduction to Hiragana and   Katakana syllabaries, and Kanji.
instructors: SHINAGAWA C, SUGAWARA H, CANTRELL A M
name: First-Year Japanese I

desc: Continuation of Japanese 3. Course emphasizes the further development of both oral-aural   proficiency and reading-writing skills with an intensive review of basic grammar as well   as an introduction to more advanced grammar, vocabulary, and Kanji.
instructors: CANTRELL A M, SHINAGAWA C, YAMAUCHI Y
name: Second-Year Japanese
prequisites: Japanese 3 with grade C or better, or equivalent

desc: A survey of the main authors, themes, and styles of the   Japanese religious and philosophical traditions through   readings from and analysis of somesignificant and   influential original texts in English translation.
name: Introduction to Japanese Religion: Texts, Concepts, and   Representations

desc: Develops an intermediate to advanced level of aural-oral   skills to carry on conversations on diverse topics with   linguistic accuracy and cultural appropriateness, reading   skills to comprehend authentic materials, and writing skills   with grammatical accuracy and an increasing number of Kanji.
name: Third-Year Japanese I
prequisites: Japanese 6 with grade C or better, or equivalent

desc: An introduction to the development of Manga (Japanese comics) in relation to other world-wide graphic narrative traditions, with special emphasis on visual analysis and historical context.
name: Understanding Manga

desc: Introduction to Bungo.
name: Classical Japanese (Bungo)

desc: An independent study course (one to three quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in adocumented project or a senior thesis.
name: Senior Honors Project
prequisites: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.

desc: Guided reading in Japanese on a subject not covered in the regularly offered courses.
name: Readings in Japanese
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Japaneseconsent of instructor.

desc: Individual investigations in literary fields.
name: Independent Studies in Japanese
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Japanese;   at least one of those two courses taken with instructor for Japan 199; GPA   for those two courses 3.5 or higher

desc: Faculty supervised research.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Completion of at least 2 upper-division courses in Japanese studies or EastAsian Cultural Studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Historical survey of Asian Americans in the United States from 1850 to the present. Topics include: Immigration patterns, settlement and employment, race and gender relations, community development, and transnational connections.
instructors: SONI M, YU JING, HE F, ZHAO X
name: Introduction to Asian American History, 1850-Present

desc: An examination of central themes in immigration law and policy, especially after the Immigration Act of 1965.  The class focuses on Asian immigrants, but covers immigration trends comparatively.  Topics include economic integration, interracial conflict, subsequent immigration reforms and their consequences.
instructors: DESLIPPE P R, NAGASAWA J E, WU J C, PARK J S W
name: American Migration Since 1965: Asians and others in the United States

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: American Migration Since 1965: Asians and others in the   United States
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in AS AM 2; consent of instructor.

desc: Selected major themes in literary texts from Asian American communities, including Japanese, Chinese, Korean, Filipino and Southeast Asian Americans: dislocation/relocation; finding/inventing a usable past; poetics/politics in language; identities/ethnicities.
instructors: MACIAS H C, RAGHU P, HOESLY D
name: Introduction to Asian American Literature

desc: A intensive introduction to playwriting for beginning   dramatists. Students will read and analyze   the structure of plays, write and stage their ownshort   plays, and gain experience acting in and directing each   other's work. Homework for the course includes a series   of written and performance-based assignments.
name: Introduction to Playwriting

desc: The historical and contemporary experiences of specific Asian   ethnic groups: South Asian Americans (100FF),
name: South Asian Americans

desc: Examines the Asian American Movement of the 1960s-70s in the "long Civil Rights Movement" framework, connecting with earlier and later activism. Focuses on leadership development, pan-Asian identity, Third World solidarities,feminism, education, housing, and antiwar, among other critical issues.
name: Asian Americans and the Long Civil Rights Movement

desc: Presents formal justifications for using racial categories in   American public policy. Course presents racial theories about   other groups, with particular attention to Asians. Covers   period from 1850 to 1990.
name: Asian Americans and Public Policy

desc: Examines the legal dimensions of white supremacy in American public law after   the Civil War.  The course reviews commonly recurring rules and principles about   segregation and racial subordination in American society before the 1960's.
name: Racial Segregation from the Civil War to the Civil Rights   Movement

desc: Survey of the historical and contemporary political experiences of Asian Americans and their pursuits for immigration, equality, citizenship, political identity, racial justice, cross-racial/ethnic coalition building and incorporation into the U. S. political system.
name: Asian American Politics
prequisites: Political Science 12 or Asian American Studies 1 or Asian American Studies 2.

desc: Independent study of topics not covered in the regular curriculum under theguidance of approved faculty member.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: A lower-division Asian American Studies course and 2 upper-division courses; upper-division   standing.

desc: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Asian American Studies

desc: The beginning course in Korean. The student acquires a basic knowledge of the grammar, a limited general vocabulary, correct pronunciation, and an ability to read and understand simple texts. Weekly laboratory assignments support and enhance classroom learning.
name: First Year Korean

desc: Surveys the major social, economic, and cultural impact of the   globalization, commercialization, and consumption of Korean   popular cultural exports and media genres. Adopting a case   study approach, the lectures will analyze pop music,   television, film, and tourist destinations.
name: The New Korean Wave

desc: Individual investigations in literary fields.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division Korean courses; oneof those two courses taken with the instructor for KOR 199; GPA for those two   courses 3.5 or higher

desc: Advanced study of one of the extant works of Rome's first great historian: The Bellum Catilinae or the Bellum Iugurthinum. Translations; discussion ofphilological, stylistic, literary, and historical points; introduction to current scholarship.
name: Sallust

desc: Individual Tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Written proposal approved by department chair and graduate advisor.

desc: Independent research.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Terminal preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Presentation.

desc: The beginning course in classical Latin, and first in a three-  quarter sequence introducing fundamentals of grammar, syntax,   and reading skills. Concepts taught using written exercises.   Interesting aspects of Ancient Roman society are introduced.
instructors: SMITH J S, SEGAL N A, DUTSCH D
name: Elementary Latin

desc: Reading and analysis of various Latin prose authors to develop reading skills and introduce study of the style and thought of historical, rhetorical and/or philosophical writers.
name: Introduction To Latin Prose
prequisites: Latin 3 with a grade of C or better.

desc: Study of one of the extant works of Rome's first great historian: the Bellum Catilinae or the Bellum Iugurthinum. Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, literary, and historical points.
name: Sallust

desc: Independent investigations in Latin language and literature.
name: Independent Studies In Latin.
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair. upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Latin.

desc: Supervised teaching of LAIS discussion sessions at UCSB.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Individual independent study which could include work with EAP. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by student's program adviser andby the department chair. The number of units that a student may take depends on the nature of the program and the consent of the adviser or the graduate committee.
name: Directed Reading and Research

prequisites: graduate standing. no unit credit allowed toward advanced degrees.

desc: Only for research and writing of the thesis under the direction of a faculty member in the program and with the approval of the chair.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Fulfillment of all graduate requirements except the thesis.

desc: Introduction to issues debates, and approaches in the study of Latin America, Spain and Portugal, and the Latino world, from an interdisciplinary perspective. Topics considered include history, culture, society, and literature from various places and times.
instructors: SANTOS-GOMEZ, ALVAREZ D, COLON M R, KHRLOBIAN C Z
name: Introduction to the Latin American and Iberian World

desc: Individual study with the advisor for the purpose of writing a major interdisciplinary research paper on a topic of sufficient depth and sophistication.
name: Senior Honors Thesis
prequisites: Admission to honors program; consent of department.

desc: The description of any one 199 must not be identical to any existing coursedescription.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in LAIS.

desc: Fundamentals of scientific inquiry and methodology;   basics of   experimental design, statistical methods (descriptive and   analytic)   relevant to linguistics such as chi-squared, testing of   distributions and   means, simple correlation and regression.
name: Research Methodology and Statistics in Linguistics

desc: Methods for transcribing conversational discourse, with focus on discourse features relevant to linguistic and interactional research. Features include pause, laughter, intonation, voice, speaker overlap, turn-taking, participation, others. Recording natural conversation, computer-assisted transcription, transcription as theory, alternative transcription systems, transcription ethics/politics.
name: Discourse Transcription

desc: Introduction to fieldwork and language documentation.   Students work   with a speaker of a language unknown to the students for   three   consecutivequarters. Techniques of data collection,   elicitation,   management, and analysis. Emphases include collaborative   research,   theoretical contextualization of field data, and   descriptive and theoretical writing.
name: Field Methods

desc: Functional approaches to syntax. Methods of syntactic   description and explanation. Survey of clause-level   syntactic structures in diverse languages.
name: Advanced Syntax

desc: Specialized topics in sociocultural linguistics.
name: Topics in Sociocultural Linguistics

desc: Sequence of lectures by faculty of the Linguistics Department and closely related departments, to acquaint new graduate students with current faculty research, and with research directions and resources of the campus.
name: Research Orientation

desc: Presentations on current topics in linguistics by visiting scholars, faculty, and graduate students.
name: Linguistics Colloquium

desc: Supervised teaching of undergraduate linguistics courses.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum
prequisites: Appointment as teaching assistant and departmental approval.

desc: Covers development of teaching techniques.
name: Teaching Assistant Seminar

desc: Research under the direction of a faculty member(s).
name: Research in Linguistics

desc: The second quarter continuation of a MA-level elective course.    May be taken only once during a student's career to satisfy   one of the Ph.D. levelseminar requirements.  May not be taken   as the continuation of an MA-level required course.
name: Seminar Paper
prequisites: Completion of a Linguistics MA-level elective course.

desc: Limited to small groups whose interest and needs determine the central focus.
name: Graduate Group Studies in Linguistics

desc: Individual tutorial in any area of linguistics.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of the committee.
name: Individual Study for Master's and Ph.D.
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Instructor normally should be chair of the student's thesis committee. Onlyfor research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Ph.d dissertation research and preparation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Instructor approval required prior to registration.

desc: Designed for focused instruction in oral and written academic English.  Enrollment by instructor consent.  Preference given to students at advanced proficiency levels.
name: EMS: Individual and Small Group Instruction for International Graduate Students

desc: Introduction to the scientific study of language: The sounds of language;  word and sentence structure; semantics and pragmatics; discourse and   conversational speech; the social and cultural functions of language;   language change and the reconstruction of languages at earlier stages.
instructors: LESTER N A, CROUCH C Q, SCHAEFER K J, CAMINSKY D W
name: Language And Linguistics

desc: Examines how social identities and relations (nationality,   class,  ethnicity, age, gender) are constructed, maintained,   and challenged  via language practices, policies, and   ideologies. Considers power  dynamics in multiple domains   including everyday interaction,  education, media   (advertising, news, film/tv, online), and political    discourse.
instructors: LOPEZ A N, PETERS S L, AUDERSET S, FINE J C
name: Language and Power

desc: An introduction to the analytic methodology in the study of phonology,   morphology,   syntax, and semantics. A typologically oriented course designedto   demonstrate how   linguists analyze languages.
name: Basic Elements Of Linguistic Analysis

desc: Fundamentals of scientific inquiry and methodology; basics of   experimental design, statistical methods (descriptive,   analytic, and exploratory) relevant to linguistics
name: Statistical Methods in Linguistics

desc: An introduction to the articulatory and acoustic properties   of speech sounds. Survey   of speech sounds found in the languages of the world.   Emphasis on ear training and   transcription using the International Phonetic Alphabet.
instructors: GORDON M K, TSAI K, HIEBER D W
name: Introduction to Phonetics

desc: Linguistic practices of major ethnoracial groups in the United States, including African Americans, Asian Americans, European Americans, Latinos, and Native Americans; examination of the linguistic effects of immigration and colonialism; bilingualism, code switching, style shifting, language shift, and heritage language learning; linguistic interaction and contact between ethnoracial groups; language as a resource for ethnoracial identity; linguistic racism; linguistic activism.
instructors: BUCHOLTZ M H, FAWCETT A Z, GARZA J Y
name: Language, Race and Ethnicity

desc: Introduction to the languages of the world: Geographical   distribution; genetic (genealogical) classification,   including comparison with genetics and archeology;   structural properties and sociolinguistics of selected   languages representing different parts of the world.
instructors: COMRIE B S, SIMS N A
name: Languages of the World

desc: Limited to small groups whose interest and needs determine the   central focus.
instructors: BECENTI G, DU BOIS J W
name: Group Studies In Linguistics

desc: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.
name: Honors Thesis

desc: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.
name: Honors Thesis.

desc: Guided research and writing of an original research paper to meet the requirements of the honors program in Linguistics.
name: Honors Thesis

desc: Intended for the study of special areas within Linguistics.
name: Independent Studies In Linguistics.
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in linguistics; consent of instructor.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance In Linguistics.
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in linguistics; consent of instructor and department.

desc: A series of lectures and seminars on diverse research topics in marine science.
name: Seminar in Marine Science

desc: Individual tutorial. Hours and credit by arrangement with faculty.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: MS candidate and consent of commitee chair.

desc: For writing of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Ph.D. candidate and consent of instructor.

desc: The microscopic statistical mechanical foundations of the macroscopic   thermodynamics of materials, with applications to ideal and non-ideal gases,  electrons and phonons in solids, multicomponent solutions, phase equilibriain   single and multicomponent systems, and capillarity.
name: Thermodynamic Foundation of Materials

desc: Matrices and tensors, stress and deformation, compatibility   and equilibrium conditions, constitutive equations, and   boundary conditions, applications in elasticity, plasticity   and fracture.
name: Mechanics of Materials

desc: Diffraction theory: fourier transformation, schrodinger equation,   Maxwell's equations, kinematical theory, Fresnel diffraction, Fraunhofer   diffraction, scattering of x-rays, electrons and neutrons by isolated atoms and   assemblies of atoms, pair correlation and radial distribution functions. Basic   symmetry operations, point groups, space groups.
name: Crystallography and Diffraction Fundamentals

desc: Intensive theoretical and laboratory instruction in solid-state device and integrated circuit fabrication. Topics include 1) semiconductor material   properties and characterization; 2) phase diagrams; 3) diffusion; 4) thermal   oxidation; 5) vacuum processes; 6) thin-film deposition; 7) scanning electron   microscopy. Both gallium arsenide and silicon technologies are presented.
name: Semiconductor Device Processing

desc: Review field equations of elasticity and plasticity.   Energy   principles and uniqueness theorems. Elementary problems   in one   and two dimensions,stress functions, and complex   variable   methods. Plastic stress-strain laws; flow potentials.   Torsion   and bending of plastic flow, slip line theory. Bounding   theorems.
name: Elasticity and Plasticity

desc: The use of x-ray and neutron scattering to characterize   solid state materials.   Subjects include the crystal unit cell, space groups,   structure determination   and refinement. It is recommended that the student have   anelementary   introduction to vectors, matrices and fourier series.
name: Structural Inorganic Chemistry

desc: Fundamental concepts and mathematical models underlying   major types of   processes for inorganic materials, with emphasis on the   relationships between   processing and microstructure.  Topics include: melting   and solidification,   powder synthesis and consolidation, coatings and surface   treatments.
name: Processing of Inorganic Materials

desc: Stress and strain relations in composites. Residual stresses. The fracture resistance of organic and inorganic matrix composites. Statistical aspects of   fiber failure. Composite laminates and delamination cracks. Cumulativedamage   concepts. Interface properties. Design criteria.
name: Composite Materials

desc: Review of semiconductor physics, growth technology, and   materials   properties; double-heterostructure and quantum-well laser   structures; carrier and photon rate equations; light vs. current   characteristics; scattering and   transmission matrices; compound cavity, distributed bragg   reflector, and   distributed feedback lasers.
name: Semiconductor Lasers I
prequisites: ECE 162A-B-C; or MATRL 162A-B and ECE 162C; or ECE 144.

desc: Basics of preparation of polymer and macromolecular   assemblies, and   characterizaton of large molecules and assemblies.   Discussion of chemical   structure, bonding, and reactivity.
name: Synthesis and Properties of Macromolecules

desc: Experiments using X-ray and light scattering, optical and electron microscopy.   Crystalline, quasi-crystalline and amorphous materials. Solid, solution, and   colloidal samples.
name: Experiments in Macromolecular Materials

desc: Survey of classes of biomolecules (lipids, carbohydrates,   proteins, nucleic   acids). Structure and function of molecular machines   (enzymes for biosynthesis,   motors, pumps).
name: Biomolecular Materials I: Structure and Function

desc: Basic theory and methods of electronic structure, illustrated with examplesof   practical computational methods and real-world applications.  Topics: Band   structure; Uniform electron gas; Density functional theory; Exchangeand   correlation; Kohn-Sham equations; Pseudopotentials; Basis sets; Predicting   materials properties: bulk, surfaces, interfaces, defects.
name: First-Principles Calculations for Materials

desc: This course will be offered on an irregular basis and will include in-depthdiscussions of advanced topics in inorganic materials.
name: Special Topics in Inorganic Materials

desc: This course will be offered on an irregular basis and will concern in-depthdiscussions of advanced topics in electronic materials.
name: Special Topics in Electronic Materials

desc: This course will be offered on an irregular basis and will   concern in-depthdiscussions of advanced topics in structural   materials.
name: Special Topics in Structural Materials

desc: In this course students or instructors present recently published papers and/or results relevant to their own research.
name: Research Group Studies

desc: Practical experience in the various activities associated with teaching including: lecturing, supervision of laboratories and discussion sections, preparation, and grading of homework and exams.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor usually student's major professor. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Research and preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of chair of student's doctoral committee.

desc: An introduction to materials in modern technology. The   internal structureof   materials and its underlying principles: bonding, spatial   organization of atoms   and molecules, structural defects. Electricial, magnetic   and optical properties of   materials, and their relationship with structure.
instructors: RUSCHEL A L, WENDORF J H
name: Structure and Properties I

desc: Electrons as particles and waves, Schrodinger's equation and illustrative  solutions. Tunneling. Atomic structures, the exclusion principle and the   periodic table. Bonds. Free electrons in metals, periodic potentials and   energy   bands.
name: The Quantum Description of Electronic Materials
prequisites: ECE 130A-B and 134 with a minimum grade of C- in all; open to EE, senior students in the BS/MS   programs and Materials graduate students only.

desc: Measure theory and integration. Point set topology. Principles of functional analysis. Lp-spaces. The Riesz representation theorem. Topics in real andfunctional analysis.
name: Real Analysis

desc: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix   computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.
name: Matrix Analysis and Computation

desc: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic partial differential equations, with application to problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.
name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations - Finite   Element Methods

desc: Existence, uniqueness, and stability; the geometry of phase space; linear systems and hyperbolicity; maps and diffeomorphisms.
name: Ordinary Differential Equations

desc: Group theory, ring and module theory, field theory, Galois theory, other topics.
name: Modern Algebra

desc: Metric spaces, topological spaces, continuity, Hausdorff condition, compactness, connectedness, product spaces, quotient spaces. Other topics as time allows.
name: Foundations of Topology

desc: Selected topics in number theory.
name: Topics in Number Theory

desc: Topics, varying from year to year, include piecewise linear and differential topology, manifolds, fiber bundles and fiber spaces, homotopy theory, andspectral sequences.
name: Advanced Topics in Geometric and Algebraic Topology

desc: Differentiable manifolds, definition and examples of lie groups, lie group-lie algebra correspondence, nilpotent and solvable lie algebras, classification of semi-simple lie algebras over the complexes, representations of liegroups and lie algebras, special topics.
name: Lie Groups and Lie Algebras

desc: Topics include geometry of surfaces, manifolds, differential forms, Lie groups, Riemannian manifolds, Levi-Civita connection and curvature, curvature and topology, Hodge theory. Additional topics such as bundles and characteristic classes, spin structures, and Dirac operator, comparison theorems in Riemannian geometry.
name: Introduction to Differential Geometry and Riemannian Geometry

desc: Various topics are covered including sectional curvature and Ricci curvature, minimal submanifolds, Atiyah-Singer index theorem and eta invariant, Einstein manifold, symplectic geometry, geometry of gauge theories, geometric PDE, Morse theory and Floer theory.
name: Topics in Differential Geometry

desc: Existence and stability of solutions, Floquet theory, Poincare-Bendixson theorem, invariant manifolds, existence and stability of periodic solutions, Bifurcation theory and normal forms, hyperbolic structure and chaos, Feigenbaum period-doubling cascade, Ruelle-Takens cascade.
name: Ordinary Differential Equations

desc: Topics in algebra, analysis, applied mathematics, combinatorial mathematics, functional analysis, geometry, statistics, topology, by means of lecturesand informal conferences with members of staff.
instructors: OGRAIN C M, ATZBERGER P J, BIRNIR B, HUISGEN-ZIMME
name: Seminars in Mathematics

desc: Supervised teaching of undergraduate mathematics courses.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum
prequisites: Appointment as teaching assistant and departmental approval.

desc: Consideration of ideas about the process of learning mathematics and discussion of approaches to teaching.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Supervised teaching of undergraduate courses.
name: Teaching Associate Practicum

desc: Directed reading and research.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Master's thesis research and preparation.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Dissertation preparation.
name: Dissertation Preparation

desc: Math 3A with precalculus: A function approach integrating algebra, trigonometry, and differential calculus. Topics include: one-on-one and onto functions; inverse functions; properties and graphs of polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic functions; properties and graphs of trigonometric functions; analytic geometry; functions and limits; derivatives; techniquesand applications of differentiation; logarithmic and trigonometric functions.
instructors: GARFIELD P M, FROST G A, TRISAL A V
name: Calculus with Algebra and Trigonometry
prequisites: Qualifying score on the Mathematics Placement Exam.

desc: Differential Calculus including analytic geometry, functions and limits, derivatives, techniques and applications of   differentiation, logarithmic and trigonometric functions.
instructors: BIGELOW S J, KALAULI A K, LU D, WRIGHT K M, VARBLE M R, GARFIELD P M, HIGGINS V B
name: Calculus with Applications, First Course
prequisites: Qualifying score on the Mathematics Placement Exam.

desc: Integral calculus including definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, with applications in   mathematics and physics.
instructors: KELZ J M, SCHLEY N B, CARLSON R J, TENER J E, PABLO S R, ROBERTS J A, LIU L, FRYER S, PHAM K N
name: Calculus with Applications, Second Course
prequisites: Mathematics 3A with a minimum grade of C.

desc: Systems of linear equations, matrix algebra, determinants, vector spaces and subspaces, basis and dimension, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, and orthogonality.
instructors: GOODEARL K, PEDRICK M G, BUENO C, WELLS S B, QIU Y, BLUMENSTEIN Z, ROBINETT E L, FORD S I, LAINEZ REYES, KAMINSKY J M, LI YIHAN
name: Linear Algebra with Applications
prequisites: Math 2B or 3B or 3BI with a minimum grade of C.

desc: First and second order differential equations, separation of variables, linear differential equations, systems of first order equations, nonlinear differential equations and stability.
instructors: CHAI L, SHIFLEY T H, KHOSHBIN M, GEEVECHI A A, SETO S, NGUYEN D
name: Differential Equations
prequisites: Math 4A or Math 4AI with a minimum grade of C.

desc: Calculus of functions of several variables, vector-valued   functions of one variable, scalar and vector fields,   integration along paths, double andtriple integrals,   integration over surfaces, properties, and applicationsof   integrals, and classical integration theorems of vector   calculus.
instructors: PANAGIOTOU E, TRETTEL S J, CHAHINE Y K, BLOOMQUIST W, HATELEY J C
name: Vector Calculus with Applications, First Course
prequisites: Mathematics 4A (or 4AI) or Mathematics 5A (or 5AI) with a letter grade of Cor better.

desc: Integral theorems of vector calculus (continuation), infinite   series, Fourier series, integrals and transforms, partial   differential equations.
instructors: KAMINSKY J M, GORMAN C H, HAWKINS C P
name: Vector calculus with Applications, Second Course
prequisites: Mathematics 5B  or 5BI with a minimum grade of C; or, Mathematics 4B (or 4BI)   and Mathematics 6A (or 6AI), each with a minimum grade of C.

desc: Emphasizing fundamental concepts and applications. Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Honors Seminar-Calculus
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Mathematics 3A or 3B or 3BI or 3C or 4A or 4AI or 4B   or 4BI or 5A or 5AI or 6A or 6AI or 6B.

desc: Introduction to the elements of propositional logic,   techniques of mathematical proof, and fundamental mathematical   structures, including sets, functions, relations, and other   topics as time permits. Mastery of this material is essential   for students planning to major in mathematics.
instructors: PFAFF C E, BLACKER C A, SCHARLEMANN M, SCHULTE A J, CASTEELS K L, SARAJIAN G P, KELZ J M, SCHERICH N C, DEMER E M
name: Transition to Higher Mathematics
prequisites: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI or 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI or 5B or   5BIor 5C or 6A or 6AI or   6B with a grade of B or better.

desc: Introduction to differential and integral calculus with   applications to modeling in the biological sciences.
instructors: AKEMANN C A, ALTHAUSER S B, BAGHERI A R, LUO JIAJIE, KUBLER J W, BALKIN R A, HAKE K S, CHEN Q, EPELBAUM D P, MARTINEZ ESPA, PANKAU J C
name: Calculus for Social and Life Sciences

desc: Lectures and discussions on special topics.
name: Group Studies in Mathematics

desc: Especially suitable for prospective teachers. A conceptual   rather than anaxiomatic development starting with the natural   numbers and progressing through the integral, rational, real,   and complex number systems. The historical implications of   these developments in number systems.
name: Classical Number Systems
prequisites: Mathematics 3A; and Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.

desc: Discussion and solution of nonroutine mathematical   problems related with different problem-solving techniques. Possible topics   are: Pigeonhole principle,   use of invariants and symmetries in problem solving,   coloring arguments, parity,   recursive arguments, extreme principle, inclusion-  exclusion principle.
name: Problem Solving I

desc: Numerical methods for the solution of nonlinear equations   (Newton method), for integration (quadrature formulas and composite   integration), and for the initial value problem for ordinary differential   equations (Euler and Kutta methods).
name: Introduction Into Numerical Analysis
prequisites: Mathematics 4B or 4BI, 6A or 6AI, and 6B; or 5A or 5AI, 5B or 5BI and 5C;  and, Math 8, and Math 117 and, Computer Science 5AA-ZZ or 10 or 8 or 16 or Engineering 3, each with a grade of C or above.

desc: Abstract vector spaces subspaces. Span and linear   independence. Basis anddimension. Linear maps. Eigenvalues   and eigenvectors.
instructors: DAI X Z, WEI G, GUANG Q, PFAFF C E
name: Introduction to Linear Algebra
prequisites: Mathematics 3C or 3CI or 4A or 4AI, 4B or 4BI or 5A or 5AI; and Math 8 witha grade of "C" or better.

desc: An introduction to algebraic structures with an emphasis on   groups.
name: Introduction to Abstract Algebra
prequisites: Mathematics 108A with a grade of "C" or better.

desc: An introduction to hyperbolic geometry with some discussion of other non-  euclidean systems.
name: Non-euclidean Geometry
prequisites: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.

desc: Introduction to programming with specific examples in   scientific computing. The algorithms used will be analyzed   in detail in Math 104A-B-C. The emphasis will be the   translation of numerical algorithms into actual working   code.
name: Computational Tools for Numerical Analysis
prequisites: Math 6B, Math 8, and Math 108A or Math 117 each with a letter grade of   "C" or higher.

desc: Introduction to methods of proof in analysis. topics include limits, sequences   and series, continuity, compactness, as well as other topics. This course is   intended to follow Mathematics 8 and to introduce students to thelevel of   sophistication of upper-division mathematics.
name: Methods of Analysis
prequisites: Mathematics 8 with a grade of "C" or better.

desc: The real number system, elements of set theory, continuity,   differentiability, Riemann integral, implicit function   theorems, convergence processes, and special topics.
name: Introduction to Real Analysis
prequisites: Mathematics 5A or 5AI and 5B or 5BI; or 4B or 4BI and 6A or 6AI; and   108A-B and 117 each with a grade of "C" or better.

desc: Existence, uniqueness, and stability; the geometry of phase   space; linearsystems and hyperbolicity; maps and   diffeomorphisms.
name: Ordinary Differential Equations
prequisites: Mathematics 5A or 5AI and 5B or 5BI; or 4B or 4BI and 6A or 6AI; and,   Math 8 with a minimum grade of C.

desc: Lectures on a coherent body of mathematical topics which are not usually presented in standard mathematics courses.
name: Special Topics

desc: A formal introduction to the language and culture of mathematics.    Students will learn how to rigorously think about mathematics and write   mathematical proofs. Topics covered include: propositional logic, set theory,   cardinality, number theory, and various number systems.
name: Introduction to the Higher Mathematics

desc: Information about the special topics to be presented may be obtained from the office of the Department of Mathematics.
name: Special Topics in Mathematics

desc: Independent research under the supervision of a faculty member which will result in a senior thesis. Student will concentrate on reading and gatheringmaterial for a thesis.
name: Senior Thesis
prequisites: Open to senior majors only; consent of department and instructor.

desc: Coursework shall consist of academic research supervised by a faculty member on a topic not available in established course offerings.
name: Independent Studies in Mathematics
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in math; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in math; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Discussion and solution of nonroutine mathematical   problems related with different problem-solving techniques. Possible topics   are: Pigeonhole principle,   use of invariants and symmetries in problem solving,   coloring arguments, parity,   recursive arguments, extreme principle, inclusion-  exclusion principle.
name: Problem Solving I

desc: Lectures on a coherent body of mathematical topics which are not usually presented in standard mathematics courses.
name: Special Topics

desc: A formal introduction to the language and culture of mathematics.    Students will learn how to rigorously think about mathematics and write   mathematical proofs. Topics covered include: propositional logic, set theory,   cardinality, number theory, and various number systems.
name: Introduction to the Higher Mathematics

desc: A survey of the development of astronomy with an emphasis on understanding the observable properties of the solar system, the sun and other stars, ourown and other galaxies, and the entire universe. Topics of current interestwill be discussed as time permits.
instructors: GELLER R M, HIRAMATSU D, BURKE J F
name: Basic Astronomy

desc: A supplement to Astronomy 1 emphasizing fundamental   concepts and additional topics in astronomy. Intended for   highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Honors Supplement to Basic Astronomy
prequisites: Honors standing. Concurrent enrollment in ASTRO 1.

desc: A series of weekly lectures given by university staff and   outside expertsin   all fields of mechanical engineering.
name: Professional Seminar

desc: A ten-week individual research project on an advanced topic in mechanical engineering.
name: M.S. Project

desc: A series of bi-weekly presentations given by ladder faculty members to familiarize graduate students with current department research projects. This course is required to be taken by all graduate students within the first year of arrival.
name: Faculty Research Seminar

desc: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.
name: Matrix Analysis and Computation

desc: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptical partial differential equations, with applicationto problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.
name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations - Finite Element Methods

desc: Phase-plane methods, non-linear oscillators, stability of fixed points and periodic orbits, invariant manifolds, structural stability, normal form theory, local bifurcations for vector fields and maps, applications from engineering, physics, chemistry, and biology.
name: Applied Dynamical Systems I

desc: Matrices and tensors, stress and deformation, compatibility   and equilibrium conditions, constitutive equations, and   boundary conditions, applications in elasticity, plasticity   and fracture.
name: Mechanics of Materials

desc: Introductory course in fluid mechanics. Basic equations of motion (continuity, momentum, energy, vorticity), coordinate transformations, "potential" flow, thin airfoil theory, conformal mapping, vortex dynamics, boundary layers, stability theory, laminar/turbulent transition, turbulence. Inviscid/viscid, irrotational/rotational, incompressible/ compressible flow examples.
name: Fundamentals of Fluid Mechanics

desc: Specialized courses dealing with advanced topics and recent developments inone or more of the following areas: dynamic systems, control and robotics, fluid mechanics, materials science and engineering, ocean engineering, solid mechanics and structures, thermal sciences.
instructors: LIAO B, HAWKES E W, MCMEEKING R M
name: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering

desc: Review field equations of elasticity and plasticity.   Energy   principles and uniqueness theorems. Elementary problems   in one   and two dimensions,stress functions, and complex   variable   methods. Plastic stress-strain laws; flow potentials.   Torsion   and bending of plastic flow, slip line theory. Bounding   theorems.
name: Elasticity and Plasticity

desc: Internal and external descriptions. Solution of state equations. Controllability and observability realizations. Pole assignment, assignment, observers; modern compensator design. Distribance localization and decoupling. Least-squares control. Least-squares estimation; Kalman filters; smoothing. Theseperation theorem; LQG compensator design. Computational considerations. Selected additional topics.
name: Linear Systems I
