desc: Methods of solution of partial differential equations and boundary value problems. Linear vector and function spaces, generalized fourier analysis, Sturm-Liouville theory, calculus of variations, and conformal mapping techniques.
name: Advanced Theoretical Methods in Engineering

desc: Introduces students to the concepts of multiphysics   simulation. Students are   introduced to PDE's, associated analytical solutions, and   the finite element   method. Multiphysics problems are solved in multiple   domains,and with   fluid/structure interactions. Each student conducts a   project where   multiphysics   tools are used to explore details of multiphysical  processes.
name: Introduction to Multiphysics Simulation

desc: Stress and strain relations in composites. Residual stresses. The fracture resistance of organic and inorganic matrix composites. Statistical aspects of fiber failure. Composite laminates and delamination cracks. Cumulative damage concepts. Interface properties. Design criteria.
name: Composite Materials

desc: A series of weekly lectures given by university staff and outside experts in the fields of control systems, dynamical systems, and computation.
name: Group Studies: Controls, Dynamical Systems, and Computation

desc: Practical experience in the various activities associated with teaching, including lecturing, supervision of laboratories and discussion sections, preparation and grading of homework and exams.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Practical experience in the various activities associated with research, including experimental work, theoretical work and analyses, and assisting department faculty and other professional researchers in their duties.
name: Research Assistant Practicum

desc: Experimental or theoretical research undertaken under the direction of a faculty member for graduate students who have not yet advanced to candidacy.
name: Directed Research

desc: Individual studies for ph.d. qualifying examination.
name: Individual Study for Ph.D. Qualifying Examination

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: For research and preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: The theme question of this course is, "What do mechanical engineers   do?" Survey of mechanical engineering applications. Lectures by mechanical   engineering faculty and practicing engineers.
name: Introductory Concepts in Mechanical Engineering

desc: Basic machine shop skills course. Students learn to work safely in a machine   shop.   Students are introduced to the use of hand tools, the lathe, the milling machine,   drill press, saws, and precision measuring tools. Students apply these skills by   completing a project.
name: Introduction to Machine Shop

desc: Introduction to applied mechanics. Forces, moments, couples, and resultants;   vector algebra; construction of free body diagrams; equilibrium in 2- and 3-  dimensions; analysis of frames, machines, trusses and beams; distributed   forces; friction.
instructors: DALY S H, LANE K V, GOCKOWSKI L F, HUANG E Y
name: Statics
prequisites: Math 3B, or AP Calculus AB with a score of 5, or AP Calculus BC with a score of 3 or better; and   Physics 1

desc: Participation in projects in the laboratory or machine shop. Projects may be student- or faculty-originated depending upon student interest and consent of faculty member.
name: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering

desc: Course offers students opportunity to work on established departmental design projects. P/NP grading, does not satisfy technical elective requirement.
name: Mechanical Engineering Design Projects

desc: Directed study to be arranged with individual faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to participate in a research group.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: A series of weekly lectures given by university staff and outside   expertsin all fields of mechanical engineering.
name: Professional Seminar

desc: Interfacing of mechanical and electrical systems and mechatronics. Basic   introduction to sensors, actuators, and computer interfacing and control.  Transducers and measurement devices, actuators, A/D and D/A conversion,   signal conditioning and filtering. Practical skills developed in weekly lab exercises.
instructors: TURNER K L, BOYLES A J, SHUKLA P J
name: Mechatronics
prequisites: ME 6; open to ME majors only.

desc: Individual courses each concentrating on one area in the   following subjects: applied mechanics, cad/cam, controls, design, environmental   engineering, fluid mechanics, materials science, mechanics of solids and   structures, ocean and coastal engineering, robotics, theoretical   mechanics,thermalsciences, and recent developments in mechanical engineering.
name: Special Topics in Mechanical Engineering

desc: Introductory course addresses the challenges of biomedical   device design,prototyping and testing, material considerations, regulatory   requirements,   design control, human factors and ethics.
name: Design of Biomedical Devices
prequisites: Mechanical Engineering 10, 14, 15, 16, and 153; open to ME majors only.

desc: Numerical analysis and analytical solutions of problems   described by linear and   nonlinear differential equations with an emphasis on MATLAB.   First and second   order differential equations; systems of differential   equations; linear algebraic   equations, matrices and eigenvalues; boundary value   problems; finite   differences.
name: Numerical Analysis in Engineering
prequisites: ME 17 with a minimum grade of C-, or Chemical Engineering 132A.

desc: Basic concepts in thermodynamics, system analysis, energy,   thermodynamic laws, and cycles.
name: Thermosciences 1
prequisites: Physics 2; ME 14 with a minimum grade of C-; and, Mathematics 5C or   Mathematics 6B.

desc: Introduction to the fundamental concepts in fluid mechanics and basic fluidproperties. Basic   equations of fluid flow. Dimensional analysis and similitude. Hydrodynamics.
name: Fluid Mechanics
prequisites: Mathematics 5C or Math 6B; and, ME 16 with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Introductory course in structural analysis and design. The theories of matrix   structural analysis and finite element analysis for the solution of analytical and   design problems in structures are emphasized. Lecture material includes   structural theory compatibility method, slope deflection method, displacement   method, and virtual work. Topics include applications tobars, beams, trusses,   frames, and solids.
name: Design and Analysis of Structures
prequisites: ME 15 with a minimum grade of C-; and, ME 16 with a minimum grade of C-; open to ME majors   only.

desc: The rational selection of engineering materials, and the utilization of Ashby-  charts, stress, strain, strength, and fatigue failure consideration asapplied to   the   design of machine elements. Lectures also support the development of   system design concepts using assigned projects and involve the   preparation of   engineering reports and drawings.
name: Mechanical Engineering Design - I
prequisites: ME 14, with a minimum grade of C-; and ME 15, with a minimum grade of C-; and MATRL 101   (or   MATRL 100B); or consent of instructor.  Open to ME majors only

desc: Introduces students to the concepts of multiphysics   simulation. Students are   introduced to PDE's, associated analytical solutions, and   the finite elements   method.  Multiphysics problems are solved in multiple   domains, and with   fluid/structure interactions. Each student conducts a   project where multiphysics   tools are used to explore details of multiphysical processes.
name: Introduction to Multiphysics Simulation
prequisites: Mechanical Engineering 151A-B; and Mechanical Engineering 152A-B; and   Mechanical Engineering 140A

desc: Presents introductory matrix methods for analysis of structures. Topics include review of matrix algebra and linear equations, basic structural theorms including the principle of superposition and energy theorms, truss bar, bean and plane frame elements, and programming techniques to realize these concepts.
name: Structural Analysis

desc: Dynamic modeling and control methods for robotic systems. Lagrangian methodfor deriving equations of motion, introduction to the Jacobian, and modeling and   control of forces and contact dynamics at a robotic end effector. Laboratories   encourage a problem-solving approach to control.
name: Introduction to Robotics: Dynamics and Control
prequisites: ECE 130A or ME 155A (may be taken concurrently)

desc: Design, programming, and testing of mobile robots. Design problems are   formulated in terms   of robot performance. Students solve electromechanical problems, developing   skills in   brainstorming, concept selection, spatial reasoning, teamwork and   communication. Robots   are controlled with micro-controllers using C programming and interfaced to   sensors and   motors.
name: Introduction to Robotics: Design Laboratory
prequisites: Engr 3; and ME 6 or ECE 2A. Not open for credit to students who have   completed ME 170C   or ECE   181C.

desc: Students work in teams under the direction of a faculty advisor (and possibly   an industrial   sponsor) to tackle an engineering design project. Engineering communication,   such as   reports and oral presentations are covered. Emphasis on practical, hands-on   experience, and   the integration of analytical and design skills.
name: Capstone Mechanical Engineering Design Project
prequisites: ME 105; and ME 151C; and ME 152B; and ME 153; and ME 163; or consent of instructor.   Open to ME majors only.

desc: Students obtain credit for a mechanical engineering related internship and/or industrial experience under faculty supervision. A 6-10 page written report is required for credit. It may NOT be used to satisfy the engineering elective requirement for ME majors.
name: Internship in Industry
prequisites: Consent of instructor. Prior departmental approval needed.

desc: Special projects in design engineering. Course offers motivated students   opportunity to synthesize academic skills by designing and building new   machines.
name: Independent Projects in Mechanical Engineering Design

desc: Directed individual study.
name: Independent Studies in Mechanical Engineering
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in   Mechanical Engineering.

desc: Overview of music and technology, including historical aspects. Readings and   exercises with a range of music software applications. Basics of Internet audio   and evolving media, music production, business, technical, and aesthetic   aspects.
name: Music and Technology

desc: A six-quarter practical programming course devoted to digital audio applications development. The emphasis is on learning to use current state-of-the-art programming methods, tools, and library APIs. Programming assignments are given in the C, C++, Java, Smalltalk and/or SuperCollider programming language. Topics: A. Using Commerical I/O APIs; B. Spectral Transformations; C. Spatial Sound Manipulation; D. Sound Synthesis Techniques; E. Multi-rateControl and Synchronization; F. Media Application Integration.
name: Digital Audio Programming: The Series

desc: Artistic, philosophical, scientific, and technical foundations of transdisciplinarity, transmodality, and Transvergence. New conceptions of actual, virtual, and informational space and form. Trans-Euclidean geometry, from Gauss to present. Emergence and immanence in algorithmic poetics and information aesthetics. Models of physical, biological, and social complex systems. Worldmaking and epistemology.
name: Transvergence Seminar I

desc: First quarter of a three-quarter sequence course concentrates on multi-track   recording, mixing, digital signal processing, and studio based composition.
name: Digital Audio Montage
prequisites: Graduate MAT majors and graduate non-majors in areas of electrical engineering, computer science,   physics and math; consent of instructor.

desc: Special projects for selected students. Offered in conjunction with selected industrial and research under direct faculty supervision. Prior departmental approval required.
name: Internship in Industry

desc: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Offers an opportunity to qualified students to undertake independent research or work in a group laboratory in digital media arts and technology.
name: Independent Study
prequisites: Consent of graduate advisor and Director of graduate studies.

desc: Courses taught or assisted by T.A.'s.
name: Teaching in Media Art & Technology

desc: Special course in selected problems in multimedia engineering, visual arts,or electronic music.
name: Special Topics in Multimedia Engineering, Visual Arts or Electronic Music

desc: Special seminar in selected problems in multimedia   engineering, visual arts, or electronic music.
name: Special Topics in Multimedia Engineering, Visual Arts or   Electronic Music

desc: Special course in selected problems in multimedia engineering, visual arts,or electronic music.
name: Special Topics in Multimedia Engineering, Visual Arts or Electronic Music

desc: Special Seminars Focusing on Topics of Interest in Media Arts and Technology.
name: Media Arts and Technology Seminar

desc: Independent research, either experimental or theoretical, may be taken by properly qualified graduate students under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Directed Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor and Director of graduate studies.

desc: Maximum of 12 units per quarter; enrollment limited to 24 units per examination. Instructor is normally student's major advisor or chair of dissertation committee. S/U grading. Individual studies for Ph.D. qualifying examination.
name: Individual Study for Ph.D. Examinations

desc: For research underlying the thesis/project and writing of the thesis/project.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Project Research

desc: For research and preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Students attend and write responses to papers by visiting lecturers on topics in various fields of Medieval Studies. Themes will vary from year to year.
name: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Medieval Studies

desc: Introduction to the organization, purpose, and functions of the U.S. Army. Provides the foundation in basic life skills to include fitness,interpersonal communication and ethical behavior using current Army models. Provide insight into the Army's profession of arms and officer's role within that profession.
name: Introduction to Leadership I

desc: Explores leadership and leadership problems solving case study: A broad analysis of leadership with an emphasis on the modern leader. Familiarization with case study on decision making and the modern army leader. Course is designed to maximize student participation, inspire intellectual curiosity, teach critical "life skills," and stimulate self-study.
name: Foundations of Leadership I

desc: Students attend the 28-day paid Leadership Training Course   designed to develop leadership and officer potential for the   U.S. Army and ultimately contracting into the Army's ROTC   advance course program. Training is intentionally stressful   and designed to build individual confidence through the   accomplishment of leadership opportunities.
name: Basic Military Science Field Study

desc: Basic physical conditioning using the United States Army physical training program. Emphasis on cardiovascular system and upper body strength. Focus towards army officer training corps cadets, although not limited to this group.
name: Basic Military Physical Conditioning

desc: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Study of military leadership principles, responsibilities, and traits in a small unit, emphasizing adaptability and flexibility. Master technical skills in land Navigation, Troop Leading Producers, Tactical Orders, Battle Drills and Squad Tactics. Gain practical experience by planning and executing small unit military training events.
name: Tactical leadership I

desc: Students study the fundamentals of decision making, command and control problems, staff relationships, counseling,analyzing courses of action. Leadership laboratory required for all ROTC students. Students gain practical experience by planning and executing cadet training and social events. Labs required.
name: Developmental Leadership I

desc: Students attend the 33-day paid Leadership Development   Advanced Course   designed to further develop and evaluate leadership and   officer potential. The   challenges are rigorous and demanding, both mentally and   Physically, and will   test intelligence, common sense, ingenuity and stamina.
name: Advanced Military Science Field Study
prequisites: Students must have had successfully completed MS 131, 132, and MS 133, and three quarters of MS   22 prior to attending this course. Students must meet US Army Officer   contracted Qualification and   Documentation Requirements.

desc: Independent studies with the professor to permit study on a   subject agreed by the student and professor, not covered by   regular course offerings.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of at least two upper-division courses in   military science; open only to ROTC advanced students approved by the department chair.

desc: History and scope of pharmacology as a basic science;   principles of drug action and relationship of pharmacology to   physiology, chemistry, biochemistry emphasized.
name: Basic Pharmacology

desc: Analysis of drug sites and mechanisms of action using isolated tissues, organs, and intact animal preparations.
name: Pharmacology Lab I

desc: Discussion topics relevant to structure-function relationships in proteins including the chemical reactivity of amino acid side chains, posttranslational modifications, and the covalent and noncovalent interactions of multimeric structures. Case studies involve recent advances in structure-function relationships of mechanoproteins.
name: Protein Biochemistry

desc: Introduction to biological properties of microrganisms   historical foundations of the field of microbiology; a study   of major groups of microorganisms, their structure,   physiology, cultivation, and pathogenicity.
instructors: HAYES C S, JENSEN S J
name: General Microbiology
prequisites: MCDB 1A-AL or MCDB 1B-BL or EEMB 2-2L; Chemistry 107A-B and 108, or Chem   130A-B-C, or Chem 109A-B-C.

desc: Discussion of experimental strategies used to purify,   analyze, and manipulate nucleic acids, isolate molecular   clones from complex genomes, physically map genomes, analyze   gene expression, and perform reverse genetics.
name: Experimental Strategies in Molecular Genetics

desc: Nervous system properties ranging from single cells to whole   organisms, using examples from vertebrates/invertebrates   studied in terms of morphology, physiology, behavior.
name: Neurobiology I: Cellular Organization and Biophysics of the   Nervous System
prequisites: MCDB 1A and 1B or equivalent. Completion of both prerequisites with a gradeof C or better.

desc: Seminars on research in progress presented by faculty of the Department of Chemistry and Department of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology.
instructors: MONTELL D J MILLER G L

timeslots.instructor: MONTELL D J MILLER G L

name: Research Seminar in Biochemistry-Molecular Biology

desc: Research presentations by postdoctoral fellows and advanced Ph.D. students of research progress in the department.
name: Research Progress in Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology

desc: Research seminars presented by invited speakers on current research topics.
instructors: MONTELL D J MILLER G L

timeslots.instructor: MONTELL D J MILLER G L

name: Progress in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology

desc: Critical reading and presentation of the literature in modern   neurobiology.
instructors: FEINSTEIN S C CLEGG D O MONTELL C SIMPSON J H

timeslots.instructor: FEINSTEIN S C CLEGG D O MONTELL C SIMPSON J H

name: Literature in Neurobiology

desc: Critical reading and presentation of the current literature   in higher plantmolecular biology, cell biology, and   development.
name: Literature in Plant Molecular Biology

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list. (see individual letter designations)
name: C Elegans Development

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research.
name: Developmental Neurobiology

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be   selected from the following list. (see individual letter   designations)
name: Epithelial Cell Biology and Molecular Renal Pathobiology

desc: This interdisciplinary course will train students to become competent in communicating research project design, implementation, and data analysis to scientific audiences of their peers.  Students will interact directly with the faculty mentor and other members of a laboratory team.
name: Topics at the Interface of the Physical and Biological Sciences

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list. (see individual letter designations)
name: Group Studies

desc: General orientation regarding the University of California and the Santa Barbara campus; various pertinent regulations, officials and their functions,staff and functions; services available to teaching assistants and to students. Prospective teaching assistants are encouraged to take this course during the fall quarter prior to their employment.
name: Teaching Assistant Orientation

desc: Practical experience in teaching within specified areas of biology. Students will have responsibility for one or more laboratory and/or discussion sections. Staff will periodically observe teaching assistants in actual teaching situations. Evaluation forms will be completed by members of the class sections.
name: Practicum in Instruction

desc: Weekly discussion and readings on techniques of teaching including lecturing, leading discussions, writing and grading exams, student- teacher interactions, classroom dynamics, and teaching philosophy.
name: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision

desc: Basic procedures and methods of research in a specific area as determined by consultation between the supervising faculty member and the research assistant. Includes weekly meetings and consultations, and formal evaluations.
name: Research Practium in Biology

desc: In this course we will review Nature Methods articles   entitled “Points ofSignificance” covering the statistical   principles and approaches most commonly required for data   analysis in biological research.
name: Biostatistics

desc: A critical review of research in selected fields of biology.
name: Microbial Pathogenesis

desc: A critical review of research in selected fields of biology. Subject matterfor these seminars will be selected from the following list: (refer to individual letter designations.)
name: Group Studies

desc: A critical review of research in selected fields of biology.
name: Cell Biology

desc: Hours and credit by arrangement with faculty.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual study for M.A. comprehensive examinations and Ph.D. examinations.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: M.A. (thesis) candidate and consent of committee chair.

desc: For writing of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Ph.D. candidate and consent of instructor.

desc: Introduction to biochemistry, cell biology and development, and genetics.
instructors: FEINSTEIN S C CHRISTOFFERSE CLEGG D O NGUYEN A T, GONZALEZ NINO WILTON M B, GONZALEZ NINO WILTON M B ZIRRETTA L, GONZALEZ NINO WILTON M B LANKIEWICZ T, WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO LANKIEWICZ T, WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO ZIRRETTA L

WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO ZIRRETTA L
WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO ZIRRETTA L

name: Introductory Biology I
prequisites: Chemistry 1A-B-C (Chem 1C may be taken concurrently), or a score of 4 or better on either the Advanced Placement Chemistry or Advanced Placement Biology exams.

desc: Designed for transfer students who have completed part of MCDB 1A through transfer work. Topics will be selected by the department, as appropriate, tofulfill the introductory biology requirement at UCSB.
instructors: FEINSTEIN S C CHRISTOFFERSE CLEGG D O NGUYEN A T

timeslots.instructor: FEINSTEIN S C CHRISTOFFERSE CLEGG D O NGUYEN A T

name: Selected Topics from MCDB 1A

desc: Introduction to basic biochemistry, cell biology and   genetics. Topics   include biological macromolecules, molecular basis of   heredity, cell theory,   cellular organelles, cell division cycle, mitosis,   meiosis, fertilization,   early development, Mendelian genetics, and molecular   genetics. Biological   principles will be taught with examples involving the   nervoussystem where   appropriate. Designed for Psychological and Brain   Sciencesmajors.
name: Principles of Molecular and Cellular Biology for Brain   Sciences
prequisites: Chem 1A-B with a minimum grade of C or better

desc: Seminar for first year pre-biology students.  Focus is on   developing   scientific study skills and fostering the confidence and   motivation involved   in higher cognitive learning. Students will engage in   peer mentoring activities, problem-solving exercises and relevant   discussion promoting  academic success.
instructors: WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO KULESH B

timeslots.instructor: WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO KULESH B
WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO KULESH B
WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO KULESH B
WILTON M B GONZALEZ NINO KULESH B

name: Biology Mentoring and Engagement I
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Chemistry 1A or Chemistry 2A.

desc: Opportunity to obtain practical biological-related research   experience byworking under faculty direction as an intern   with local, state, federal, or private agencies. A written   report will be submitted for evaluation.
name: Internship in Biological Sciences
prequisites: Lower-division standing; instructor and departmental approval required.

desc: Special topics in molecular, cellular, and developmental biology. Course content varies. Information may be obtained in department office.
name: Special Topics in Biology

desc: Laboratory experience for advanced lower-division students. Hours and credit by arrangement with any member of the staff.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: From the double helix and genetic code to the latest   breakthroughs. Structure,   function, evolution and manipulation of DNA, RNA.    Replication, expression,   recombination, complementation, and their regulation in   prokaryotes (bacteria,   plasmids, viruses).  Recombinant DNA technology in   medicine, research, agriculture   and industry.
instructors: THROWER D A, SALLAK Y R, YEH T, BAILEY L J, MORALES A E
name: Molecular Genetics I: Prokaryotes
prequisites: MCDB 1A-B, EEMB 2; and, Chemistry 1A-B-C; completion of all listed   prerequisites with a grade of C or better.

desc: Honors section designed to permit an in-depth analysis of   topics relatingto genetics.
name: Molecular Genetics I: Prokaryotes - Honors
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in MCDB 101A; consent of instructor.

desc: Current molecular genetics techniques used to study model organisms. Module1 -   Forward genetics: Mutagenesis and genetic mapping of mutants using single   nucleotide polymorphisms, classical Mendelian inheritance. 2) Reverse genetics:   gene knockdown by RNAi. 3) Genetic analysis of cell signaling. 4) Cellular   reprogramming using transgenic strains. Techniques:  PCR, gel electrophoresis,   Computer based sequence analysis, fluorescence and light microscopy and imaging.    Experiments are based on ongoing research atUCSB. Students get to design their   own experiment in final module.
instructors: JOSHI P M KILLINGSWORTH, KILLINGSWORTH JOSHI P M, JOSHI P M ALCORN M R, ALCORN M R JOSHI P M

name: Molecular Genetics Laboratory

desc: An introduction to the structure and function of cell organelles; membranes, nucleus, mitochondria, chloroplasts, endoplasmic reticulum, golgi apparatus, lysosomes, microbodies, microtubules, cilia, centrioles, and microfilaments.

prequisites: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B; and Chemistry 1A-B-C; and Chemistry 109A-B-C (Chem 109C may be taken concurrently). Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C or better.

name: Pre-Socratics

desc: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Plato.
name: Plato

desc: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of the Hellenistic philosophers.
name: Hellenistic Philosophy

desc: A study at the graduate level of selected writings of Hume.
name: Hume

desc: Graduate seminar in ethics. Specific subject matter is   selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in   the department office before each quarter.
name: Seminar in Ethics

desc: Graduate seminar in epistemology. Specific subject matter is   selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in   the department office before each quarter.
name: Seminar in Epistemology

desc: A teaching practicum involving the study and development of effective teaching techniques in philosophy. Each student will be responsible for andteacha class section in an undergraduate course in philosophy. One meetingper week with instructor and one or more discussion section meetings, and attendance in the lecture of the assigned course are required.
name: Apprentice Teaching in Philosophy

desc: Instructional training. Orientation in professional conduct and responsibilities; observation of student's teaching (in the form of facultyvisits or videotaping) and follow-up conferences; discussion of teaching evaluations and workshops on pedagogical problems.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: A written proposal must be approved by the instructor and department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate student in philosophy; Consent of instructor.

desc: Individual preparation for the doctoral qualifying examination.
name: Individual Study for Master's and/or Ph.D. Examinations for Advancement to Candidacy

desc: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: An introductory course in western philosophy.
instructors: KORMAN D Z, ZAHN S E, STORY D E, KOTLOW Z A, MAINWARING T, SCHAAL-O'CONN
name: Short Introduction to Philosophy

desc: Practical reasoning, argumentation, and the analysis of language as instruments of sound thinking in everyday life.
instructors: LEE JEONGGYU, NORTON P R, JOSEPHSON M A, COMAN D, BRITTON C J
name: Critical Thinking

desc: An examination, at an introductory level, of such ethical issues as: why bemoral, moral relativism, the nature of virtues and vices; and possibly consideration of practical ethical problems such as abortion or war.
instructors: GEE Q P, KYLER B E, COSTIGAN T J, BARNES D B, MOKRISKI D A, ABNEY D P
name: Introduction to Ethics

desc: From Thales to Aristotle.
instructors: TSOUNA V, BAGWELL J N, YARANDI S, AUGUSTIN M J
name: History of Philosophy

desc: Investigates fundamental questions surrounding the nature   of human knowledge and human justification, such as: What   do I know? What am I justifiedin believing? What is it to   know something? What is it to hold a justified belief?
instructors: ZIMMERMAN A Z, LIMA J F, CONKLIN S L
name: Theory of Knowledge

desc: Introduction to philosophical problems and theories concerning the nature of language. Topics typically include the notion of linguistic structure, theories of meaning and reference, names and descriptions, the relations between languages and thought, necessity and analytic truty, and conversationalnorms.
name: Philosophy of Language

desc: A study of some of the following topics: religious language, the existence and nature of god, the problem of evil, religious experience, religion and morality, the rationality of religious belief.
name: Philosophy of Religion

desc: Analysis of fundamental political conceptions; the state, sovereignty, political obligation, natural rights, natural law, etc.
name: Political Philosophy
prequisites: Major in philosophy, law & society, political science, or global and international studies.

desc: Determinism is the doctrine that the laws of nature plus   the past necessitate the future. Is determinism compatible   with the view that we often act freely and are often   morally responsible for what we do?
name: Freedom and Determinism
prequisites: Prerequisite: one prior course in philosophy.

desc: Advanced topics in metaphysics. Specific subject matter is selected by the instructor and descriptions are available in the department before each quarter.
name: Advanced Topics in Metaphysics
prequisites: Two courses from Philosophy 100A or 100B or 100C or 100D or 100E or 100F.

desc: A study of the pre-Socratic philosophers.
name: Pre-Socratics
prequisites: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

desc: The philosophy of Plato.
name: Plato
prequisites: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

desc: An examination of the thought of major Greek philosophers of the Hellenistic period.
name: Hellenistic Philosophy
prequisites: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

desc: The philosophy of David Hume.
name: Hume
prequisites: One prior upper-division course in Philosophy and one additional course in philosophy.

desc: Practical experience and application of analytical skills learned in philosophy as interns with agencies and business. Periodic and final reports required under faculty direction.
name: Internship in Philosophy
prequisites: Upper-division standing in philosophy; consent of department and instructor

desc: A continuous two-quarter research and writing tutorial designed for senior honors majors. The first term will be spent mainly in selecting and researching a topic for the thesis.
name: Senior Honors Thesis
prequisites: Enrollment limited to senior honors philosophy majors; by consent of instructor and departmental approval.

desc: A research and writing tutorial on some topic relevant to issues in ethics and public policy. A written proposal of the project must be approved by the undergraduate adviser and the instructor.
name: Senior Project for Majors with Ethics and Public Policy Emphasis
prequisites: Upper-division standing in philosophy; consent of department.

desc: A written statement of the proposed program of study must be   presented tothe instructor for his or her approval before the   student signs up for the course.
name: Independent Studies in Philosophy
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in   philosophy.

desc: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research.
name: Independent Research Assistant

desc: Students receiving credit will present talks in their field on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.
instructors: LATTO J G TYLER C M KURIS A M

timeslots.instructor: LATTO J G TYLER C M KURIS A M

name: Biology Colloquium

desc: This course is supplementary to MCDB 1A.  It is intended for and open only to CCS students enrolled in MCDB 1A.  Students will attend MCDB 1A lecturesand also meet for more in-depth consideration and analysis of the lecture materials and their broader implications.
name: CCS Introductory Biology I

desc: Serious independent study in biology with consenting faculty member.
instructors: MCCAULEY D J, ARIAS GONZALE, FISHER S K, MA D, GOARD M, OAKLEY T H, SANTORO A E, TYLER C M, T B A
name: Independent Studies

desc: Review of lagrangian mechanics. Variational principles. Hamilton's equations. Canonical transformations. Hamilton Jacobi theory. Action angle variables. Time dependent and canonical perturbation theory. Central forcesand scattering. Small vibrations. Rigid body motion. Poincare maps. Non-integrable systems. Hamiltonian and dissipative chaos.
name: Classical Mechanics

desc: Fundamental principles; Schroedinger equation; angular momentum; perturbation theory; scattering theory, emission, and absorption of radiation; Dirac equation.
instructors: FISHER M P KUNS K A

timeslots.instructor: FISHER M P KUNS K A

name: Quantum Mechanics

desc: Field theoretic methods as applied to (non-relativistic) condensed matter systems. Green's functions and diagrammatic techniques applied to various examples of interacting many body systems, including fermions, bosons, and spins. Relationship of theoretical quantities to physical measurements.
name: The Many Body Problem in Condensed Matter Physics

desc: Introduction to the theory of Lorentz covariant quantized   fields. Global and local conservation laws. Path integral   formulation. Applications to quantum electrodynamics, quantum   chromodynamics, and electroweak interactions. Other possible   topics include grand unification, the renormalizationgroup,   anomolies, current algebra and supersymmetry.
name: Relativistic Quantum Field Theory

desc: Lattice and electron dynamics. Elementary excitations and collective phenomena. Transport properties. Disorder and localization. Long-range order and broken symmetries. Magnetism, superconductivity and liquid crystals. Properties and structures of polymers, membranes, and self-assembling systems.
name: Concepts and Phenomena of Condensed Matter Physics

desc: Gravity as geometry, differential geometry, Einstein's equation, relativistic stars, gravitational collapse, black holes, cosmology, gravitational radiation, and special topics.
name: General Relativity

desc: Stellar dynamics, Jeans equations, potential theory, orbit theory, linear stability analysis, kinetic theory, dynamical friction, applications to starclusters, galaxy morphology and mergers.
name: Galactic Dynamics

desc: Colloquium.
name: Colloquium

desc: Weekly seminar on topics of research currently being pursued in the department of physics.
name: Graduate Seminar

desc: Active participation in an outreach program that presents physics demonstrations and experiments on the road to local schools in order to provide a valuable learning experience for K-12 students.
name: Physics Outreach

desc: Covers development of teaching techniques especially oriented to lower-division physics laboratory instruction. Theoretical aspects covered at beginning of each quarter. Practical techniques discussed including weekly meetingwith class instructor, formal evaluation, and videotaping analysis.
name: Teaching Assistant Seminar

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest. Each staff memberhas a seminar identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.
name: Special Topics

desc: Each staff member has a group studies course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.
name: Group Studies

desc: Individual tutorial. Reading and research in special topics including work done as the basis for the dissertation. Each staff member has a directed reading and research course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: This course is reserved for writing the dissertation. Each staff member hasa research course identified by a number code listed in the schedule ofclasses.
name: Dissertation Preparation

desc: Rotational dynamics and angular momentum; equilibrium and   elasticity; periodic motion including LRC electrical   circuits; gravitation; fluid mechanics; temperature; thermal   expansion; heat and the first law of thermodynamics; heat   conduction; kinetic theory of gases; entropy and the second   law; heat engines.
instructors: BOUWMEESTER D, KAUFMAN J J, POPESCU P E, YOUNGBLOOD BJ
name: Basic Physics
prequisites: Physics 1 with a grade of C- or better; Mathematics 3A-B or AP Math BC examwith a score of 3 or better.

name: Introductory Physics
prequisites: Mathematics 3A or 34A (may be taken concurrently) or AP Math AB Exam score of 3 or better.

desc: Covers the essence of experimental research. Students study   three different systems experimentally, and write short   Physical Review style articlesabout the results.   Students are responsible for deciding what to measure,how to   analyze data, and what conclusions can be reached.
instructors: JAYICH A M SIMMONS E Q, JAYICH A M LIPATOV M

name: Introduction to Experimental Physics
prequisites: Physics CS 31; consent of instructor; creative studies and ccs physics majors   only.

desc: Classical mechanics, kinematics, vectors, Newton's laws, work   and energy,conservation laws. (F)
instructors: BIBILASHVILI, CHEN ZHITAO, ZHAO R, GURUSWAMY S, KUTNER D J, RASMUSSEN A D
name: General Physics
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Mathematics 3A or AP Math AB Exam Score of 3 or   better

desc: Vectors. Kinematics. Newton's laws of motion. Work and energy. Conservativeforces. Momentum. Conservation of momentum. Center of mass motion. Collisions. Systems with variable mass.
name: Newtonian Mechanics
prequisites: Consent of instructor; creative studies majors only.

desc: Electrostatics. DC circuits. Magnetostatics. Vector Potential.
name: Electromagnetism
prequisites: Consent of instructor; creative studies majors only.

desc: Linear Algebra: vector spaces, operators, spectral   decomposition. Topics may include Sturm-Liouville equations,   special functions, group theory.
name: Linear Algebra and Applications
prequisites: Math 6B with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Newtonian mechanics in 3D. Conservation laws. Simple harmonic   oscillator (undamped, damped, driven and nonlinearities).   Central force motion (orbits, Kepler’s laws). Collisions   (elastic, inelastic, scattering, cross sections). Special   relativity.
instructors: KOUTROULAKIS, VAFA F, TROTT T J
name: Intermediate Mechanics
prequisites: Physics 1, 2 and 3 or Physics 20, 21 and 22; Mathematics 6B (may be taken  concurrently).

desc: Electrostatics, Laplace's equation, method of images,   separation of variables, multipole expansion, magnetostatics,   electric and magnetic fields in matter.
instructors: JAYICH ANIA, FU Z, ZHAO R
name: Electromagnetism
prequisites: Physics 5 or 25 with a minimum grade of C-; Mathematics 6B with minimum grade   of C-.

desc: Inadequacies of classical physics and quantum mechanical   resolutions. Thepostulates of quantum mechanics.   Schroedinger's equation, measurements, operators, and   observables. Angular momentum and spin, the exclusion   principle, perturbation theory, and scattering theory.   Applications to atomic, molecular, and nuclear physics.
instructors: CRAIG N J, STREICHER A A, KOREN S C
name: Quantum Mechanics
prequisites: Physics 5 or 25 with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Thermodynamics: three laws of thermodynamics, phase diagrams,   entropy, equipartion of energy, specific heat, reversible and   irreversible processes, pressure, viscosity, thermal   conductivity, diffusion.
name: Thermal and Statistical Physics
prequisites: Physics 5 or 25 with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Why do the waves hit the beach every five seconds? This course teaches students the relevant fluid dynamics and allows them to apply it to natural phenomena of California: seismic waves, tsunamis, maximum tree heights, fluid flow around fish.
name: Physics of California Waves, Weather, Quakes and Fires

desc: Classification of solids; crystal symmetry, therma electric and magnetic properties; metals, semiconductors, and the band theory of electronic states;magnetic resonance; superconductivity; imperfections. Emphasis willbe placed on both fundamental and applied aspects.
name: Condensed Matter Physics
prequisites: Physics 115A with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Passive circuits, diodes, transistors, field effect   transistors, operational amplifiers, feedback and control.   Design, building and testing of analog circuits.
instructors: STUART D D, SWIMMER N J STUART D D, DANESHI K STUART D D, ZAMANI S STUART D D, SHEPLOCK J T BALAKRISHNAN STUART D D, O'HARA J D STUART D D, BALAKRISHNAN SHEPLOCK J T STUART D D, ZHANG ZHIRAN STUART D D

prequisites: Physics 25L and Math 3B with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Selected experiments in contemporary physics, e.g.,   holography, laser lightscattering zeeman effect, x-rays,   superconductivity, magnetic resonance, Mossbauer effect.

prequisites: Physics 25L or Physics 13AH or Physics CS 15A. Physics 127AL with a minimumgrade of C-; and Physics 115A (may be taken concurrently).

Studies of   variable stars, galaxy morphology, supernova, etc.

prequisites: Physics 5 or 25; and consent of instructor.

desc: Offers qualified undergraduates the opportunity to work in research laboratories in biophysics.
name: Experimental Research in Biophysics

desc: Offers qualified undergraduates the opportunity to work in experimental research in astrophysics. Each staff member has his/her own course identified by a number listed in the schedule of classes.
name: Experimental Research in Astrophysics
prequisites: Physics 5 or 25; and consent of instructor.

desc: Active participation in at least 4 Circus events per   quarter but preferably all events. Improve an existing   Circus activity or create a new Circusactivity for   evaluation by Physics Circus faculty and participants.
name: Physics Outreach
prequisites: Consent of instructor. Phys 6A-6C OR Phys 1-4 OR Phys 20-24.

desc: Provides experience in communicating science and technology to nonspecialists. The major components of the course are field work in mentoring, a biweekly seminar, presentations to precollege students and to adult nonscientists, and end-of-term research papers.
name: Science for the Public

desc: Each staff member has own directed reading course identified by a number code listed in the schedule of classes.
name: Directed Reading
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in physics.

desc: Directed individual study open to qualified seniors in the department. Eachstaff member has own independent studies course identified by a number codelisted in the schedule of classes.
name: Research in Physics
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in physics.

desc: Undergraduate research for qualified seniors to gain valuable experience inresearch methodology.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in physics.

desc: Covers the essence of experimental research. Students study   three different systems experimentally, and write short   Physical Review style articlesabout the results.   Students are responsible for deciding what to measure,how to   analyze data, and what conclusions can be reached.
name: Introduction to Experimental Physics
prequisites: Physics CS 31; consent of instructor; creative studies and ccs physics majors   only.

desc: Vectors. Kinematics. Newton's laws of motion. Work and energy. Conservativeforces. Momentum. Conservation of momentum. Center of mass motion. Collisions. Systems with variable mass.
name: Newtonian Mechanics
prequisites: Consent of instructor; creative studies majors only.

desc: Electrostatics. DC circuits. Magnetostatics. Vector Potential.
name: Electromagnetism
prequisites: Consent of instructor; creative studies majors only.

desc: An introduction to quantitative political methodology,   ranging from probability theory to the basic multivariate   linear regression model. Emphasisis placed on the use of   statistical software to implement the statisticalmodels   covered.
name: Political Research Methods I

desc: A general survey of theories of comparative politics with   some attention toconcrete applications and to comparative   trends in other social sciences and history.
name: Comparative Political Systems

desc: The development of political attitudes and behavior throughout the entire life cycle. Major foci of attention include the study of agents of politicalsocialization, the content of socialization, variations within and across political systems, and the impact of generational and historicaleffects.
name: Seminar in Political Socialization

desc: The seminar will probe a variety of issues, theoretical and historical (plus quite a few contemporary ones), that touch on war, power, and security studies.
name: War, Diplomacy and International Security

desc: Explores the global and comparative political economy of   the environment.
name: Comparative and International Environmental Politics

desc: Designed to help teaching assistants learn effective teaching methods and techniques under faculty supervision. assignments normally include conducting discussion sections, grading examinations under the supervision of appropriate faculty members and discussion of relevant pedagogical problems.
name: Practicum for Teaching Assistants

desc: Designed to help graduate students prepare for future assignments as teaching assistants. Course work normally includes dis- cussions with faculty members and past or current teaching assistants, attendance at demonstration exercises, analysis of teacher performance with the use of audio-visual aids, etc.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Designed to help beginning teaching associates improve and refine their teaching methods, techniques and materials through discussions with appropriate members of the regular faculty. The format of the course may vary according to the specific needs of the teaching associates.
name: Practicum for Teaching Associates

desc: Designed for students who are at the early to intermediate   stages of their dissertation plans. Progress reports that   will lead to an eventual prospectus are emphasized.
name: Directed Research

desc: This is a supervised internship designed to provide graduate students with a means to pursue research on the policymaking process through participation in the formulation and/or implementation of policy in the field.
name: Supervised Internship in Public Policy

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics

desc: Current topics in the field of political science.
name: Group Studies

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the instructor andthe department graduate advisor and filed with the department graduate offi

desc: Individual study for Master's comprehensive examinations and Ph.D. examinations.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examination and Ph.D Examinations

desc: Master's thesis research and preparation.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: An introduction to central texts and problems of political philosophy with an emphasis on such concepts as liberty, equality, authority, justice, and obligation.
instructors: ZAMORA M N, OSAILAN K Z, STEIN E A
name: Introduction to Political Philosophy

desc: Introduction to the workings of various political systems   with an emphasis on governmental institutions and political   processes. Comparison of political systems using some of   the basic concepts of political analysis.
instructors: BRUHN K, YE L, ROCHAT M J, TSOULOUFAS G
name: Introduction to Comparative Politics

desc: An introduction to the basic concepts, theories, and   problems of international relations; balance of power,   deterrence, the states system, imperialism, realism,   idealism, levels of explanation, war and peace.
instructors: NARANG N, ZHOU Q, JENKINS M D, JOHNSON A Y
name: Introduction to International Relations

desc: An introduction to the design and evaluation of political research, from   formulating clear questions and gathering appropriate data, to the use of simple   statistical techniques for analyzing data and presenting evidence.
instructors: STOKES L C, WANG R, LEPISSIER A M
name: Introduction to Research in Political Science

desc: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: Lectures in special areas of interest in political science. Specific coursetitles to be announced by the department each quarter offered.
name: Special Topics in Political Science

desc: Survey of the electoral systems in use throughout the world; their relationships with other   political institutions, such as the system of government; and their effects upon political   competition, democratic representationand policy outcomes.
name: The Political Consequences of Electoral Laws

desc: An examination of theories concerning the actions,   interactions, and relationships among nation-states.
instructors: STRATHMAN B A, FONTAINE S A, DOSHI V B, SIRAPRAPASIRI
name: International Politics

desc: The nature and function of international organization, including a study ofthe United Nations and the European community.
name: International Organization

desc: Examines how states use diplomacy, strategic coercion, and   military forceto achieve political objectives.
instructors: STRATHMAN B A, ROHRER K A
name: International Security

desc: An exploration of the difference between economic growth and economic   development. Why do some countries develop faster than others? The   course will reflect on the political factors that impact a state's   economic development, including order and violence, historical and   contemporary institutions, collective action, culture, ethnic   diversity, rural-urban linkages,international trade and foreign aid.
name: Politics of Economic Development

desc: The nature and function of organized interest groups and   their impact upon public opinion and government.
instructors: HAN H C, SRIRAM S, GOMEZ D M
name: Political Interest Groups

desc: Analysis of the institution of the presidency, its functions,   formal and informal relationships, and its limitations within the   American politicalsystem. Emphasis on the dynamics of the   presidency, including presidential personality, conceptions of   role, impact of public opinion, and responses to changes in the   environment.
instructors: WOOLLEY J T, NENADOVIC S M
name: The American Presidency
prequisites: Political Science 15 or 104 or 104A or Sociology 3 or Psychology 5 or   Communications 88 AND Political Science 12.

desc: Survey of the historical and contemporary political experiences of Asian Americans and their pursuits for immigration, equality, citizenship, political identity, racial justice, cross-racial/ethnic coalition building and incorporation into the U. S. political system.
name: Asian American Politics
prequisites: Political Science 12 or Asian American Studies 1 or Asian American Studies 2.

desc: Problems of politics and administration in urban and metropolitan areas.
name: Urban Government and Politics

desc: Course is structured around the major issues in environmental politics, forexample:   global warming, nuclear waste, deforestation, and chemical pollution. The roles of   economics, technology and social organization are eachconsidered as explanatory   variables for understanding environmental problems.
instructors: MILDENBERGER, HENDERSON G L, HUNNICUTT P L
name: Comparative Environmental Politics

desc: Development of political ideas from the sixteenth century to the nineteenthcentury.
name: Modern Political Theory

desc: A reconstruction of the contending theories of political order with which western intellectuals, from the nineteenth to the present century, have confronted an era of world historical changes.
name: Recent and Contemporary Political Theory

desc: Directed research on the political process through participant observation and   relevant reading. Individually assigned, instructed, and supervised fieldwork.   Students will examine first hand behavior in leading political roles in   American politics.
name: Field Research in Political Science

desc: Senior seminar in political science.
name: Senior Seminar in Political Science.

desc: Political Science 197A-B-C is a three quarter sequence   course with the final grade issued upon completion of 197C.   Honors students, in three-quarter sequence of seminars,   write original theses under close faculty supervision.
name: Honors Thesis Seminar in Political Science

desc: Independent studies in political science.
name: Independent Studies in Political Science
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two prior upper-division courses in political science; major in political science; consent of department.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Political Science
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in   politicascience; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Primarily intended to train students in techniques, background materials and selection of topics.
name: Research Seminar in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division Portuguese courses at UCSB. Participation in occasional workshops related to the field of teaching willbe required.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division Portuguese courses at UCSB. Participation in occasional workshops related to the field of teaching willbe required.
name: Teaching Associate Practicum

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by student's program adviser and by the department chair. The number of units which a student may take in this series depends on the nature of the program and the consent of the adviser or the departmental graduate committee.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual study for Master's comprehensive or Ph.D. examinations. Individual study under instructor who is member of the student's program committee.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive or Ph.D. Examinations

desc: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation. Research and writing of the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Study of the finer points of Portuguese grammar and syntax. Equal stress isplaced on written and oral practice of the language. The work in class willconsist of careful study of essays and articles.
name: Advanced Grammar and Composition

desc: Portuguese literature from its origins to the sixteeth century.
name: Survey of Portuguese Literature

desc: The student engages in research leading to a paper of considerable depth and complexity on a topic dealing with the literature and/or languageof Portugal, Brazil, or Portuguese-speaking Africa.
name: Senior Honors Independent Research
prequisites: Admission to the Portuguese senior honors program.

desc: Independent studies in selected subjects not covered by course offerings.
name: Independent Studies in Portuguese
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Portuguese; consent of department.

desc: Intended to provide fundamental understanding of neuroscience and behavior for graduate students at the beginning of their studies. Provides a broad overview of brain function with focus on the molecular, cellular, system, and behavioral level of analysis in order to instill a comprehensive appreciation of the biological mechanisms important to behavior.
name: Basic Concepts in Behavioral Neuroscience

desc: Experimental design and statistical analysis in psy- chological research. Includes basic probability, sampling and distribution theory, hypothesis testing, and estimation.
name: Design and Measurement

desc: Analysis of psychophysical relations in sensory processes with stress on detection, scaling, discrimination, spatial and temporal resolution, and the interaction of cue systems in perceptual behavior.
name: Perception

desc: Introduces students to the theoretical and practical issues involved in conducting functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) experiments. Content includes basic MR physics, physiology of the BOLD signal, experimental design, image processing, statistical analysis, and brain mapping.
name: Neuroimaging

desc: An in-depth analysis of advanced topics in human cognition. The course willinclude discussion of the cognitive processes involved in areas such as human thinking, problem solving, memory, and learning.
name: Cognition

desc: Course addresses classic and contemporary theory and research on the psychology of stigma. Emphasis is on experience of members of stigmatized groups.Issues covered will include affective, cognitive, motivational and social interaction consequences of stigma.
name: Social Stigma

desc: Introduction to basic concepts in evolutionary psychology; how natural selection works, ancestral environments, how to use theories of adaptive problems to discover new cognitive mechanisms, standards of evidence for adaptations, relation of evolved psychology to culture.
name: Evolutionary Psychology

desc: Seminar designed to prepare psychology graduate students for various roles related to the teaching of undergraduate psychology courses. Topics may include leading discussions, preparing and grading exams, conferencing, evaluating writing, ethical issues, lecturing effectively, and using audio-visualaids.
instructors: MACKIE D M BROMBERG C W

timeslots.instructor: MACKIE D M BROMBERG C W

name: Seminar On Teaching Of Psychology

desc: Research seminar for special interest groups in psychology.   Each special interest group has its own letter designation   available in department office.
instructors: MAYER R E, T B A
name: Special Interest Group Research Seminar

desc: A discussion of practical issues related to securing and   maintaining an academic position within a university/college   environment. Topics may include writing grants, preparing a   vitae, the job interview, tenure, conference presentations,   lecture preparation and presentation.
name: Professional Skills for Academic Psychologists

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest. Each faculty member has their own letter designation available in department office.
name: Special Topics

desc: Independent readings for M.A. The purpose of this course is to provide supervised readings on selected topics.
name: Readings For M.A.

desc: The purpose of this course is to providesupervised experience in experimental design and laboratory procedures on selected topics, includingthe formulation of experimental problems, discussion of relevant literatureand the analysis and interpretation of experimental results.
name: Directed Reading And Research.

desc: Research and preparation for the master's thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research And Preparation

desc: Empirical and theoretical investigations of special problems in psychology in relation to dissertation research.
name: Dissertation Research And Preparation

desc: An introduction to the subject matter and methods of psychology. Topics mayinclude development, perception, memory, learning, cognition, affect, motivation, social behavior, personality, psychopathology and the physiological basis of behavior.
instructors: WALTER K V, HE C, PURPURA M D, IHM E D
name: Introduction to Psychology
prequisites: Students are required to be subjects in low-risk psychological experiments or completion of a short paper.

desc: An introduction to the biological basis of psychology. Topics may include the anatomy and functioning of the nervous system, and the neural basis of development, perception, learning, memory, cognition, affect, motivation, social behavior, personality and psychopathology.
name: The Biological Basis of Psychology

desc: Introduction to the methodology and practice of   scientific psychology so that students can critically   evaluate research claims. Examines the multiple steps of   the research process, including developing a   testable hypothesis, operationalizing the hypothesis into   independent and dependent variables, adopting an   appropriate methodology for the research question (e.g.,   survey, experiment, observation), and analyzing   and interpreting data, as well as considering the ethical   context of research.
name: Research Methods in Psychology
prequisites: Psychology 1 with a minimum grade of C-; Psychology 5 or PSTAT 5A with a   minimum grade of C-; Math 3A or 34A with a minimum grade of C-; Chem 1A-B  or 2A-B; Students are required to be subjects in low-risk psychological   experiments or completion of a short paper.

desc: Introduction to key statistical concepts and their appropriate application so that students understand how to use statistics. Examines foundational statistical concepts of descriptive statistics, probability, and sampling distributions and introduces some of the major concepts and inferential statistical techniques used in psychological research to test hypotheses.
name: Statistical Methods in Psychology
prequisites: Psychology 10A with a minimum grade of C-; Students are required to be subjects in low-risk psychological experiments or completion of a short paper.

desc: Seminar for specially selected students. Advanced reading, writing, and discussion.
name: First-Level Honors Seminar

desc: Readings in Psychology under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Students wishing to enroll must prepare a short plan of study.
name: Readings in Psychology

desc: Advanced independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in thedepartment, including writing a research report or review.
name: Independent Research in Psychology
prequisites: Consent of department and instructor; completion of at least one quarter ofPsychology 99P.

desc: Introduction to concepts, theory, and research within   social psychology. Topics may include: person perception,   attitude formation and change, interpersonal interactions,   persuasion and influence, group processes, prejudice, and   social values.
name: Introduction to Social Psychology

desc: Introduction to concepts, theory, and research within   developmental psychology. Topics may include: a focus on   child development, and an examination of research and   theory in major areas of child psychology.
instructors: LA JOY J R GRILLOT R L

timeslots.instructor: LA JOY J R GRILLOT R L

name: Introduction to Developmental Psychology

desc: Introduction to concepts, theory, and research within   cognitive psychology. Topics may include: pattern   recognition, attention, memory, language, reasoning and   problem solving.
instructors: SCHOOLER J W ORTOSKY L E

timeslots.instructor: SCHOOLER J W ORTOSKY L E

name: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology

desc: Overview of visual perception. Course covers a wide range of phenomena fromthe detection of simple stimuli to the identification of objects and events. Human performance, psychological theories, and biology are considered.
name: Perception: Vision
prequisites: Psychology 1, 5, and 7; open to psychology, biopsychology and interdisciplinary studies majors only.

desc: An examination of major concepts in behavioral neuroscience. Topics may include: molecular bases of neuron function, neurotransmitter systems, sensoryand motor systems, neural bases of learning, memory, and motivated behavior.
name: Fundamentals of Behavioral Neuroscience
prequisites: PSY 3 or PSY 106; open to Psychological & Brain Sciences, Biopsychology andInterdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: Methods, techniques and typical experimental research in   social psychology.
name: Laboratory in Social Behavior
prequisites: Psychology 102. Open to psychology, biopsychology, psychological & brain   sciences and interdisciplinary majors only.

desc: An overview of theory and research in memory. Topics may   include: how knowledge is represented internally, cognitive   processes involved in remembering, and an examination of   different memory systems.
instructors: KLEIN S B DARUGAR E R

timeslots.instructor: KLEIN S B DARUGAR E R

name: Memory
prequisites: Open to Psychological & Brain Sciences, Biopsychology, and   Interdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: A combined laboratory/lecture course that emphasizes the   theoretical issues, experimental methods, and data   analysis techniques relevant to the study of psychology.    The lab exposes students to sophisticated aspects of experimentation in psychology including the bases for   theoretical inference, experimental designs, development   of procedures and analyses.
instructors: WOODS V E, MILNER A E, BAINBRIDGE K, BROMBERG C W
name: Laboratory in Advanced Research Methods
prequisites: PSY 102, 105, 106, or 108; open to Psychological & Brain Sciences,   Biopsychology, and Interdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: An overview of theory and research in visual neuroscience.   Topics may include: a focus on mammalian vision considering   evidence from behavioral and biological approaches.
name: Visual Neuroscience
prequisites: PSY 111; open to Psychological & Brain Sciences, Biopsychology, and   Interdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: An overview of theory and research on the evolution and   psychology of human social relationships. This class takes an interdisciplinary approach to human relationships. Topics may include: mate choice, relationship regulation, kinship, parent-offspring conflict, cooperation, friendship, coalitions, and status hierarchies.
name: The Evolution of Human Relationships
prequisites: Open to Psychological & Brain Sciences, Biopsychology, and   Interdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: An overview of theory and research in evolution and cognition. Explores ways in which the human mind can be seen as a collection of devices designed by evolution to solve adaptive problems faced by our hunter-gatherer ancestors.   Topics may include: cooperation, mating, sibling jealousy, coalitional aggression.
name: Evolution and Cognition
prequisites: Open to Psychological & Brain Sciences, Biopsychology, and Interdisciplinary Studies majors only.

desc: Investigates empirical approaches to the psychology of a fulfilling and flourishing life.  Topics include research on positive emotions, happiness, empathy, friendship, goal setting, love, achievement, morality, creativity, mindfulness, spirituality and humor.
instructors: THAYER B S SMALL P A

timeslots.instructor: THAYER B S SMALL P A

name: Positive Psychology
prequisites: PSY 1, 5, and 7; open to psychology, biopsychology, and interdisciplinary studies majors only.

desc: Lectures in special areas of interest in contemporary psychology. Consult the department office regarding course topics.
name: Special Topics in Psychology
prequisites: psychology 1, 5, 7, and consent of instructor. course may be repeated once

desc: A combined laboratory/lecture course examining the   organization and connectivity of the mammalian nervous   system. Topics covered will include neurohistological   techniques; neurology and neuropsychology; comparative   neuroanatomy.
name: Laboratory in Neuroanatomy
prequisites: Psychology 111 or MCDB 151 (either may be taken concurrently); open to   full psychology, biopsychology, psychological & brain sciences, and   interdisciplinary studies majors only.

desc: Independent study under supervision of faculty member, involving either design and execution of independent research project or scholarly analysis andcritique of theoretical and research literature pertaining to substantial issues. Honors thesis qualifies student for distinction in major upon graduation.
name: Honors Research in Psychology
prequisites: Psychology 196; at least two quarters of psychology 99P, 99, 199P, or 199; consent of department.

desc: Readings in psychology under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Students wishing to enroll should prepare a short plan of study.
name: Readings in Psychology
prequisites: Open to psychology, biopsychology and interdisciplinary studies majors only; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-divison courses in psychology; consent of department.

desc: Advanced independent research under the guidance of a   faculty member in the department, including writing a   research report or review.
name: Independent Research in Psychology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-divison courses in   psychology; consent of department; one quarter of Psychology 99P or 199P.

desc: Critical analysis of key themes and figures in anthropology and sociology of religion, with attention to their role in the emergence and current practice of religious studies. Includes the works of such figures as Tylor, Frazer, Mauss, Levi-Stauss, Douglas, Turner, Geertz, Durkheim, Weber, and Berger.
name: Proseminar in History and Theory of Religion

desc: Critical analysis of key themes and figures in contemporary critical theoryand cultural studies, with attention to their role in the current practice of religious studies. Includes the works of such figures as Benjamin, Foucault, Bourdieu, Derrida, Lacan, Kristeva, Butler, and Taussig.
name: Proseminar in the History and Theory of Religion

desc: Explores ways of thinking about the visual dimension of religious practice in South Asia. A central theme is the effect of modern media technologies on darshan, or visual worship. Accordingly, many of the readings foreground contemporary Hinduism, but Islam and other traditions are represented. Questions of the gaze, the body, substance transfer, legibility, affect, idolatry, surveillance, and the like keep us busy across a range of theoretical and methodological approaches. The syllabus includes several films.
name: Visuality in Traditions of South Asia

desc: An introduction to the social scientific study of religion through the lensof the ethnographic method. Attends both to practical questions concerning the performance of qualitative research and to ethnography as a literary genre that captures the complexities of lived experience. Reading assignmentsmay be divided into three categories: historical investigations of ethnographic theory and fieldwork praxis; close examinations of discrete religious sites; and interdisciplinary meditations on such themes as interpretation, ethics, authority, and cultural translation.
name: Religion and Ethnography: Theory, Praxis, Experience

desc: Explores the legacy of Neoplatonic thought in the Greco-  Roman world on Jewish,   Christian, and Muslim thinkers in the middle ages.   Thinkers to bestudied   include Pseudo-Dionysius, Eriugena, Eckhart, Al-Kindi,   Avicenna, Ibn Arabi,   Isaac Israeli, Solomon ibn Gabirol, and Maimonides.   Particular focus will be   given to the impact of Neoplatonic negative theology on   the theistic emphasis   on these three religious traditions.
name: Negative Theology and Jewish, Christian, and Muslim   Neoplatonism

desc: Historical and critical examination of selected figures, categories, and phenomena pertaining to the diversity of Native American religious traditions.
name: Seminar in Native American Religious Traditions

desc: Historical, philosophical, methodological, and/or   bibliographical analysis of different aspects of Buddhism or   of selected areas in the study of Buddhism.
name: Seminar in Buddhist Studies

desc: Selected readings from important Taoist texts.  Depending on   the year, primary sources will be read in original Chinese or   in translation.
name: Readings in Taoism

desc: Examination of theories and case studies at the intersection of religion and race/ethnicity in the United States.
name: Seminar in Race and Religion

desc: Addressing of Muslim juristic and political debates about the intersectionsand dialectics of government and shari'a.
name: Islamic Political Philosophy

desc: Will explore the reformist movement that has arisen   within and outside the   Islamic Republic, which attempts to reconcile social and   economic modernity   with newer and more tolerant interpretations of Shi'i   Islam. Readings will   be in English.
name: Reformist Shi'ism Today

desc: Seminar in special areas of interest in religious studies. Specific course titles to be announced by the department each quarter offered. Course content will vary.
name: Special Topics

desc: Required orientation and on-the-job_instructors of teaching assistants and associates through consultations with_instructors, evaluation of their teaching through videotapes or other means of observation, follow-up consultations, teaching evaluation.
name: T.A. and Associate Training Program.

desc: Special readings selected under guidance of individual instructor to help the student make up particular gaps in his/her intellectual background thatare pertinent to his/her graduate program.
name: Directed Reading

desc: A series of discussions involving panels, debates, special speakers, etc., at which the presence of all enrolled graduate and selected faculty is required.
name: Colloquium

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics

desc: Research and preparation of dissertation.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual study for Master's or Ph.D. examinations for advancement to candidacy.
name: Individual Study for Master's or Ph.D. Examination for Advancement to Candidacy.

desc: For research underlying the project; writing the project.
name: Master's Project Research and Preparation

desc: Terminal preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: Covers Western encounters with Muslims from Islam's spread in the Near Eastand Europe until the mid-nineteenth century, including the depiction of theProphet Muhammad in Western literature, positive and negative Muslim/European interactions, and their rivalry.
instructors: AHMAD A A, CANTU K E
name: Islam and the West from 700-1850

desc: Introduction to the basic texts, institutions, and practices of western religious traditions: Judiasm, Christianity, and Islam.
name: Introduction to Judaism, Christianity, and Islam

desc: Introductory modern standard Arabic: pronunciation, script,   conversation,and oral comprehension. Weekly sections involve   cultural materials such as elementary calligraphy, Middle   Eastern cooking, Arabic television shows, films, singing, and   folk dance.
name: Elementary Arabic I

desc: Intermediate Arabic: complex grammar, and vocabulary, readings in classicaland modern Arabic literature, including short stories, newspaper articles, and poetry. Extensive use of audio-visual materials including news broadcasts, television shows, and films. weekly conversation section.
name: Intermediate Arabic IV

desc: The beginning course in Hindi. Survey of grammar. Graded exercises and readings drawn from Hindi literature, leading to mastery of grammatical structures and essential vocabulary and achievement of basic reading and writing competence.
name: Elementary Hindi I

desc: Intermediate Hindi. Selected readings in Hindi fiction and nonfiction, withexercises in grammar, composition, and conversation.
name: Intermediate Hindi IV
