desc: Surveys twenty world religious traditions in their approaches to the problem of death, care for the dead, and death-related doctrines and practices within their broader cultural, historical, and social contexts from a cross-cultural perspective.
instructors: WHITE D G, CHAVEZ W S, RUNKEVICH Y P, KING S L, BUENDIA DE LL, DICKSTEIN J H, GONZALEZ J H, ATUR R, WHITESIDES K, WU Y
name: Religious Approaches to Death

desc: This course is designed as an introduction to the contribution that Native American religions make to the general study of religion. Metaphysical and philosophical aspects of North American native culture. Major concepts of belief systems, religion, and medicine. Theories of balance, harmony, knowledge, power, ritual, and ceremony.
instructors: TALAMANTEZ I, MONDRAGON D M, CLAVERIA A J
name: Introduction to Native American Religious Studies

desc: Introduction to the orthography, phonology, grammar, and lexicon of Tiberian Biblical Hebrew as found in most printed Bibles. Concludes with selected Pentateuchal readings where the student applies grammatical knowledge to texts.
name: Introduction to Biblical Hebrew I

desc: An introduction to the history and texts of the major lineages of Ch`an Buddhism in China and Zen Buddhism in Japan.
name: Zen Buddhism

desc: Survey of the major trends of Jewish mysticism from late   antiquity through early modernity. Topics include   celestial ascent and the angelic transformation of the   mystic; letter mysticism and magical techniques; the   divine and mystical union; gender and the anthropomorphic   representation ofGod; secrecy and mystical fellowship;    ascetic eroticism and the spiritual ideal of worship.
instructors: WOLFSON E R, WRIGHT L S
name: Introduction to Jewish Mysticism

desc: Survey of Tibetan religions focusing on Tibetan Buddhism (from its origns to the present) but also touching on the Tibetan indigenous religion, Bon and on Tibetan Islam. Special attention is paid to the four major schools of Tibetan Buddhism, their history, doctrines, and meditation practices.
instructors: CABEZON J I, TAKKINEN J H, ELLERTON D M, IUM M H
name: The Religions of Tibet

desc: A survey of religion's influence on American politics, studying those seeking greater alignment between religious values and public policy. An examination of the relationship between religion and political mobilization, interest group politics, public opinions, race and ethnicity, foreign policy, and elections.
instructors: BLANKHOLM J L, FORMAN J D, LANAHAN-KALIS
name: Introduction to Religion and Politics

desc: Introduction to Persian pronunciation, script, and basic grammar, and vocabulary. Included lessons in reading, writing, conversation, and oral comprehension. Sections involve audio-visual materials and a general introduction to the literature and cultures of Persian-speaking Iran, Tajikistan, and Afghanistan.
name: Persian I

desc: Continuation of Persian III.
name: Intermediate Persian IV

desc: Continuation of Persian IV.
name: Intermediate Persian V

desc: This intensive course is for students with some background- mostly in listening and speaking skills of Persian language. This course is an introduction to Persian sound system, script, basic grammar, reading, and writing. Also includes developing vocabulary, formal vs. informal speaking, and learning about the diverse culture of Persian-speaking Iran, Tajikistan, and Afghanistan.
name: Intensive Persian I

desc: Examines female deities and apparitions of the Virgin Mary historically depicted as dark-skinned, placing particular emphasis on the role color has played in defining their attributes, relationships with religious practitioners, and ethnic or racial identities. Among the goddesses to be discussed are the Egyptian Isis, Hindu Kali, Taiwanese Mazu, Tibetan Tara, Haitian Ezili Dantor, and Yoruba Yemonja. The Black Madonnas include the Catalan Montserrat, Polish Czestochowa, and Mexican Guadalupe.
name: Dark Goddesses and Black Madonnas

desc: Introduction to Turkish pronunciation, script, basic grammar, and vocabulary, including lessons in reading, writing, conversation, and oral comprehension. Course involves audio-visual materials and a general introduction to the literature and cultures of Turkey.
name: Introduction to Turkish Language I

desc: Continuation of Turkish III
name: Intermediate Turkish Language IV

desc: A survey of the main authors, themes, and styles of the   Japanese religious and philosophical traditions through   readings from and analysis of somesignificant and   influential original texts in English translation.
name: Introduction to Japanese Religion: Texts, Concepts, and   Representations

desc: The decline of classical antiquity; the emergence of medieval Christendom; religion and culture of the Middle Ages (eleventh-thirteenth centuries); subsequent development of the Renaissance and Reformation.
instructors: CARON L R, SNEDIKER T B, MORALES C T
name: Religion and Western Civilization II: Medieval

desc: A discussion section led by the instructor, provided for   students in the honors program. Students receive one unit   for the honors seminar (80BH) in addition to four units for   Religious Studies 80B.
name: Religion and Western Civilization II: Honors
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Religious Studies 80B; consent of instructor

desc: Explores the vibrant culture of the modern Arab World, including poetry, novels,   theater, television,   film, art, architecture, food, folklore, music, humor, reality TV, social media,   and the blogosphere, in   short, everything that makes Arabs Arab.
instructors: REYNOLDS D F, MURPHY C L
name: Modern Arab Culture

desc: This course surveys Islamic civilization with an emphasis on its early and formative periods. The first part addresses geographical, historical, religious, and institutional contexts and expressions, and the second part explores intellectual, scientific, philosophical, and spiritual contributions.
instructors: EL OMARI R M, SIBLEY C M
name: Introduction to Islamic Civilization

desc: Lectures in special areas of interest in religious studies. Specific coursetitles to be announced by the department each quarter offered.
name: Topics in Religious Studies

desc: These internships pair students with philanthropic and non-profit organizations, nationally and globally. Students work digitally or on site with the organization. They will learn about practical implications of a degree in Religious Studies and in the Humanities more generally. They will also have the opportunity to put to use their knowledge of foreign languages and technology. While helping to make the world a better place, students will gain valuable experience that can be applied to their chosen career after graduation.
name: Internship

desc: An examination of religious themes and forms as they appear in significant works of modern film. The nature of man, the problem of suffering, the quest for meaning are among the topics considered.
name: Religion and Film

desc: Introduction to the varieties of literature, traditions, and institutions of ancient Israel through the prophetic period.
name: Literature and Religion of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament

desc: Addresses major intellectual and cultural developments relating to the disintegration of medieval Christianity and the birth of modern Europe. Attention given to both contemporary historical studies and selected primary sources in theology, philosophy, literature, and the arts.
name: Christian Thought and Cultures of the Reformation

desc: Elements of traditional Judaism in biblical and rabbinic times.
name: Judaism

desc: Close readings of the different genres of the classical texts   of Tibetan Buddhism in the original Tibetan: philosophy,   history, autobiography, religious poetry, ritual, etc. Also   provides a hands-on introduction to available digital tools.
name: Readings in Tibetan Buddhist Texts

desc: Various courses on the topic of Catholic Studies, including courses taught by the Tipton Visiting Professor in Catholic Studies.
name: Topics in Catholic Studies

desc: Advanced study of grammar and vocabulary; readings in the major genres of classical and modern Arabic literature, including Qur'an, medieval poetry and prose, modern short story and novels, etc.
name: Advanced Arabic

desc: A history of Islamic philosophy with a focus on its early and classical phases. Attention will be given to the universalist aspirations and articulations of Islamic philosophy as well as to its interaction with Islamic doctrines and with theologies.
name: History of Islamic Philosophy

desc: This seminar is part of the Capps Center internship program   in public service and social ethics. It addresses issues of   ethics and the role of governmental and non-governmental   organizations in contemporary society. Students will intern   in local non-profit organizations in Winter and Spring quarters.
name: Seminar in Social Ethics
prequisites: Instructor approval required prior to enrolling.

desc: Environmental Ethics probes questions of duty and policy regarding human impact on the natural world. Topics such as climate change, sustainable economics, population explosion, and the standing of non-human animals are examined from various perspectives.
name: Environmental Ethics

desc: An introduction to the phonology, morphology, and syntax of classical Sanskrit.
name: Elementary Sanskrit

desc: Readings in Philosophical literature in Sanskrit.
name: Religious Literature in Sanskrit: Philosophical Literature

desc: An introduction to the classical religious traditions of India, with particular attention to three major areas of Indian religion and culture: the ritual, moral and social order; philosophical perspectives and traditions; andtraditions of mythology and devotion.
name: Religious Traditions of India

desc: Traces the history of tantra, yoga, and alchemy in South Asia   from the origins of yoga in the first centuries CE through   the medieval period.
name: Yoga, Alchemy, and Tantra: Three Paths to Power in Medieval   India
prequisites: Completion of either: Religious Studies 19 or 20 or 160A or 169; or prior  consent of instructor.

desc: A comparative study of the interrelationship of law and   religion within society. Examples selected from the legal   traditions of small-scale societies, the great   civilizations   of the past, and modern societies.
name: Religion and Law

desc: Will explore the reformist movement that has arisen within   and outside the Islamic   Republic, which attempts to reconcile social and economic   modernity with newer and   more tolerant interpretations of Shi'i Islam. Readings will   be in English.
name: Reformist Shi'ism Today

desc: Examines the contemporary religious politics of love, sex and   gender relations in Egypt. As in the United States, the proper   organization of intimate life and women's bodies has been placed at   the center of politics. Politics has become intensely personal,   joining political projects of religious nation-making with personal   decisions as to how people, and particularly young women, should   organize their private lives and navigate the public sphere.
name: Politics of Veiling in Modern Egypt

desc: Features lectures by various visiting professors or adjunct   lecturers on topics pertaining to the study of religions   using various methodological approaches to subjects that  are the specialty of the respective instructors. Course   content will vary.
instructors: LOPEZ F R, FASULA P, BUSTO R V
name: Topics in Religious Studies

desc: Projects for advanced work in Religious Studies in conjunction with individual members of the faculty and developed by students. For honors students who with to graduate with the distinction in Religious Studies.
name: Senior Honors Thesis
prequisites: Two prior upper-division courses in religious studies; consent of instructoand department; senior standing; open to religious studies majors only.

desc: These internships pair students with philanthropic and non-profit organizations, nationally and globally.  Students work digitally or on site with theorganization. They will learn about practical implications of a degree in Religious Studies and in the Humanities more generally. They will also have the opportunity to put to use their knowledge of foreign languages and technology. While helping to make the world a better place, students will gain valuable experience that can be applied to their chosen career after graduation.
name: Internship

desc: Projects for work in religious studies in conjunction with individual members of the faculty and developed by students.
name: Independent Studies in Religion
prequisites: Two upper-division courses in religious studies; consent of instructor and department; open to Religious Studies majors only.

desc: Faculty supervised reseach. Written work is usually required.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Two upper-division courses in religious studies; consent of instructor and department; open to Religious Studies majors only.

desc: Study or research under the guidance of a member of the advisory committee for seniors of high scholastic standing. Students wishing to enroll should prepare a short plan of study for their course work.
name: Independent Studies in the Renaissance
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Renaissance Studies.

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by department chair and filed with graduate division.
name: Directed Reading in Research

desc: Comprehensive introduction to Russian. Focus on developing basic communicative skills (speaking, listening comprehension, reading, writing) within theframework of contemporary Russian culture. Students acquire a basic grammatical framework for further language study. Audio, visual, and web-based materials included.
instructors: MCCLAIN K L, MCLELLAN L, MOVSESIAN H
name: Elementary Russian

desc: Focuses on developing fluency, expanding vocabulary, and acquiring basic reading and writing skills. Comprehensive review of basic Russian grammar; introduction to participles and verbal adverbs. Audio, video, and web-based materials are an integral part of the course.
name: Intermediate Russian

desc: Continued development of oral and written fluency. Special attention to development of reading skills through a variety of texts related to Russian culture. Systematic review of advanced grammar. Compositions, translations and oral presentations required. Periodic screenings of Russian films.
name: Advanced Russian

desc: Intensive study of one writer. Readings supplemented by selected criticism.Taught in English.
name: Chekhov

desc: Introduction to Russian art and aesthetic theory from the beginning to the present. Readings and lectures in English.
name: Russian Art

desc: Introduction to the calendar cycle, rituals, dance, music, and folkcraft ofthe Slavs and other East European peoples.
name: Slavic and East European Folklore

desc: An independent study course (one or two quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic which results in a documented project or a senior thesis.
name: Senior Thesis in Russian

desc: Guided reading on a subject not covered in the regularly offered courses.
name: Readings in Russian
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 courses in Slavic.

desc: Independent Studies in Russian.
name: Independent Studies in Russian
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Slavic.

desc: Explores the connection between data and theory as they are developed in the major research traditions in sociology. Approaches that may be discussed are the quasi-experimental model, comparative-historical research and/or relational methods.
name: Logics of Inquiry

desc: Fundamental issues in contemporary social theory from their emergence in the Enlightenment, through the writings of Marx, Durkheim, and Weber, to present day controversies.
name: Sociological Theory

desc: Selected topics in the sociological analysis of race,   ethnicity, and nation,   as well as their intersection with questions of gender and   class.
name: Topics in Race, Ethnicity, and Nation

desc: Seminar on the sociological study of culture, examining theoretical perspectives, definitional and analytical problems, production of culture, and cultural effects.
name: Sociology of Culture

desc: The professional roles of sociologists as teacher, researcher, and colleague will be explored.  This course will introduce students to the culture of the discipline, the department and the university.  Students will explore the skills and sensibilities of effective teaching in undergraduate settings. Colloquia presentations will be considered as alternative modes of teaching effectiveness. Faculty presentations on their own pedagogic methods and current research activity will be included.
name: Professional Development Seminar

desc: The application of research and theory to classroom practice in the teaching of undergraduate sociolgy courses. At the teaching assistant level, faculty will supervise individual students as they lead discussion sections, prepare and grade examinations, read written assignments, and engage in individual consultations with undergraduates. Associates will be responsible for courses in their entirety. Weekly meetings with instructor are required.
name: Apprentice Teaching
prequisites: Sociology 290A-B-C and teaching assistant or associate status.

desc: Content will vary with individual students, each of whom will be instructedin the practical aspects of doing research in the area employed--bibliographical work, interviewing, statistical analyses, or questionnaire construction and analysis. Weekly group meetings with instructor are required.
name: Research Assistance Practicum

desc: Presentation of research completed, in progress or proposed, with faculty in attendance. Students are expected to offer critical and useful comments on research.
name: Graduate Workshop In Sociological Research

desc: Individual tutorial. Plan of study must be approved by department chair.
name: Directed Reading And Research

desc: Individual study for M.S. and Ph.D examinations. Normally taken with the student's committee chair.
name: Independant Study M.A.-Ph.D. Examinations

desc: M.A. thesis research and preparation. Research and preparation for the Master's thesis. Normally taken with the student's M.A. committee chair.
name: M.A. Thesis Research Preparation

desc: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation. Ph.D. dissertation preparation. Normally taken with the student's committee chair.
name: Ph.D Dissertation Research and Preparation.

desc: Basic concepts and issues in the study of human society. The structures andprocesses of human conduct, social organization, and social change.
instructors: GORDON A F, LYTLE G A, SOTO O F, CHAJDAS T W, AWADALLA C A, KAPLAN R E, LEAVELL V H, GONZALES G G, YANG R
name: Introduction to Sociology

desc: Eligible students are invited to enroll in the honors seminar which is generally taught by the course instructor.
name: Introduction to Sociology - Honors
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Sociology 1 and consent of instructor; students must meet departmental honors criteria.

desc: Critical reviews and discussions of related topics in sociology under the guidance of a faculty member. Students wishing to enroll must prepare a short plan of study.
name: Readings in Sociology

desc: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in   the department. Course offers exceptional students the   opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a   research group. Students wishing to enrollmust prepare a   short plan of study.
name: Introduction to Research in Sociology

desc: Traces the history of environmentalism and applies social science theories,concepts, and methods to analyze critical contemporary environmental issuesand societal responses to them.
name: Environmental Sociology

desc: Fundamentals of designing, conducting, and analyzing social surveys. While the focus is on survey techniques, problems of design and interpretation inexperimental and observational studies are touched upon in terms of similarities and contrasts.
instructors: CAST A D, BRYANT K N, LAHIRI S
name: Methods of Sociological Research

desc: A survey of several methodological approaches that can be applied to the analysis of culture. Methods will be chosen from among the following: interviewing, content analysis, historical methods, structuralism, survey, ethnography, etc.
instructors: FRITZLER M A, KEMP J L
name: Methods of Cultural Analysis

desc: Surveys major instances of economic, poltical, cultural, and social change in the Middle East, historically and in the contemporary period. Assesses changing social structures, social movements, the role of Islam, and other topics in Iran, Egypt, and Turkey, among others.
name: Development and Social Change in the Middle East

desc: Causes, dynamics and consequences of protest. American social movements, particularly labor, civil rights, student and women's movements, are studied as cases in movement development. Documentary and fiction films help illustrate   analytic themes and historical moments.
name: Social Movements

desc: A seminar for advanced research on and discussion of the sociology of humansexuality. Each student facilitates one class discussion on one of the maintopics on sexuality.
instructors: BALDWIN J D BALDWIN J I

timeslots.instructor: BALDWIN J D BALDWIN J I

name: Topics in Human Sexuality

desc: The course covers specific details about human sexuality. Course content will be determined by students and instructors.
instructors: BALDWIN J D BALDWIN J I

timeslots.instructor: BALDWIN J D BALDWIN J I

name: Advanced Study in the Sociology of Human Sexuality

desc: A lecture course on family and household organiz tion, past and present. Attention to contemporary issues in the American family focusing on gender,class, and cultural variation.
name: Sociology of the Family

desc: Introduction to interdisciplinary feminist literature on girls culture. Examination of how girls from range of racial/ethnic, class, religious, and national backgrounds respond to social inequalities and cultural prescriptions of femininity. Topics include sexuality, popular culture, economic dependence and activism.
name: Sociology of Girls and Girlhood

desc: Institutional analysis of administrative structures and voluntary associations; informal organization, ideology, bureaucracy, decision making, and morale.
name: The Structure and Dynamics of Organizations

desc: Introduction to the sociological study of conformity and deviance, with emphasis on processes of social control.
name: Sociology of Deviant Behavior

desc: Analysis of the structure and agency of juvenile justice. The history and function of the juvenile justice system (structure) and the experience and behavior (agency) of juveniles who are "deviant" or "delinquent" is examined.
name: Juvenile Justice: Youth Offenders and the Criminal Justice System in the New Millenium

desc: Sociological analysis of law enforcement systems and court systems; police discretion, differential implementation of the criminal law; negotiation incriminal justice decisions.
name: Criminal Justice and the Community

desc: An examination of major developments in French social theory both from the historical and the thematic point of view. Authors studied may include: Comte, Durkheim, Mauss, Althusser, Foucault, Bourdieu, Sartre, Levi-strauss, and Baudrillard.
name: French Social Theory

desc: Exploration of both classical and contemporary theories about social power.Application of these ideas to two or three special topics each quarter suchas gender, organizations, work, and the state. Emphasis on explaining historical foundations of institutional arrangements.
name: Power in Social Institutions

desc: Study of Marx and related theorists, with links to   contemporary debates and conflicts over capitalism and   economic inequality.
name: Marxist and Critical Social Theory

desc: Designed for outstanding students who intern as course assistants under thesupervision of the assigned faculty member.
name: Instructional Laboratory in Sociology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Students will develop research topics and appropriate   methodologies. General issues of sociological research will   be discussed, including the relationship between theory and   method.
name: Honors Research Practicum in Sociology
prequisites: Open to upper-division sociology majors only.

desc: Readings in sociology under the guidance of a faculty member in the department students wishing to enroll should prepare a short plan of study.
name: Readings in Sociology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two prior upper-division courses in sociology.

desc: Independent studies in sociology under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Students wishing to enroll should prepare a short plan of study.
name: Independent Studies in Sociology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two prior upper-division courses in sociology.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Sociology
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two prior upper-division courses in sociology; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Selected topics in historical phonology in light of recent   scholarship.
name: History of Spanish and Portuguese Languages

desc: Primarily intended to train students in research   techniques; background  material and selection of topic. Completion of research   paper, reporting regularly to class on progress of work.
name: Research Seminar in Spanish-American Literature

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division Spanish courses at UCSB. Participation in occasional workshops related to the field of teaching willbe required.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division Spanish courses at UCSB. Participation in occasional workshops related to the field of teaching willbe required.
name: Teaching Associate Practicum

desc: A special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by student's program adviser and by the department chair. The number of units which a student may take in this series depends on the nature of the program and consent of the adviser or the departmental graduate committee.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor; approval of department chair.

desc: Individual study for M.A. comprehensive and Ph.D. examinations. Instructor study for M.A. comprehensive and Ph.D. examinations. Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of doctoral committee.
name: Individual Study for M.A. Comprehensive and Ph.D. Examinations

desc: Only for research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor; approval of department chair.

desc: Ph.D. dissertation preparation. Only for research in preparing and writing of the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: Hispanic Literature in relation to literary problems in   general. Such topics as:the functions of literature,   literary periods, movements and trends. The analysis and   interpretation of texts.
name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature

desc: Introduction to linguistic theories, methods, and problems as applied to Spanish. Taught in Spanish with Spanish examples.
name: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
prequisites: SPAN 16A and 16B or SPAN 25 (may be taken concurrently).

desc: Medieval Spanish literature.
name: Spanish Literature from the Beginning to the Present

desc: Colonial Spanish-American literature.
name: Spanish-American Literature from the Beginning to the Present

desc: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the Spanish system, as follows: phonetics and phonemics.
name: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach

desc: The different languages spoken in the Hispanic world: their origins, development, convergence, divergence, and diffusion in relation to historical processes.
name: Language and History in the Hispanic World

desc: Covers different periods of the Spanish cinema history and the way movies could   represent the history and culture of the twentieth century in Spain.It may be   offered in English or Spanish based on the materials and the instructor who is   teaching the course.
name: Spanish Cinema

desc: Focus is on the social and cultural history of the different   languages inthe Iberian Peninsula, including Spanish -   whether in Spain, Latin America or the U.S. The course   analyzes and compares their present status within mostly   bilingual communities.
name: Sociolinguistics of Iberian Languages

desc: Catalan for advanced students. An intensive course for   students with no previous study of Catalan.
name: Catalan Language and Culture

desc: Spanish Basque Culture, the Basque language, its uniqueness, the geography of the Basque country (Euskalerria), its history, its literature in Basque and in Spanish.
name: Basque Studies

desc: An intensive course for students with no previous study of   the Basque language.
name: Basque Language and Culture

desc: Spanish literature since the Civil War a study of the main trends of post-war Spanish novel, theatre, and poetry, in their historical and socialcontext.
name: Contemporary Spanish Literature

desc: Social, institutional, intellectual, and artistic trends in the developmentof modern Mexico.
name: Mexican Culture
prequisites: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 or equivalent language proficiency.

desc: An introduction to the field of Second Language Acquisition   and Foreign Language Teaching. Special attention will be   given to topics that have proved most problematic for native   speakers of English who learn Spanish as a second language.   After a general overview of Applied Linguistics, the course   will cover topics dealing with teaching situations. This   course is a theoretical and practical review of how to teach   writing, reading, communicative competence, listening   comprehension and culture at all levelsof Spanish study.
name: Foreign Language Teaching

desc: The student will engage in research lead ing to a paper of considerable depth and complexity on a topic dealing with the literature and/or languageof Spain and Spanish America.
name: Senior Honors Independent Research

desc: This course enables students to obtain credit for Spanish or Portuguese related internship experience. The course is graded P/NP and must be taken in conjunction with Spanish 199, for which a written project related to the internship experience must be completed.
name: Internship
prequisites: Upper-division standing; Spanish or Portuguese majors only; consent of department.

desc: Independent studies in selected subjects not covered by course offerings.
name: Independent Studies in Spanish
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in Spanisconsent of department.

desc: Students receiving credit will present talks in their field on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.
name: Biology Colloquium

desc: This course is supplementary to MCDB 1A.  It is intended for and open only to CCS students enrolled in MCDB 1A.  Students will attend MCDB 1A lecturesand also meet for more in-depth consideration and analysis of the lecture materials and their broader implications.
name: CCS Introductory Biology I

desc: Serious independent study in biology with consenting faculty member.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Anatomical, physiological, and neurological bases for an understanding of speech communication.
name: Anatomy, Physiology, and Neurology of the Speech Mechanism

desc: Independent work with faculty sponsor culminating in senior thesis.
name: Undergraduate Thesis

desc: Selected topics in accordance with instructor's area of specialization.
name: Group Studies for Advanced Students
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Tutoring experience for advanced undergraduate students in preparation for graduate education.
name: Instructional Laboratory

desc: Independent studies.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Univariate and multivariate distribution theory; generating functions; inequalities in statistics; order statistics; estimation theory: likelihood, sufficiency, efficiency, maximum likelihood; testing hypotheses: likelihood ratio and score tests, power; confidence and prediction intervals; bayesian estimation and hypothesis testing; basic decision theory, linear regression; analysis of variance.
name: Statistical Theory
prequisites: PSTAT 120A-B-C. Part of a three quarter sequence with 207B and 207C.

desc: Probability spaces: axioms, sigma-algebras, monotone class theorems, construction of probability measures on measurable spaces. Random variables. Expectations (integral Lebesque). Product spaces and Fubini theorem. L2 spaces of random variables.
name: Measure Theory for Probability

desc: Generating functions, discrete and continuous time Markov chains; random walks; branching processes; birth-death processes; Poisson processes, point processes.
name: Introduction To Probability Theory And Stochastic Processes

desc: General linear models; regression; analysis of variance of fixed, random, and mixed effects models; analysis of covariance; and experimental design. Discussion of each technique includes graphical methods; estimation and inference; diagnostics; and model selection. Emphasis on application rather than theory. R/SAS Computation.
name: Advanced Statistical Methods

desc: Topics chosen from: large deviations; random walks; weak covergence in metric spaces; empirical processes; point processes; Gaussian processes; randomfields; branching processes; inference for stochastic processes. Applications.
name: Advanced Probability Theory

desc: An introduction to Brownian motion, stochastic calculus and   stochastic differential equations. Diffusion processes,   related partial differential equations and Feynman-Kac   formula. Applications to filtering, stochastic control,   mathematical finance and other areas of science and   engineering.
name: STOCHASTIC CALCULUS AND APPLICATIONS
prequisites: PSTAT 213A-B-C (or equivalent first-year graduate course in Probability   and   Stochastic Processes).

desc: Data Mining is used to discover patterns and   relationships in large data sets. Topics will   include: data exploration, classification and regression   trees, random forests, clustering and   association rules. Building predictive models focusing on   model selection, model comparison and performance   evaluation. Emphasis will be on concepts, methods and   data analysis; and students   are expected to complete a significant class project,   individual or team based, using real   world data.
instructors: FRANKS A, ZAPATA J, WANG YUANBO
name: Data Mining
prequisites: PSTAT 120A-B; and PSTAT 126 with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Topics of current research interest in probability and/or   statistics, by means of lectures and informal conferences   with members of staff. PSTAT 262FM is reserved for topics in   financial mathematics and statistics.
name: Seminars In Probability and Statistics

desc: Research seminars presented by faculty, visiting scholars, and invited speakers on current research topics.
name: Research Seminars in Probability and Statistics

desc: Stationary and non-stationary models, seasonal time series, ARMA models: calculation of ACF, PACF, mean and ACF estimation. Barlett's formula, model estimation: Yule-Walker estimates, ML method. Identification techniques, diagnostic checking, forecasting, spectral analysis, the periodogram. Current software and applications.
instructors: FELDMAN R, HUYNH N T, ZHOU Z, NING N
name: Time Series

desc: Introduction to research skills. Discussion of current   research trends, writing literature reviews etc. Students will   be required to present material reflecting their interests in   actuarial science, which will be critically appraised for both   content and presentation. Emphasis will be placedon aiding   students to acquire a high-level of professionalism.
name: Intro to Research in Actuarial Science

desc: Consideration of ideas about the process of learning probability and statistics, and discussion of approaches to teaching.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Readings for area examinations.
name: Readings for Area Examinations
prequisites: Enrollment in M.A. or Ph.D. program.

desc: Directed reading and research.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Only for research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis. Instructor should be the chair of the student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Ph.D dissertation preparation.
name: Ph.D Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Random variables, sampling distribution, estimation   hypothesis testing, correlation and regression, other   topics from statistics. Computing labs required.
instructors: NAVA M M, KU B C, ZHANG CHAO, ZHANG XINYUE, YOVANOVICH C, ANDREI M S, YI Z, LUO YA
name: Statistics

desc: Eligible students will be invited to enroll. A variety of   statistics  topics will be introduced based on weekly reading   assignments. As well as preparation for discussion, a 15-  minute group presentation or a short (2-3 pages) analytical   essay will be required.
name: Honors Seminar, Statistics

desc: An introduction to statistics for students interested in   the   quantitative analysis of problems in the life sciences.   The   focus is on application; topics include probability,   correlation and regression, sampling distributions,   confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing.
instructors: SWENSON J S, LUO W, LEI S, LIU LU
name: Statistics for Life Sciences

desc: An overview of data analytic thinking through examples. Introduction to   descriptive statistics and linear regression. Fundamentals of programming   using R. Basic graphics in R. Relational database management systems and   simple data manipulation using SQL.
instructors: HOLMES D E, XU D, HU M, LEE Y, HAN XINZHI
name: Introduction to Computing for Data Science
prequisites: Math 3B with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Independent study under the guidance of a faculty member in   the department. Course offers exceptional students an   opportunity to undertake independent study or work in a group.
name: Independent Studies in Statistics

desc: Statistical methods for model-free data analysis, including use of ranks incomparing means and assessing correlation, computer-based permutation and bootstrap   calculations for significance tests and confidence intervals, estimation of lifetime   survival curves. Emphasis on scientific applications.
instructors: CARTER A V, XU CHANGWEI, BANG S
name: Introduction to Nonparametric Methods
prequisites: PSTAT 120B with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: An introduction to probabilistic modeling and statistical   inference for students with basic knowledge of calculus:   probability, discrete and continuous random variables,   probability distributions, mean, variance, correlation,   sampling, parameter estimation, unbiasedness and efficiency,   confidence intervals, hypothesis testing.  Computing labs with Excel.
instructors: NAVA M M, SHERRARD R W, ISRAEL CANCAD, UHRIG R A, KOGELNIK M J, BERNSTEIN A D, YIN M, NING N, JIN H, WANG JIAQI, LEE S W, FU W
name: Statistics for Economics
prequisites: Math 34A-B or Math 3A-B; Math34B or 3B can be taken simultaneously. Course cannot be used to satisfy any Actuarial Science, Financial Math & Statistics   or Statistical Science major or minor requirements.

desc: Concepts of probability; random variables; combinatorial   probability; discrete and   continuous distributions; joint distributions, expected   values; moment generating   functions; law of large numbers and central limit theorems.
instructors: MYUNG JIYOUN, WANG KE, URBISCI L C, CHEN A P, CHEN T, MAZANIANS A, JAMMALAMADAKA, WANG QI, HOLLADAY B A, BAPAT S R, GHOSAL A, GOU W, CARTER A V, ZHENG J, GORDEE A J
name: Probability and Statistics
prequisites: Math 3C or Math 4A or Math 4AI or Math 6A or Math 6AI completed with a   minimum grade of C or better.

desc: An introduction to statistical design and analysis of experiments. Covers: principles of randomization, blocking and replication; fixed, random and mixed   effects models; block designs, factorial designs and nested designs; analysis of   variance and multiple comparison.
instructors: SHIAU J H, JIN Q, XU JIAYE
name: Design and Analysis of Experiments
prequisites: PSTAT 120B with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Linear and multiple regression, analysis of residuals, transformations,   variable and model selection including stepwise regression, and analysis of covariance. The course will stress the use of computer packages to solve real-world problems.
instructors: PETERSEN A M, XLIU, HALL B R, GROSS T M, FU W, SPENCER E B
name: Regression Analysis
prequisites: PSTAT 120B with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: In depth SAS programming course. Topics include importing/exporting raw data files, manipulating/transforming data, combining SAS data sets, generating reports, handling syntax and logic errors. Provides preparation for the SAS   Institute Certified Professional (Base Programming) Examination.
instructors: SWENSON J S, ZHU X, LYU XIN
name: SAS Base Programming
prequisites: One upper division course in PSTAT, MATH, Computer Science or ECE.

desc: Data Mining is used to discover patterns and relationships in large data sets. Topics will include:   data exploration, classification and regression tress, random forests, clustering and association   rules. Building predictive models focusing on model selection, model comparison and performance   evaluation. Emphasis will be on concepts, methods and data analysis; and students are expected to complete a significant class project, individual or team based, using real-world data.
instructors: FRANKS A, ZAPATA J, WANG YUANBO
name: Data Mining
prequisites: PSTAT 120A-B and PSTAT 126 with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Discrete probability models. Review of discrete and continuous probability.Conditional expectations. Simulation techniques for random variables. Discrete   time stochastic processes: random walks and Markov chains with applications to   Monte Carlo simulation and mathematical finance. Introduction to Poisson   process.
instructors: HOHN M E, MENG F, ZHANG Z, MARQUIS S M, ANGIULI A
name: Applied Stochastic Processes
prequisites: Mathematics 4A or 4AI or 5A, Mathematics 8, and PSTAT 120A. A minimum letter grade of C or better must be earned in each course.

desc: Describes mathematical methods for estimating and   evaluating   asset pricing models, equilibrium and derivative pricing,   options, bonds, and the term-structure of interest rates.   Also introduces finance optimization models for risk   management and financial engineering.
instructors: DETERING N, SHANNON C C, MENG F
name: Introduction to Mathematical Finance
prequisites: PSTAT 120A-B and 160A, all completed with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Introduction to fixed Income Markets. Topics include: measurement of interest, annuities certain, varying annuities, amortization schedules, sinking funds, bonds and related securities, depreciation.
instructors: DUNCAN I, FAN Y, BROWN M D, VOSS M, YANG TI, HOSKINS D M, CHEN GUOQIANG
name: Mathematics of Fixed Income Markets

desc: Stationary and non-stationary models, seasonal time series, ARMA models:   calculation   of ACF, PACF, mean and ACF estimation. Barlett's formula, model estimation: Yule-  Walker estimates, ML method. identification techniques, diagnostic checking   forecasting, spectral analysis, the periodogram. Current software and applications.
instructors: FELDMAN R, HUYNH N T, ZHOU Z, NING N
name: Time Series
prequisites: PSTAT 120B with a minimum grade of C or better.

desc: Problem solving sessions to prepare students for the first four actuarial examinations. Topics corresponding to these examinations (probability, financial mathematics, statistical modeling, and risk management) will be offered in different quarters.
name: Tutorial in Actuarial Statistics

desc: Faculty sponsored academic internship in industrial or   research firms.
name: Internship in Statistics
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Special topics of current importance in statistical sciences,   actuarial science, or financial mathematics and statistics.   Course content will vary.
name: Special Topics in Statistics
prequisites: Upper-division standing in statistics, actuarial science, and financial   mathematics.

desc: Independent studies in statistics.
name: Independent Studies in Statistics
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in PSTAT.

desc: Lecture series where entrepreneurial, technological,business   and governmental leaders share their lessons of experience and discuss current   business issues. For anyone interested in   entrepreneurship, management, technology development and   commercialization and the impact that innovation has on   society.
name: Opportunities and Perspectives in Technology, Business, and   Society

desc: Course covers business principles relevant to today’s   increasingly competitive international business environment in four areas:   Competitive Strategy and General Management;   Accounting and Finance; Marketing and Sales; and Business   Ethics.
name: Business Strategy & Leadership Skills

desc: Learn how to start any type of venture; for profit, non-  profit, service, sole-proprietorship, with a focus on high-  tech ventures. Analysis of new business opportunities,   development of customer-centric value propositions, financing, marketing,   selling, and protection of intellectual property.
name: Entrepreneurship

desc: New product development requires technical and non-technical   business persons to work across disciplines. Instruction is   provided in a wide range of topics concerning customer driven   product innovation. Students learn new product development   processes, tools, techniques, and organizational skills.
name: New Product Development

desc: Course provides foundation knowledge in Organizational   Behavior.
name: Organizational Behavior

desc: Exploration of how organizing processes enable and   constrain the development and use of technology   innovations.
name: Networks and Innovation

desc: Courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in the areas ofbusiness, technology management, entrepreneurship, and other issues relatedto   the management and creation of sustainable businesses.
name: Special Topics in Business and Management

desc: Covers the major concepts, principles, and analytical   tools that   support financial-based managerial decision-making.   Modules include   measuringand analyzing financial performance, planning   and budgeting,   developingforecasts and financial pro-formas, time value   of money, cost of   capital, risk/return trade-offs, capital budgeting and   investing, cash and   working capital management, and cost accounting and   analysis. Emphasis   will   be on applying these concepts and tools in technology   businesses.
name: Finance and Accounting for Technology-Driven Companies

desc: Data analytics, demand forecasting, defining and   estimating market   segments, determining   consumer preferences. Explores the entire cycle of market   research, from   objectives and planning; choice of methodology; designing   questionnaires   and focus group guides;   collecting, analyzing andinterpreting data; and   presenting findings. Special   emphasis on   usingmarket research to develop and support decision-  making processes to   minimize risk   and direct-resource investment.
name: Product and Market Validation

desc: Provides students with knowledge and tools to manage complex projects and operations to ensure that a project is completed on time, within budget, andwith high quality by exploring specific techniques for accomplishing those three goals. Introduction to commonly used business systems and strategies for managing Value/Supply Chains, Information, Human Resources, considerations and strategies for global business operations. Prepares students to manage people, budgets, scheduling, and quality of projects.
name: Project Management in New Product Development

desc: Explores human capital topics including employee   selection, performance  management, training and development, compensation,   downsizing, and   human capital analytics. Provides an understanding of how   organizations   manage knowledge assets for strategic advantage, and   offers skills for   managing in knowledge-intensive organizations.
name: Creating Value Through Human Capital

desc: Teaches students fundamentals of business communication, including professional writing, presentation formation and delivery, and pitching.
name: Leadership Practicum: Business Communication
prequisites: Graduate standing, enrolled in MTM degree program.

desc: Lecture series where entrepreneurial, technological,business,   and governmental leaders share their lessons of experience and   discuss current business issues. For anyone interested in   entrepreneurship, management, technology development, and   commercialization and the impact that innovation has on   society.
name: Opportunities and Perspectives in Technology, Business, and   Society
prequisites: Writing 2 with a minimum grade of B; and Writing 50 or equivalent with a   minimum grade of B.

desc: Introduction to critical business principles and practices required by   leaders for business   success and societal benefit. Students will be exposedto key   management theories, models   and tools in strategy, finance, accounting, commercialization,   marketing, and sales.
instructors: CALLERY P J, BOGART K S
name: Fundamentals of Business Strategy

desc: Learn how to start any type of venture; for profit, non-profit, service,   sole-  proprietorship, with a focus on high-tech ventures. Analysis of new business   opportunities, development of customer-centric value propositions,   financing,   marketing, selling, and protection of intellectual property.
name: Entrepreneurship
prequisites: TMP 120 with a minimum grade of B-

desc: Learn the art of persuasion and selling. Theory and applications of the   basic tenets of persuasion and how such scientifically supported   techniques can   be deployed to positively impact the sales process.
name: Selling High Tech Products

desc: Provides a high level introduction to modern marketing research. Course   covers   the fundamental principles and techniques for market validation that are   critical to launch, grow, and sustain a viable business.
name: Market Research
prequisites: TMP 120 with a minimum grade of B-.

desc: Varies in content from year to year, but offerings may include studies of the avant-garde and perforance art, sport as ritual and performance, theatreon trial, politics and war as performance.
name: Performance Studies

desc: Projects in dramaturgy; practical applications and projects.
name: Practice in Dramaturgy

desc: Advanced problems in directing, practical applications, and projects. Culminates in directing one-act plays.
name: Practice in Directing
prequisites: Theater 221 or 261; graduate standing; consent of instructor.

desc: An independent study in playwrighting. Students may work on a   full-lengthplay, a one act play, a solo performance text.
name: Practice in Playwriting

desc: Projects in various areas of theatre and dance, including acting, stage management, production and directing.
name: Practice in Theatre and Dance

desc: An examination of trends and traditions in theatre of the United States. Roots of Broadway, U.S. Latino theatre, Asian American theatre, melodrama, the Group Theatre and its legacy, multicultural theatre and contemporary theater.
name: Theatre and Drama of the United States

desc: Introduction to the problems and techniques of teaching dramatic art, through teaching responsibilities in departmental courses and through consultation with supervising faculty members.
name: Teaching: Methods and Practice
prequisites: Graduate standing and current appointment as a departmental teaching       assistant.

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Master's thesis project, research and creative.
name: Master's Thesis Project, Research and Creative

desc: Dissertation research and preparation.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of chair of student's doctoral committee. (Repeatable to 108 units - not 99).

desc: Introduction to theater and performance practice and   traditions in Europe. Topics will include ritual, the rise of   a public theater, the politicaluses of theater, the   development of festival theater, and the uses of performance   in non-theatrical contexts.
name: Performance in Global Contexts: EUROPE

desc: An intensive introduction to playwriting for beginning   dramatists. Students will read   and analyze the structure of plays, write and stage their   own short plays, and gain experience acting in and   directing each other'swork. Homework for the course   includes a series of written and performance-based   assignments.
name: Introduction to Playwriting

desc: Intense physical training designed to produce a neutral, dynamic, and expressive bodily instrument.
name: Movement For The Stage

desc: A fundamental approach to voice for the actor with emphasis on vocal production, articulation, and quality; plus physical relaxation techniques.
name: Voice Laboratory

desc: Development of the intermediate actor's foundational work in improvisation,technique, scene study, textual analysis, and characterization while exploring creative capacity.
name: Fundamentals of Acting

desc: Projects in the interpretation of plays through scenic   elements with concentration on the design process and the   dramatic use of space. Drafting projects including floor   plans, elevations and basic perspective drawing.
name: Scenic Design

desc: Empirical understanding of methods of assembly and materials for stage scenery. Shop organization and operation are experienced during the construction process.
name: Scenic Practicum

desc: Empirical understanding of optical properties of lightin units, available hanging positions and apparatus, lighting control, electrical safety and stage crew organization.
name: Lighting Practicum

desc: Empirical understanding of methods of assembly and materials for stage dress. Costume shop organization and operation are experienced during the construction process.
name: Costume Practicum

desc: Empirical understanding of backstage organization and operation during liveperformance.
name: Run Crew Practicum

desc: Projects in costume, scenery, lighting, acting, directing.
name: Theater Workshop

desc: Special opportunities for study, research, and project preparation.
name: Group Studies For Lower-Division Students

desc: Foundational course exploring the full range of duties and   responsibilities of a stage manager, a vital role for all   theatrical and dance productions.
name: Introduction to Stage Management

desc: An exploration of the essential components of playwriting.   Exercises focus on writing dialogue, monologue, creating three-dimensional characters, building effective story structures, and developing action through language and stage images. A series of written assignments.
name: Playwriting Workshop

desc: A continued exploration of the essential components of   playwriting. Writing exercises in dialogue, monologue,   character, story structure, action and stage images.   Students focus on developing their individual writing   voice. A series of written assignments.
name: Advanced Playwriting Workshop

desc: A continuation of the Dramatic Art 10 series with increased focus on physical characterization and technical skills.
name: Advanced Movement for the Stage

desc: Advanced problems in voice for the actor with continued emphasis on craft, plus the creative and expressive uses of the voice with the body.
name: Advanced Voice Laboratory

desc: Lecture-demonstration of controllable properties and   functions of light. Includes technical drawing: light   plots, scheduling and organization for lighting design,   drawing using light and shadow, perspective drawing.   Practical application through studio exercise.
name: Advanced Stage Lighting Design

desc: Further exploration of performances and criticism of   scenes   from a broad range of dramatic scripts with focus on the   actor's perspective. Practical skills are taught to make   the   physical exploration of the text a valid exercise.
name: Advanced Acting Workshop II

desc: Projects in costume, scenery, lighting, acting, directing.
name: Theatre Workshop

desc: Advanced acting. Scene work and exercises exploring various acting styles which may include Shakespeare, Artaud, Greek, period comedy and farce, and Absurd.
name: Advanced Acting
prequisites: Theater 15C and 188S; concurrent enrollment in Theater 110A and 111A

desc: Preparation and study of material and techniques for professional and graduate school audition.
name: Senior Auditions

desc: Individually researched performance projects.
name: Senior One-Person Shows

desc: Basic principles and practice of directing. Lectures, demonstrations, and projects   to give the nonspecialist and potential directing emphasis student a general idea   of the directorial process.
name: Introduction to Stage Directing

desc: Full directorial responsibility for the mounting of one-act play.
name: Directorial Production

desc: Special projects in each area of concentration.
name: Projects in Design and Production

desc: History of the American drama and theater from early years to 1940. Important plays, performers, institutions, and styles of production are given selective attention.
name: American Drama to 1940

desc: Workshop for advanced students functioning as assistants to directors, designers, and technical directors. portfolio, promptbook, or paper required.
name: Production Administration

desc: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic researchor creative activity, supervised by a faculty adviser. Students successfullycompleting the project, as evalutated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.
name: Senior Honors Project

desc: Intensive study, research, and project preparation in theatrical design.
name: Group Studies in Design

desc: Upper division course that builds upon the foundational   information of THTR 95, providing a greater depth and   breadth of exploration into the duties of the stage manager   from pre-production through strike. Topics include   communication, organizational skills, rehearsal procedures,   and performance responsibilities. Greater stage management   practical experience gained through in-class exercises and   outside assignments.
name: Principles of Stage Management

desc: Production oriented course allowing student practical experience in stage management training. Student will serve as assistant stage manager or stagemanager for a main stage or student directed departmental production.
name: Stage Management Practicum

desc: Exploration of the process of collaboration between dance   choreographers and theater designers in the development of   designs for dance productions. Final project is a public   performance of the choreographers' and designer' work.
name: Dance Production
prequisites: Theater 19; 22 or 123 or 125; upper-division standing; consent of          instructor.

desc: Independent studies in theater.
name: Independent Studies in Theater
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in         Theater.

desc: Graduate credit given for an upper-division course with   additional work at the graduate level.
name: Graduate Studies

desc: Teaching assistants must register during quarter of service for this courseof supervision for instruction.
name: Directed Teaching
prequisites: Appointment as teaching assistant or associate title.

desc: Preparatory orientation and concurrent training in composition   theory andpedagogy for newly appointed Writing Program   teaching assistants. Topics include theories of composition   pedagogy, academic literacies, principlesof instructional   design and curriculum development, effective classroom  practices, and assessment of student writing.
name: Academic Writing Instruction Theory and Practice
prequisites: Application submitted for Writing Program TA appointment.

desc: A three-quarter course sequence that immerses students in the   theory, methods, and issues of Writing Studies. Serves as a   foundation for additional emphasis courses.
name: Proseminar in Writing Studies

desc: Group or individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Principles of critical reading, thinking, and writing in the university. Students analyze academic discourse, develop rhetorical strategies for exposition and   argument, practice examination writing, and write and revise papers.
instructors: WEEDON J S, EVANS K B
name: Approaches to University Writing for Engineers
prequisites: Freshmen only; open to ECE, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Computer Engineering majors only.

desc: Independent studies in writing.
name: Independent Studies in Writing
prequisites: Lower-division standing; students must have satisfied the Subject A and Writing 2 requirements; consent of instructor.

desc: Traces the physical interactions by which sequence-specific polypeptides attain a unique, functional native state. Fold design, fold prediction, and protein folding kinetics are also discussed.
name: Protein Structure and Function

desc: Primary, secondary, and higher-order structures of DNA and RNA, thermodynamic stability and folding, protein-nucleic acid interactions, ribozymes, applications to gene regulation, RNA world evolution.
name: Chemistry and Structure of Nucleic Acids
prequisites: MCDB 108A-B-C; and, Chemistry 113A or 142A or 142B or 142C.

desc: Practical theory and application of basic biochemical techniques. Topics include SDS-PAGE, buffers, centrifugation, antibody methods, spectroscopy andfluorescence techniques.
name: Biochemical Techniques
prequisites: One year of undergraduate biochemistry (e.g., MCDB 108A-B-C) or equivalent.

desc: Discussion topics relevant to structure-function relationships in proteins including the chemical reactivity of amino acid side chains, posttranslational modifications, and the covalent and noncovalent interactions of multimeric structures. Case studies involve recent advances in structure-function relationships of mechanoproteins.
name: Protein Biochemistry

desc: Discussion of experimental strategies used to purify, analyze, and manipulate nucleic acids, isolate molecular clones from complex genomes, physicallymap genomes, analyze gene expression, and perform reverse genetics.
name: Experimental Strategies in Molecular Genetics

desc: Research presentations by postdoctoral fellows and advanced Ph.D. students of research progress in the department.
name: Research Progress in Biomolecular Science and Engineering

desc: A weekly seminar discussion group to review, in advance, relevant literature of participating BMSE seminar guests.
name: BMSE Seminar Discussion Group

desc: Survey of classes of biomolecules (lipids, carbohydrates, proteins, nucleicacids).   Structure and function of molecular machines (enzymes for biosynthesis, motors,   pumps).
name: Biomolecular Materials I: Structure and Function

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: A. Biomolecular Materials Synthesis.
name: Group Studies: Biomolecular Materials Synthesis

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: B. Biomineralization.
name: Group Studies: Biomineralization

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: BP. Bacterial Pathogenesis.
name: Group Studies: Bacterial Pathogenesis

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: CE. C. elegans Development.
name: Group Studies: C. elegans Development

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be   selected from the following list: A. Biomolecular Materials   Synthesis; B. Biomineralization; BP. Bacterial Pathogenesis;   CE. C. elegans Development; DN. Developmental Neurobiology;   HW. Marine Structural Proteins; PM. Molecular Plant-Microbe   Interactions; PR. Protein-Nucleic Acid Interactions; S.   Molecular Virology and Interferon Action.
name: Group Studies

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: DN. Developmental Neurobiology.
name: Group Studies: Developmental Neurobiology

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: HW. Marine Structural Proteins.
name: Group Studies: Marine Structural Proteins

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, to be selected from the following list: PM. Molecular Plant-Microbe Interactions.
name: Group Studies: Molecular Plant-Microbe Interactions

desc: Laboratory rotation project in BMSE faculty laboratories.
name: Laboratory Research Rotation in Biochemistry
prequisites: Enrollment in the BMSE Ph.D. program; open to first year graduate students only.

desc: A critical review of research in selected areas of biochemistry-molecular biology.
name: Biochemistry/Molecular Biology Literature Seminar

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor is usually the student's major research advisor. Each faculty member has a unique number designation.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Writing of the Ph.D. dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing as a Ph.D. student and advancement to Doctoral Candidacy.

desc: UCSB faculty working in Creative Writing, Writing Studies,   and Literary  Studies present their research or creative work to expose   students to   examples of topics, theories, and methods in those   disciplines.
name: Writing and Literature Colloquium

desc: Students engage in discussions of the presentations given   in the   Writing and Literature Colloquium. Focuses on introducing   the   disciplines andexploring the relationships between the   material and   the students’ interests.
name: First Year Colloquium Seminar

desc: Students engage in discussions of the presentations given   in the   Writing and Literature Colloquium. Encourages deeper   engagement with   the material of the colloquium through reading of   complementary texts   and exploring application of methods and theories to the   work students   will commit to in the Mid-Residency Review.
name: Second Year Colloquium Seminar

desc: Provides an introduction to the intellectual orientation,   practices, and epistemologies of Writing Studies.
name: Introduction to Writing Studies

desc: Students write original poems to be read and discussed in a   workshop setting.   Students learn the essentials of the craft of poetry as   well as strategies to   generate and revise work.
name: Poetry Workshop

desc: Students write original works of fiction to be read and   discussed in   a workshop setting. Students learn the essentials of the   craft of   fictionwriting as well as strategies to generate and   revise work.
name: Fiction Workshop

desc: Students write diary entries as a literary form to be read   and discussed in a workshop setting.   Students learn to use diaries as a tool for invention and   how to craft diary entries into   narratives.
name: Diaries to Stories

desc: Students write original works of creative nonfiction to be   read and   discussed in a workshop setting. Students learn the   essentials of the   craft of creative nonfiction as well as strategies to   generate and revise   work.
name: Creative Nonfiction Workshop

desc: Full-year course offering instruction in literary   publication. Students apply what they learn to creating the CCS literary magazines Spectrum and Into the Teeth of the Wind or to an independent project. Topics covered include establishing an editorial perspective, developing and soliciting content, promotion, document design and layout, and strategies for copyediting.
name: Literary Publishing

desc: UCSB faculty working in Creative Writing, Writing Studies,   and Literary  Studies present their research or creative work to expose   students to   examples of topics, theories, and methods in those   disciplines.
name: Writing and Literature Colloquium

desc: Students engage in discussions of the presentations given   in the   Writing and Literature Colloquium. Focuses on introducing   the   disciplines andexploring the relationships between the   material and   the students’ interests.
name: First Year Colloquium Seminar

desc: Students engage in discussions of the presentations given   in the   Writing and Literature Colloquium. Encourages deeper   engagement with   the material of the colloquium through reading of   complementary texts   and exploring application of methods and theories to the   work students   will commit to in the Mid-Residency Review.
name: Second Year Colloquium Seminar

desc: Provides an introduction to the intellectual orientation,   practices, and epistemologies of Writing Studies.
name: Introduction to Writing Studies

desc: Students write original poems to be read and discussed in a   workshop setting.   Students learn the essentials of the craft of poetry as   well as strategies to   generate and revise work.
name: Poetry Workshop

desc: Students write original works of fiction to be read and   discussed in   a workshop setting. Students learn the essentials of the   craft of   fictionwriting as well as strategies to generate and   revise work.
name: Fiction Workshop

desc: Students write diary entries as a literary form to be read   and discussed in a workshop setting.   Students learn to use diaries as a tool for invention and   how to craft diary entries into   narratives.
name: Diaries to Stories

desc: Students write original works of creative nonfiction to be   read and   discussed in a workshop setting. Students learn the   essentials of the   craft of creative nonfiction as well as strategies to   generate and revise   work.
name: Creative Nonfiction Workshop

desc: Full-year course offering instruction in literary   publication. Students apply what they learn to creating the CCS literary magazines Spectrum and Into the Teeth of the Wind or to an independent project. Topics covered include establishing an editorial perspective, developing and soliciting content, promotion, document design and layout, and strategies for copyediting.
name: Literary Publishing

desc: Hours and credit arranged with any member of the staff. Laboratory.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.

desc: A seminar focusing on criticism of current art work.
name: Graduate Seminar in Critique
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: In-depth look at contemporary media and art discourse framed   through a wide range of theoretical approaches: formalism,   structuralism, phenomenology, psychoanalysis, Marxism, gender   and queer studies, poststructuralism,postcolonial theory,   deconstruction, issues of authorship, narratology, and   multiculturalism. Specific content varies with instructor.
name: Graduate Theory Seminar
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Symposium format course presents contemporary artists'   creative projects in relation to recent developments in art   and cross-disciplinary practices. Lectures by faculty from   UCSB's Art Department supplemented by distinguished guests   invited to expand on art, theory and cultural production.
name: All Faculty Graduate Seminar

desc: Practice of teaching art.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Study in Visual Arts Education
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: M.F.A. Thesis Project
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Independent research involving extensive reading and written   essay on a  particular period, artist, or body of work with a historical   context.
name: Direct Historical Reading and Research

desc: For graduate students who serve as teaching assistants: analyses of texts and materials; discussion of teaching techniques; conducting discussion sections; formulation of topics and questions for papers and examinations; and grading papers and examinations under supervision of instructor assigned tocourse.
name: Teaching Methodology in Black Studies
prequisites: Appointment as teaching assistant in Black Studies.

desc: Individual tutorial. Plan of study must be approved by department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: To assist graduate students who are doing research or writing   their master's thesis in African area studies and/or Black   Studies.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: PhD Dissertation Research and Preparation
name: PhD Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Explores historical and current social conditions of black people in the United States. Topics include slavery, emancipation, reconstruction and urbanblack migration, with particular consideration given to the black church and the black family as bearers and creators of African-American culture.
instructors: STEWART J C, EDWARDS J A, FLOWERS N Z
name: Introduction to African-American Studies

desc: A survey of the culture and society of the Caribbean. After surveying Amerindian communities and examining the impact of the Atlantic slave trade, focus will be on slavery, emancipation, African and Creole cultures,and the issues accompanying an independent nationhood status.
instructors: MCAULEY C, ARGUERA S M, PINHEIRO DE O
name: Introduction to Caribbean Studies

desc: An introduction to the diverse literary traditions of Africa through an examination of selected works. Regional focus on North, West, East, Central, and South Africa varies.
name: Major Works of African Literatures

desc: Independent studies and mentorship in Black Studies under the direction of a   faculty member in the department.
name: Independent Studies in Black Studies
prequisites: BL ST 1 or 3 or 4 or 7 and one additional course in Black Studies.

desc: Explores the effects of social, political, and economic forces on the history of Black education. Examines ways of challenging the impacts of race, class, gender, and language in the educational achievement of Black children.Focuses on anti-bias/multicultural curricula in urban settings. Fieldwork required.
name: The Education of Black Children

desc: An exploration of the intersection of Black Studies and Queer Studies from various theoretical, literary, historical, and multi-media perspectives. Cultural producers studied include: Audre Lorde, Marlon Riggs, Bayard Rustin,and Bruce Nugent.
name: Queer Black Studies

desc: Examines the evolution of African-American urban communities. Focuses on theoretical and historiographical debates including: social organization; conditions; daily life; culture; social movements; sustainable development; and class, gender, race relations. Analysis of current policy debates and community initiatives.
name: The Urban Dilemma

desc: History of Francophone West Indian and African literature from the 1920s through the 1950s. Writers studied include Aime and Suzanne Cesaire, Leon Gontran Damas, Leopold Sedar Senghor, and Jane and Paulette Nardal.
name: Negritude and African Literature

desc: Examines the intersection of gender, sexuality, race, and class in creatingdisadvantage and advantage. In examining how racism, sexism, and heterosexism shape Black life chances in a 21st century context, this course focuses on systems of oppression that exist within and outside Black communities.
name: Gender and Sexuality in Black Studies

desc: Designed to introduce students to the history and contemporary influence ofhip hop, including rap music, break dancing, graffiti, Bboying, djing, fashion, global marketing, etc. Traces the history of hip hop from its early emergence in the Bronx in the 1970s to its emergence as the global soundtrackof the 21st century. Students will also study the particular urban geographies of hip hop culture and its critique of social, political, and economic conditions of Black life.
name: Hip-Hop

desc: Explores, with examples from dominant (Hollywood) cinema and   African cinema, what the sample films show about the   relationship between ideology and representation, especially   the reference points through which Africa functions as a site   of complex and conflicting meanings.
name: Africa in Film

desc: Each student, under the direction of the department chair,   will identify a research topic and map out a research   project with the appropriate faculty member(s). Research   will begin in Fall and continue more intensely during   Winter. Research papers will be completed in Spring with a   formal presentation before an audience of faculty, graduate   and undergraduate students in Black Studies.
name: Honors Thesis Seminar in Black Studies

desc: Directed field research or writing seminar on a topic in Black   Studies.
name: Research Seminar

desc: Independent studies in Black Studies.
name: Independent Studies in Black Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 cumulative and major GPA for the   preceding three quarters; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Black   Studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Black Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; minimum 3.0 cumulative and major GPA for the   preceding 3 quarters; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Black   Studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Fundamental concepts in classical thermodynamics and statistical mechanics for engineering students. Establishes the framework within which problems can be solved using methodologies that start with molecular level understanding.
name: Fundamentals and Applications of Classical Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics

desc: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.
name: Matrix Analysis and Computation
