desc: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptical partial differential equations, with applicationto problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.
name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Element Methods

desc: Overview of soft materials (suspensions, gels, polymers,   surfactants,   emulsions, powders and   granules) that arise in diverse industries, including   consumer   products, foods, advanced   materials, biotechnology, and mineral and energy   production.   Influence of non-Newtonian   rheology (shear-thickening and thinning, viscoelasticity,   extension-  thickening, yield stresses,   normal stress differences, and metastability) upon   handling,   processing, production, and   performance of chemical products. Strategies to design   chemical   products that meet performance   targets, and to scale-up production. Real-world case   studies and   classroom demonstrations.
name: Non-Newtonian Fluids, Soft Materials and Chemical Products

desc: Methods of solution of partial differential equations and boundary value problems. Linear vector and function spaces, generalized fourier analysis, Sturm-Liouville theory, calculus of variations, and conformal mapping techniques.
name: Advanced Theoretical Methods in Engineering

desc: Following review of the theory of reaction kinetics for catalyzed and noncatalyzed systems, detailed consideration is given to design and performance of catalysts and chemical reactors. Mathematical studies of stability and optimization are emphasized in relationship to mass, energy, and momentum transport.
name: Advanced Chemical Reaction Engineering

desc: Seminars and workshops focusing on current research topics   and graduate student education.
name: Chemical Engineering Forum

desc: Students or instructors present recently published papers and/or results relevant to their own research.
name: Research Group Studies

desc: Special projects for selected students. Students pursue   practical engineering experience in selected industrial and   research firms, under faculty supervision.
name: Internship in Industry

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics

desc: Experimental or theoretical research undertaken under the direction of a faculty member for graduate students who have not yet advanced to candidacy.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Only for research underlying the thesis and writing the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Only for research underlying the dissertation and writing the disseration.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Introduction to the design and analysis of processes involving chemical   change in the context of chemical and biomolecular engineering. Students   learn mathematical, empirical, and conceptual strategies to analyze   chemical processes to assess product quality, economics, safety, and   environmental issues. Focus topics include an overview of chemical and   biomoleuclarengineering, evaluating and analyzing data, flowsheets,   material and energy balances, economics, and unit operations.
name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering Design

desc: Elementary principles and problem solving skills required   for   quantitative analysis of   chemical processes. Topics to be covered include   macroscopic   material and energy balances,   reaction stoichiometry, elementary thermodynamics, and   phase   equilibria associated with   chemical engineering processes and unit operations.
name: Material and Energy Balances
prequisites: Chemical Engineering 5 (may be taken concurrently); Chemistry 1A-B-C or   2A-B-C; Mathematics 3A-B and Mathematics 4A or 4AI; and Engineering 3;   Chemical Engineering majors only.

desc: Directed study, normally experimental, to be arranged with individual faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to participate in a research group.
name: Introduction to Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor and undergraduate advisor.

desc: Introductory course in conceptual understanding and   mathematical   analysis of   problems in fluid dynamics of relevance to Chemical   Engineering. Emphasis is   placed on performing microscopic and macroscopic   mathematical   analysis to   understand fluid motion in response to forces.
name: Transport Processes
prequisites: Chemical Engineering 10 with a minimum grade of C- (may be taken   concurrently); Mathematics 4B or 4BI; Mathematics 6A or 6AI and   Mathematics 6B.

desc: Overview of soft materials (suspensions, gels, polymers,   surfactants, emulsions, powders and granules) that arise in   diverse industries, includingconsumer products, foods,   advanced materials, biotechnology, and mineral and energy   production. Influence of non-Newtonian rheology (shear-  thickening and thinning, viscoelasticity, extension-  thickening, yield stresses, normal stress differences, and   metastability) upon handling, processing, production, and   performance of chemical products. Strategies to design chemical products that meet performance targets, and to   scale-up production. Real-world case studies and classroom   demonstrations.
name: Non-Newtonian Fluids, Soft Materials and Chemical Products

desc: Basic principles and design techniques of equilibrium-stage separation processes. Emphasis is placed on binary distillation, liquid-liquid extraction,and multicomponent distillation.
name: Separation Processes
prequisites: Chemical Engineering 10, and 110A-B; open to Engineering majors only.

desc: Develop analytical tools to solve elementary partial   differential   equations and   boundary value problems. Separation of variables, Laplace   transforms,   Sturm-  Liouville theory, generalized Fourier analysis, and   computer math tools.
name: Analytical Methods in Chemical Engineering

desc: Numerical methods for solution of linear and nonlinear   algebraic   equations,   optimization, interpolation, numerical integration and   differentiation,   initial-  value problems in ordinary and partial differential   equations, and   boundary-  value problems.  Emphasis on computational tools for   chemical   engineering   applications.
name: Computational Methods in Chemical Engineering
prequisites: Mathematics 4B or 4BI; Mathematics 6A or 6AI and Mathematics 6B.

desc: Thermodynamics, kinetics, mass and energy transport considerations   associated with complex homogeneous and heterogeneous reacting systems.   Catalysts and catalytic reaction rates and mechanisms. Adsorption and   reaction at solid surfaces, including effects of diffusion in porous materials.   Chemical reactors using heterogeneous catalysts.
name: Chemical Reaction Engineering

desc: Development of theoretical and empirical models for chemical and physical processes, dynamic behavior of processes, transfer function and block diagram representation, process instrumentation, control system design and analysis, stability analysis, computer simulation of controlled processes.
name: Process Dynamics and Control

desc: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students are expected togive regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and   prepare at least one written report on their research.
name: Undergraduate Research
prequisites: Upper-division standing, completion of 2 upper-division courses in ChemicalEngineering; consent of the instructor.

desc: Directed individual studies.
name: Independent Studies in Chemical Engineering
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chemical   Engineering.

desc: Presentation and critical discussion of topics in chemistry.
name: Seminar

desc: Selected topics: orbital symmetry rules for chemical reactions (Pearson); classical theory of light, radiation, and spectroscopy (Metiu); nonlinear optics and nonlinear spectroscopy (Metiu).
name: Selected Topics in Physical Chemistry

desc: Introduction to quantum mechanics-postulatory approach; particle in box, onring, harmonic oscillator; lineral operator theory, matrix algebra; hydrogen atom; perturbation theory, variation theory; applications.
name: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry
prequisites: Consent of the graduate advisor. Graduate standing.

desc: Faculty and students present and critically discuss current chemical literature.
name: Current Events in Organic Chemistry

desc: Structure determination of complex organic molecules. Topics include NMR, IR, UV, and mass spectrometry.
name: Organic Spectroscopic Analysis

desc: A survey of reactions of organic substances with emphasis on those with practical synthetic utility, including discussion of mechanism, scope and limitations, and stereochemical issues.
name: Synthetic Organic Reactions

desc: Macromolecules of biological importance. A survey of the physical and chemical properties of proteins, nucleic acids, and carbohydrates. Methods of preparation, chemical synthesis, degradation, and characterization of biomolecules.
name: Chemical Aspects of Biological Systems
prequisites: Open only by consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.

desc: Covers the arrow pushing fomulasism and addresses molecular   rearrangements and other organic reactions from this perspective.
name: Arrow Pushing in Organic Chemistry

desc: Electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Models for bonding in molecules of nontransition and transition elements. Applications of symmetry to bonding, electronic and vibrational spectroscopy. Stereochemistry of transition metal complexes and introduction to organo- metallics.
name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
prequisites: Consent of the chemistry graduate advisor.

desc: Discussion of chemical reaction mechanisms. Emphasis will be on fundamentalreactions of metal compounds such as substitution, addition, elimination, and redox reactions for homogenous catalysis mechanisms and other complex systems.
name: Raction Mechanisms in Organometallic and Inorganic Chemistry

desc: The use of x-ray and neutron scattering to characterize   solid state   materials. Subjects include the crystal unit cell, space   groups,   structuredetermination and refinement. It is recommended   that the   student have an elementary introduction to vectors,   matrices   and fourier   series.
name: Structural Inorganic Chemistry

desc: This course is designed to reflect recent developments in organic chemistry.
name: Selected Topics in Inorganic Chemistry

desc: Principles and practice of advanced research instrumentation for soft materials   characterization including spectroscopy, microscopy, and X-ray techniques
name: Instrumental Methods in Materials Chemistry

desc: Specialized seminar topics.
name: Special Seminar in Chemistry

desc: A series of seminars by departmental faculty describ ing their active research projects.
name: Faculty Research Seminar

desc: An initial two-thre day workshop is followed by weekly   discussion. Topicscovered: laboratory organization,   supervising experiments, safety, presentations, leading   discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and grading. Aimed at   new teaching assistants.
instructors: VAN KOPPEN P, BURATTO S K, LAVERMAN L E
name: Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision

desc: An initial two-three day workshop is followed by weekly discussion. Topics covered: laboratory organization, supervising experiments, safety, presentations,   leading discussions, writing quizzes, advising, and grading. Aimedat new   teaching assistants in Organic Chemistry.
instructors: BURATTO S K GAINER M J

timeslots.instructor: BURATTO S K GAINER M J

name: Organic Chemistry Techniques of Teaching and Laboratory Class Supervision

desc: Critical review of research in selected fields. Regular meetings are held in which the student presents for discussion information from the recent chemical literature.
name: Group Studies

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor is usually the student's major research advisor. Each faculty member has a unique number designation.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Instructor should be the student's major professor or chairman of the doctoral committee.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations.

desc: Only for research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis. Instructor should be the chairman of the student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Only for research underlying the dissertation, writing the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Stoichiometry, chemical reactions, gas laws, and kinetic theory, chemical equilibrium, and acid-base chemistry.
instructors: FELDWINN D L, KUNKEL B M, JOSEPH C A, PRICE S P, HARTMANN N J
name: General Chemistry

desc: The sequence of topics will be similar to that in Chemistry 1A. Calculus will be used as needed, at the level of the concurrent Mathematics 3A course.
name: General Chemistry (Honors)

desc: Distillation, crystallization, extraction, determination of   physical properties, spectroscopy, and instrumental methods in   organic chemistry.
name: Laboratory Methods of Organic Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 109A or 109AH with a minimum grade of a C-. Concurrent enrollmentin Chem 109B.

desc: Independent research involving distillation,   crystallization, extraction,determination of physical   properties, organic synthesis, and use of instrumental   methods in organic chemistry.
name: Laboratory Methods of Organic Chemistry (Independent   Research)
prequisites: Chemistry 6AL and 109A; and Chemistry 109B (may be taken concurrently);   open to chemistry, biochemistry and creative studies majors only; consent   of instructor.

desc: Independent research involving distillation,   crystallization, extraction,determination of physical   properties, organic synthesis, and use of instrumental   methods in organic chemistry for the purposes of multistep   synthesis.
name: Organic Chemistry Labs
prequisites: Chemistry 6BL and 109B; and Chemistry 109C (may be taken concurrently);   open to chemistry, biochemistry and creative studies majors only; consent   of instructor.

desc: Directed study, normally experimental, to be arranged with individual faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to participate in a research group. Basic techniques and the operation of instruments used in research. A few students in chemistry are quite advanced having had extensive laboratory training in high school or elsewhere. This course allows them the opportunity to participate in a research group before they acquire 84 units and are then eligible for and capable of handling 199, Independent Studies.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: Students will work to develop a high school/junior high   curriculum unit. In addition, students will work in either a   high school or junior high classroom and share their   experiences through class discussions. Students will also   have the opportunity to participate in one of two elementary   outreach programs that are run out of the chemistry   department.
name: Teaching Chemistry at the High School/Junior High Level

desc: Presentation and critical discussion of topics in chemistry.
name: Seminar

desc: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules   including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and   stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers,   carbohydrates, amino acids, proteins, nucleic acids,  coenzymes and their mechanisms.
instructors: BRUICE P Y, GAINER M J
name: Organic Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 1C or 2C with a minimum grade of C-; or Chemistry 1B or 2B with  a minimum grade of B-.

desc: Structure, nomenclature, stereochemistry, and reactivity of   organic molecules.  Suitable for undergraduates requiring   strong understanding of organic chemistry and possessing   strong background in science, such as honorsstudents,   majors in chemistry, biochemistry-chem, chemical   engineering,etc.  This course cannot be repeated.
name: Organic Chemistry (H)
prequisites: Chemistry 1B/2B or 1C/2C with a minimum grade of B.

desc: Structure, reactivity and synthesis of organic molecules   including nomenclature, reaction mechanisms, and   stereochemistry. Topics include organometallics, polymers,   carbohydrates, amino acides, proteins, nucleic acids, coenzymes and their mechanisms.
instructors: READ DE ALANI, AUE D H
name: Organic Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 109A or 109AH with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Gives students hands-on experience with modern methods of   separation, identification, and study of biomolecules and   macromolecular structures. Focus is on techniques but the   course also gives an introduction to computer-based   bioinformatics tools.
name: Introductory Biochemistry Laboratory
prequisites: Chemistry 142A or Chemistry W 142A (may be taken concurrently).

desc: The laws and theories governing rates of chemical reactions and reaction mechanisms. Empirical treatment of reaction rates, treatment of data, gas-phase reactions, reactions in solution, catalysis, complex reactions, chain reactions. Collision theory and potential energy surfaces.
name: Chemical Kinetics

desc: Laws of thermodynamics, chemical equilibria and ligand   binding, phase equilibria, electrochemistry, nonelectrolyte   solutions, applications to biochemical problems.
instructors: BROWN F L, YURASH B A BROWN F L, ELLIOTT W S BROWN F L

timeslots.instructor: YURASH B A BROWN F L
ELLIOTT W S BROWN F L
YURASH B A BROWN F L
ELLIOTT W S BROWN F L

name: Biophysical Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 1C or 2C; and, Mathematics 3A-B, 4A or 3C, and 6A or 5A; and,   Physics 1, 2, 3, 3L, 4, and   4L, or, Physics 6A-AL-B-BL-C-CL; Chemistry 142A, Chem W 142A or MCDB 108A   (may be taken   concurrently).

desc: Chemical thermodynamics: laws of thermodynamics, phase   equilibria, chemical equilibria, equations of state.
instructors: METIU H I, HAGGMARK M R METIU H I, BISHOP D METIU H I, BARNES R P METIU H I

timeslots.instructor: HAGGMARK M R METIU H I
HAGGMARK M R METIU H I
BARNES R P METIU H I

name: Physical Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 1C or 2C; and, Mathematics 3A-B, 4A or 3C, and 6A or 5A; and,   Physics 1-2-3-3L-4-4L, or, Physics 6A-AL-B-BL-C-CL.

desc: Introduction to quantum mechanics-postulatory approach; particle in box, onring, harmonic oscillator; linear operator theory, matrix algebra; hydrogenatom;   perturbation theory, variation theory; applications.
instructors: KIRTMAN B, LEAVESLEY A A KIRTMAN B
name: Fundamentals of Quantum Chemistry

desc: Synthesis of inorganic and organometallic complexes   including techniques for air-sensitive materials.   Instrumental characterization and study of synthesized   compounds in a research-like setting.
name: Inorganic Synthesis and Physical Characterization   Laboratory
prequisites: Chemistry 113C and 116BL; Chemistry 173A (may be taken concurrently).

desc: Structure determination of complex organic molecules. Topics covered include NMR, IR, UV, and mass spectrometry.
name: Organic Spectroscopic Analysis

desc: A survey of reactions of organic substances with emphasis on those with practical synthetic utility, including discussion of mechanism, scope and limitations, and steriochemical issues.
name: Synthetic Organic Reactions

desc: Macromolecules of biological importance. A survey of the   physical and chemical properties of proteins, nucleic   acids, and carbohydrates. Methods of preparation, chemical   synthesis, degradation, and characterization of  biomolecules.
instructors: REICH N O YUN J H, KAHN K

timeslots.instructor: REICH N O YUN J H

name: Biochemistry

desc: Principles of analytical chemistry including classical techniques, spectrophotochemistry, electroanalytical techniques, and separation processes.
name: Analytical Chemistry

desc: Covers the arrow pushing formalism and addresses organic   reactions from this perspective.
name: Arrow Pushing in Organic Chemistry
prequisites: Chemistry 109A-B-C; upper-division standing; open to chemistry and   biochemistry majors only.

desc: Electronic structure of atoms and molecules. Models for   bonding in molecules of   nontransition and transition elements. Applications of   symmetry to bonding,   electronic and vibrational spectroscopy. Stereochemistry   oftransition metal   complexes and introduction to organometallics.
instructors: HAYTON T W, COOK A W HAYTON T W, MENARD G, HUNT C C MENARD G

timeslots.instructor: COOK A W HAYTON T W
COOK A W HAYTON T W

name: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry

desc: Students will assist instructor in teaching a lab course in which the student previously received a grade of A- or better. Activities will be determined in consultation with the instructor and include instruction of 1 or 2 lab sections per week, hold 1 office hour per week, prepare weekly quizzes and lab lectures, grade weekly lab reports and quizzes, conduct one review session for the lab final, maintain/submit student grade records, complete video tape   teaching evaluation and consultation with instructional development, complete mid-quarter and end of quarter teaching evaluations, grade and proctor exams.
name: Introduction to Teaching in Chemistry
prequisites: Upper-division standing, a chemistry grade point average of 3.5 or above and consent of instructor.

desc: Independent research project carried out under the supervision of faculty member. Goal is to write an original, publishable, research paper. The project can be on a topic of the student's choice, or it can be an extension of an ongoing research project under the direction of a faculty member in the department.
name: Honors Research Seminar
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Opportunity to obtain practical non paid chemistry-related   research and work experience by working under faculty   and/or staff direction as   an intern.
instructors: REICH N O, FELDWINN D L
name: Internship in Chemistry
prequisites: Chem 1AL, 1BL, 1CL, and consent of Chem instructor.

desc: Coursework shall consist of research in chemical education   supervised by a faculty member. This course is not intended   for internship credit.
name: Research in Chemical Education
prequisites: Upper-division standing in a physical science, life science, or   engineering major

desc: Coursework shall consist of academic research supervised by   a faculty member. This course is not intended for   internship credit.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing in the major; completion of two upper division   courses in chemistry.

desc: Supervised teaching of lower division Chicana/o Studies courses. Required participation in occasional workshops related to teaching.
name: Teaching Assistant and Assocatie Training

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics

desc: An independent research or individually guided tutorial in an area not covered by existing courses.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Normally taken with the student’s committee chair in preparation for Master’s or Ph.D. examinations. Units do not count toward graduate degrees.
name: Individual Study for Master's or Ph.D. Examinations for Advancement to Candidacy

desc: Open to graduate students conduction master’s research.
name: Master's Research and Writing

desc: Open to graduate students conducting doctoral research.
name: Dissertation Research and Writing
prequisites: Open to graduate students conducting doctoral thesis research.

desc: Introduction to the historical and contemporary development of the Chicano/a community. Course is interdisciplinary in nature. Focuses by quarter on A. history, B. gender, and C. culture.
instructors: VILLA ELIZA, FUENTES CARRE, WASHINGTON C, LATANYSHYN S, JARAMILLO N, ARAGON M J, TAGHAVI I, GOMEZ J M, LEE K H
name: Introduction to Chicano/a Studies

desc: Designed to allow courses of varying topics in areas of expertise of visiting professors to broaden opportunities for students. Examples might be: immigration, Native American, Mexican, or Latin American influences on the Chicano, legal issues, the migrants.
name: Special Topics in Chicano Studies

desc: Independent study under the guidance of a faculty member in the department.Course offers students the opportunity to undertake independent study or work in a group.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Examines Critical Race Theory (CRT) as an emerging analytical framework in the field of education. Course investigates how a CRT framework might address and challenge the impacts of race, class, gender, language, immigrant status, accent, and sexual orientation on Chicana/o, Latina/o educational attainment and achievement.
name: Critical Race Theory in Chicana/o Education

desc: Explores various manifestations of popular and mass culture in Chicano urban and semi-rural communities throughout the Southwest. Both secular and religious cultural phenomena are analyzed (lowriders, saints, music, etc.). Relationships to mainstream culture is examined.
name: Barrio Popular Culture

desc: An overview of contemporary Chicana art and feminist theory from the late 1960s to the present placed within the context of the Chicano movement and other historical events.
name: Chicana Art and Feminism
prequisites: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.

desc: Spoken wor(ld) art performance activism (SWAPA) introduces students to a method for reading, writing, thinking, and performing before an audience of peers. This method is based on the shaman-witness ritual proposed by Chicanatheorist and writer, Gloria Anzaldua.
name: Spoken Word Art Performance Activism (SWAPA)
prequisites: Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C; a previous upper-division course in ChicanoStudies.

desc: Accompanies Spoken Word Art Performance Activism (SWAPA) course. Focuses oncreative production, atriculation, and vocal expression.
name: Spoken Word Art Performance (SWAPA) Lab

desc: Racism in American History. This course will examine racism as a major ideological   force in defining American society from the colonial era to the 1980s. Major focus   will be on the   changing nature of racism as an ideology as well as the   relationship of racism to specific minority groups suchas   Afro-American, Native American, Chicanos,and Asian-American.
instructors: ARMBRUSTER R, PACHECO F, PATNETT T L
name: Racism in American History
prequisites: History 17A or 17B or 17C or Chicano Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or Asian   AmericStudies 1 or 2 or Black Studies 1 or 2 or 5 or 6 or 20.

desc: Survey of recent state and federal laws and court decisions affecting the Chicano community. Special consideration is given to landmark cases and decisions. Analysis of opposing views on each case in a historical context.
name: Law and Civil Rights
prequisites: Chicana/o Studies 1A or 1B or 1C or upper-division standing.

desc: Examination of literary works by Chicana writers. Feminist theories as wellas other contemporary critical theories are applied to the analysis of prose, poetry and dramatic works written by such authors as Sandra Cisneros, Ana Castillo, Helen Viramontes, and others.
name: Chicana Writers
prequisites: Department approval required to finalize registration.

desc: Internship in contemporary urban problems and decision-making   processes as they affect the Chicana/o community. Student   individually assigned, instructed and supervised in fieldwork   involving practical experience in decision-making unit of   local agencies serving Latina/o,Chicana/o communities.
name: Community Studies and Outreach Initiatives

desc: Seminar for the development of the honors research project. Emphasis is on the design of the project and the establishment of methodologies to be utilized. Background and initial research is undertaken.
name: Honors Project Seminar
prequisites: Acceptance into the Chicana and Chicano Studies honors program; senior standing; consent of department; open to Chicana and Chicano Studies majors only.

desc: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Chicana/o Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chicana/o Studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: An introductory survey of visual culture, encompassing art   and film theory and practice, digital technologies,   television, advertising and print media, with a special focus   on current interdisciplinary methodologies.
name: Visual Literacy

desc: The study of visual perception and image-making across visual art disciplines, both material and digital. Studio assignments are combined with relatedcritical theory, historical practice, current strategies, and new evolutions.
instructors: MORRISON A G, LUGRIS J, MATTES K A
name: Introduction to Contemporary Practice I: Image Studies

desc: Students receiving credit will present talks in their field on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.
name: Art Colloquium

desc: Examines photography as a means of artistic expression.   Conceptually-based projects explore how we view, interpret,   and manipulate visual information. Lectures cover major   historical and contemporary artists. Lab work in digital   format.
name: Lower-Division Photography

desc: Emphasis on the practice and development of making paintings and drawings.
name: Drawing and Painting

desc: Drawing and painting in sequences, and according to themes.
instructors: CONNALLY D E, BRICCETTI R E
name: Themes

desc: The study and practice of the book arts; artists' books; typography;   letterpress printing; both traditional and experimental uses of the   printing press.
name: Book Arts

desc: Designed to develop student knowledge and proficiency of material and   method, cultivating both manual and conceptual skill-levels in three-  dimensional practices. Course focus varies by quarter, but includes a   variety ofapproaches to materials and concepts in Public Practice.
name: Intermediate Spatial Practices - Public Practice
prequisites: Art 12; 1A or 7C or Upper Division or Instructor Approval

desc: Non-studio emphasis on historical, theoretical, and contemporary ideas and issues. A range of concepts will be discussed, from various approaches,according to the particular interests of faculty and students.
name: History, Theory, and Criticism

desc: This special studies course allows faculty to design and execute courses that reflect their particular research and teaching.
name: Special Topics

desc: This internship provides pedagogical and practical support for students   exhibiting work within the Arts Building and other venues across campus   such as Cheadle Hall and the University Library. Among other skills,   the course will include intensive training in exhibition scheduling and   curating, installation and display, the production of didactic   supplements such as information sheets, wall texts and titles, methods   of promotion as well as de-installation and art handling.
name: Exhibition Studies Internship

desc: Opportunities in applied learning related to visual art   through local museums, art galleries, and other art related   organizations or institutions.Students work under the   direction of the faculty sponsor who maintains contact with   the supervisor for whom the student is interning.
name: Internship in Art

desc: Seminar designed to focus on criticism of current art work.   A total of 12units in this course required to complete   honors program. Completion of seminar units followed by   public exhibition of work accomplished.
name: Honors Seminar
prequisites: L&S and CCS Art majors only; upper-division standing; acceptance into   department honors program.

desc: Independent studies. Advanced independent or collaborative   work in consultation with individual faculty; individual   tutorial.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in Art;  consent of instructor and department required.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Art
prequisites: Upper-division students only; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Course will center on readings of Chinese texts; type and period to depend on needs of students and wishes of instructor. Research methods to be taught as appropriate.
name: Readings in Selected Texts
prequisites: Ability to read Chinese at graduate level; consent of instructor.

desc: Early Mandarin as represented in selections from vernacular Chinese fictionof the sixteenth through eighteenth centuries. Primarily concerned with thesyntactical and semantic features employed in the reading selections but will also consider the issue of literary expression.
name: The Language of Vernacular Chinese Literature

desc: Selected readings from important Taoist texts.  Depending on   the year, primary sources will be read in original Chinese or   in translation.
name: Readings in Taoism

desc: Apprentice teaching. This course consists of supervised teaching practice in Chinese language.
name: Apprentice Teaching
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor. Employment in this department teaching assistant or linguistic informant.

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by department chair and filed with graduate division.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Study for master's comprehensive examinations and Ph.D examinations.
name: Preparation for Comprehensive Examinations

desc: Instructor should be chair of the student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Terminal preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: The beginning course in Chinese. The student acquires a basic knowledge of the grammar, a limited general vocabulary, correct pronunciation, and an ability to read and understand simple texts. Weekly laboratory assignments support and enhance classroom learning.
name: Elementary Modern Chinese

desc: Intended for Chinese heritage speakers who wish to learn to read and write Chinese. Content is similar to Chinese 1 with less emphasis on developing oral skills.
name: First Year Chinese Heritage

desc: Continuation of Chinese 3.
name: Intermediate Modern Chinese

desc: Continuation of Chinese 3NH.
name: Second Year Chinese Heritage

desc: The course is designed to increase facility and naturalness   of delivery in simple dialogue. This course is designed for   the students who have finished first year Chinese.
name: Chinese Conversation

desc: Provides basic introduction to the historical background   and major writers of Taiwan literature in its development   since the 19th century. Topics:sociopolitical and cultural   changes, literary trends and writing characteristics from   the Japanese colonial period to the present.
name: Introduction to Taiwan Literature

desc: Introduction to independent research in Chinese.  Topic and content are decided   by the supervising Professor in   the Department of East Asian Languages and Cultural Studies.
name: Independent Study in Chinese

desc: Advanced practice in grammar and composition.
name: Advanced Modern Chinese

desc: A selection of texts in Chinese by representative authors; literature during the Japanese rule (1895-1945). Designed for advanced students to gain an overall view of achievements of major writers in different genres.
name: Advanced Readings in Taiwan Literature

desc: Course series for students who have completed third year Chinese. Extensivereading and discussion of colloquial versus formal usage of Chinese are themajor focus of the course.
name: Fourth Year Chinese

desc: Early Mandarin as represented in selections from vernacular Chinese fictionof the 16th through 18th centuries. Primarily concerned with the syntactical and semantic features employed in the reading selections. Also considers the issue of literary expression.
name: The Language of Vernacular Chinese Literature

desc: An independent study course (1 to 3 quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in a documented project or a senior thesis.
name: Senior Honors Project
prequisites: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.

desc: Readings in Chinese.
name: Readings in Chinese
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chinese.

desc: Independent studies in Chinese. Individual investigations in   literary fields.
name: Independent Studies in Chinese
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Chinese major; Minimum major GPA of 3.5 or higher

desc: A graduate-level course in Greek and Roman authors, themes, or genres. Topics vary and may include, Aristotle's De Anima, construction of gender in Augustan poetry, texts and intertexts, and Roman tragedy.
name: Seminar in Literary Studies

desc: Weekly discussions, directed by faculty, of topics especially relevant for teaching assistants assigned to Classics 40 (Greek Mythology). Includes analyses of texts and materials, discussion of teaching techniques, formulation of exam questions and paper topics, grading, and pedagogical ethics.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Weekly discussions, directed by faculty, of topics relevant for graduate students assigned to introductory language courses. Includes design of syllabi, quizzes and exams, and especially discussion of teaching techniques and evaluation of teaching methods by observation and follow-up consultations.
name: Language Teaching Practicum

desc: Study for master's examinations and Ph.D. examinations.
name: Preparation for Comprehensive Exams
prequisites: Consent of graduate advisor and chair.

desc: Independent research.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Ph.D. dissertation presentation. Preparation of the dissertation.

An introduction to the literature and culture of ancient Greece. The study of literary and material remains will illustrate how the Greeks lived and the values they expressed through literature and the arts. Topics may include the rituals and festivals of Greek religion, the conflict between heroic ideals and democratic ideology, the institutions that shaped public and private life, and the competitive nature of law, drama, athletics and politics.
name: The Ancient Greeks

desc: A study of the Iliad, the Odyssey, the Aeneid and other   ancient epics, and of the place of these works in Greek and   Roman society. The course explores how the epic hero   embodies a culture’s ideals concerning the individual, the   community, and the universe.
name: The World of Heroes

desc: A discussion section led by the instructor, provided for   students in the honors program. Students receive one unit   for the honors seminar (36H) inaddition to four units for   Classics 36.
name: World of Heroes - Honors
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Classics 36; consent of instructor.

desc: Introduction to the principal myths of ancient Greece and the ways in whichthese myths have been understood. Format and readings vary.
instructors: RICK E P, JAQUA K M, SEET A M, GOODMAN G N, ARALERE T S, FACCANI O, COLLINS B D, NESBIT D M, TAYNTON N E
name: Greek Mythology

desc: A discussion section led by the professor is available to students in the honors program. Students will receive one unit for the honors seminar (40H) in addition to four units for Classics 40.
name: Greek Mythology--Honors
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Classics 40 and consent of instructor.

desc: Examines the techniques and methods of classical archaeology as revealed through an examination of the major monuments and artifacts of the Greco-Roman world from prehistory to the Late Empire.
name: Introduction to Classical Archaeology

desc: Directed study, oriented toward research, to be arranged with individual faculty members. Course offers exceptional students an opportunity to participate in a research project or group.
name: Introduction To Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair.

desc: The romance, from Homer's Odyssey to the contemporary romance novel, creates images of masculinity and femininity. This course considers these gender representations and questions whether they vary among ancient novels, and between the romances of antiquity and those of today.
name: From Homer To Harlequin: Masculine, Feminine And The Romance

desc: Individual or small group reading and study in subjects not included in theregular curriculum.
name: Special Readings.
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Classics.

desc: Independent study in areas in which both Greek and Latin are necessary.
name: Independent Studies In Greek And Latin.
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Classics.

desc: To cooperate on an active basis with a professor on a research project involving the Classics.
name: Independent Research Assistant.
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Classicsconsent of instructor and department.

desc: A survey of research methods in the social sciences   applicable to communication research.
name: Research Methods in Communication

desc: An introduction to evolutionary psychology and costly   signaling approaches to the   evolution of human communication. Topics include but are   not limited to: language, gossip,   pathogen avoidance, deception, laughter, norms,   aggression, hierarchies, mating,   prejudice, and coalitional behavior. The goal is to   enable students versed in the standard   social sciencemodel to apply evolutionary thinking to   their areas of interest.
name: Evolution and Human Communication

desc: The study of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) is   burgeoning as CSR is being   rapidly transformed from a vision championed by a small   number of companies to a   widespread global movement that engages corporations,  non-governmental and   governmental organizations, activists, and civil society.   Explores how contemporary   environmental, economic, social, and technological   changes influence CSR and are   affected by interpersonal, stakeholder, organizational,   inter-organizational and   media communicationdynamics.
name: Corporate Social Responsibility: A Communication   Perspective

desc: Theory of teaching communication at the college level. Topics include self-presentation, facilitating discussion, constructing examinations, grading examinations and term papers, providing feedback, and professionalism.
name: Teaching College Communication

desc: Presentation of research completed or in progress by students, faculty and guest speakers followed by critical discussion of the issues raised.
name: Issues in Communication Research

desc: Individual tutorial. Provides students with the same material as a regular course except it is conducted on an individual basis with a faculty member.Written contract describing the course, readings, and assignments should besubmitted to the departmental graduate adviser.
name: Directed Reading

desc: Individual tutorial. Provides students with supervised research experience including any of the following: reviewing literature, formulating research questions, designing measures, collecting and analyzing data, and writing papers. Written proposal must be approved by the departmental graduate advisor.
name: Directed Research

desc: Directed group or individual preparation for the master's or doctoral qualifying examination.
name: Preparation for the Qualifying Examination
prequisites: Consent of graduate advisor; graduate standing.

desc: The thesis is done under the direction of the chair of a student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of thesis advisor; graduate standing.

desc: Course is reserved for writing the dissertation.
name: Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of department; advancement to candidacy.

desc: Survey of basic concepts, principles, and models of communication. Introduction to the importance of communication in intrapersonal, interpersonal, small group,   organizational, and mass media contexts.
instructors: OSHIDARY N S, MENDEZ MURILL, YANG YOORI, PINES R L, STAMPS D L, CORNEJO M C
name: Introduction to Communication

desc: An introduction to basic statistical concepts and   applications in communication. Through lecture and computer   labs, students will be exposed to statistical applications   for advanced coursework in the major.
name: Statistical Analysis for Communication

desc: An introduction to social scientific research designs used in the field of communication, including survey research, experimental design, content analysis, and field research. The course serves as preparation for advanced coursework in communication.
instructors: HANSIA M S, AUNE A K, KIRKWOOD G L, HOPP F R, LONERGAN C A
name: Communication Research Methods

desc: An introduction to major theories and theoretical influences in the field of   communication, in the areas of interpersonal, small group, organizational, and   mass communication.
instructors: MOXLEY C M, ZAMANZADEH N, HANSIA A D, HARRISON K E, WHITESTONE S
name: Theories of Communication

desc: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Communication
prequisites: Open to Communication and Pre-Communication Majors only. Students must   have taken at least one Communication course from UCSB in order to   enroll.

desc: An opportunity for pre-communication and communication   majors to obtain credit for career-related experience and   application of academic training in a communication-  related   internship. Required are 50 hours minimum ofinternship   work, a final five-page report, and a supervisor's letter   ofverification.
name: Communication Internship
prequisites: Must be declared as pre-communication or communication major. Students   must have 2.0 cumulative GPA.

desc: Independent studies in communication.
name: Independent Studies in Communication
prequisites: Upper-division standing; open to communication majors only.

desc: Coursework consists of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Communication
prequisites: Upper-division standing; Open to Communication majors only.

desc: Addresses issues of methodology and literary theory. Specific authors and topics vary from class to class.
name: Seminar in Comparative Literature

desc: Examination of translation and the canon, questioning the hierarchical division between translation and original, illustrating the concept of the original as translation and the literary text as "work-in-progress" in which translation forms part of the creative process.
name: Literary Translation: Theory and Practice

desc: Supervised teaching of lower-division comparative literature courses at UCSB. Participation in occasional workshops related to the field of teaching will be required.
instructors: LARUE R J, AKUDINOBI J, REYNOLDS D F
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Focus on presentations at scholarly meetings and writing   for publication in scholarly journals in comparative/world   literature. Individualized meetings or small-group workshop   format.
name: Academic Presentation and Writing in World Literature

desc: Seminar provides support for graduate students when   developing their dissertation prospectus and focuses on   research in the literary humanities ata practical level.
name: Doctoral Colloquium

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the program chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Minimum of two units per quarter. Letter grade only.

desc: Individual reading and research. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the faculty emphasis adviser.
name: Translation Studies Independent Studies
prequisites: Comparative Literature 260 or approval of the emphasis adviser.

desc: For individual study with major professor or chair or director of student'sprogram.
name: Individual study for M.A. Comprehensive and Ph.D. Exams

desc: For research and writing of the master's thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: For research and writing of the doctoral dissertation. Instructor should bechair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: A survey of European literature. Renaissance and Neoclassical   literature from Petrarch to Diderot.
instructors: LARUE R J, KEYNEJAD N P, D'ANCA C, FELDMAN R H, STEWART R L, FESTA E, BELLOMI J J, THOMSEN S S
name: Major Works in European Literature

desc: Seminar course for honors students enrolled in Comparative Literature 30 designed to enrich the large lecture experience and to supplement the weekly seminar meetings. May include additional readings, more intensive study of syllabus selections, and supplemental writings.
name: Honors Section

desc: An introduction to the diverse literary traditions of the Middle East through an examination of selected works. Regional focus on North Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia varies.
instructors: REYNOLDS D F, HAMAD S, ABURQAYEQ G M, RAGHEB N J
name: Major Works of Middle Eastern Literatures

desc: An introduction to the diverse literary traditions of Africa through an examination of selected works. Regional focus on North, West, East, Central, and South Africa varies.
instructors: AKUDINOBI J, MAGEARU A, GARCIA A M
name: Major Works of African Literatures

desc: Focus on various practices and methodologies of Comparative   Literature asa cross-disciplinary and transnational   endeavor, including recent developments and debates on   translation studies and world literature in an era of   cultural globalization. Content will vary with instructor.
name: Introduction to Comparative Literature

desc: Focus on the idea of heroes and heroism in the Western tradition through readings of the three major epics of Greek and Latin Antiquity (the Iliad, the Odyssey, and the Aeneid), along with selections from modern variations onthese old stories.
name: What is a Hero?

desc: Examines globalizing cultural politics of sexuality through   literature, popular media, subaltern performances, and press   discourse from Global South; engages questions of   "universalized" LGBTQ identities, Islamic law and sexual   rights, militarized masculinities, recognition of  transexualities, and queer, anti-racist and feminist   globalisms.
name: Sexuality and Globalization

desc: The course aims to develop skills in terminology and technologies of translation;   it also examines the practical and theoretical issues pertaining to translation as   an artistic, cultural, and ethical process. Focus on literary translation as   creative research and practice.
name: The Art of Translation
prequisites: Upper-division standing; and completion of quarter 5 or equivalent of the language of study.

desc: Telegraph, telephone, phonograph, and film are techniques that have engendered new forms of representation, communication, and thinking. Course studies the impact of these transformations in literature and on literature. Taught in English.
name: Mediatechnology

desc: The generic forms of cultural issues characteristic of   early modern European poetry, fiction, and drama. Such   authors as Petrarch, Boccaccio, More, Rabelais, Ariosto,   Montaigne, Camoes, Shakespeare, Lope de Vega, and   Cervantes.
name: The European Renaissance
prequisites: Writing 2 and 50; or Writing 109AA-ZZ or English 10.

desc: Poetry & Community Practice honors a connection between poetry and   citizenship, assuming that poetry is a wisdom medium or vehicle toward   more enlightened thinking and public practice. Poetry is an ideal medium   for extending our study and practice beyond UCSB, and students will   conduct workshops in schools, community centers, and assisted living   facilities as part of their work for the course. Students will extend   their own learning through teaching—a natural stretch—while also being of   benefit elsewhere.
name: Poetry & Community Practice

desc: Individualized instruction to complete the capstone   translation project for the Minor in Translation Studies.   To be completed with the faculty advisor from the language   department of the student's focus.
name: Research in Translation Studies

desc: Student engages in research leading to a paper of considerable depth and complexity on a topic dealing with the literature of the student's focus.
name: Senior Honors Independent Research

desc: Independent studies with any faculty member. To permit study   of a subjectdesired by the student but not covered in course   offerings.
name: Independent Studies in Comparative Literature
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in   Comparative Literature.

desc: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.
name: Matrix Analysis and Computation

desc: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptical partial differential equations, with applicationto problems in science and engineering. Error Estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.
name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Element Methods

desc: Interdisciplinary introduction to applied parallel computing on modern supercomputers. Topics include applications-oriented architectural issues, MPI,parallel MATLAB, and parallel numerical algorithms. A course project emphasizes understanding the realities and myths of what is possible on the world's fastest machines.
name: Applied Parallel Computing

desc: Develops an understanding of operating systems and operating systems research at both a conceptual level and from an engineering perspective.  Fundamental design principles, culled primarily from the research literature, motivate an analysis of previous and current systems.  This analysis is furthervalidated through empirical investigation.
name: Operating Systems

desc: Covers the fundamental problems in distributed systems and the various tools used to solve them. Of primary interest is the issue of fault-tolerance. Topics include event ordering, clocks, global states, agreement, fault-tolerance, and peer-to-peer systems.
name: Advanced Topics in Distributed Systems

desc: Security analysis of networked systems. Analysis of techniques for network scanning, spoofing, hijacking, and denial-of-service attacks.  Vulnerability analysis of applications and web-based systems.  Intrusion detection and prevention techniques.
name: Advanced Topics in Security

desc: These courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer   science foundations.
name: Special Topics in Computer Science, Foundations, General

desc: An initial 1-2 day workshop on teaching techniques followed by a weekly seminar. Course emphasizes teaching skills, practical experience, and communication skills.
name: Techniques of Computer Science Teaching

desc: Procedures and techniques for teaching computer science gained through actual teaching of lecture courses, leading discussion sections, and/or teaching laboratories. Meetings will be held as needed to discuss problems,methods, and procedures.
name: Teaching of Computer Science

desc: A series of weekly lectures given by university staff and outside experts in the fields of control systems, dynamical systems, and computation.
name: Group Studies: Controls, Dynamical Systems, and Computation

desc: Individual studies exploring topics in computer science with a faculty advisor.
name: Computer Science Graduate Tutorial
prequisites: Consent of instructor or department chair.

desc: Special seminars focusing on topics of interest to faculty and   graduate students. These seminars provide critical review of   research in various areas of computer science.
name: Group Studies in Computer Science: Security

desc: Special seminars focusing on topics of interest to faculty and   graduate students. These seminars provide critical review of   research in various areas of computer science.
name: Group Studies in Computer Science: Intelligent and Interactive   Systems

desc: Instruction in these variable unit courses may be carried out   by lecture,or by laboratory, or by a combination of the two.   These courses provide critical review of research in various   areas of computer science.
name: Group Studies in Computer Science: General

desc: Research, either experimental or theoretical, may be   undertaken by properly   qualified graduate students under the direction of a   faculty member.
name: Directed Research

desc: Individual studies for M.S. comprehensive examination and Ph.D.
name: Individual Studies for Master of Science Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D Examinations

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Research and preparation of dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of chair of student's doctoral committee.

desc: Introduction to computer program development for students with little to noprogramming experience. Basic programming concepts, variables and   expressions, data and control structures, algorithms, debugging, program   design,and documentation.
name: Introduction to Computer Science

desc: Fundamental building blocks for solving problems using computers. Topics   include basic   computer organization and programming constructs:  memory CPU, binary   arithmetic, variables, expressions, statements, conditionals, iteration,   functions, parameters,   recursion, primitive and composite data types, and basic operating system   and debugging   tools.
name: Problem Solving with Computers I
prequisites: Mathematics 3A with a grade of C or better (may be taken concurrently), CS 8   or Engineering 3 with a grade of C or better, or significant prior programming experience.

desc: Intermediate building blocks for solving problems using   computers. Topicsinclude intermediate object-oriented programming, data   structures, object-  oriented design, algorithms for manipulating these data   structures andtheir   run-time analyses. Data structures introduced include   stacks, queues, lists,   trees,   and sets.
name: Problem Solving with Computers II
prequisites: Computer Science 16 with a grade of C or better; and Mathematics 3B with   a grade of C or better (may be taken concurrently).

desc: Advanced topics in object-oriented computing.  Topics include encapsulation,   data hiding, inheritance, polymorphism, compilation, linking and loading,   memory management, and debugging; recent advances in design and   development tools, practices, libraries, and operating system support.
name: Object Oriented Design and Implementation
prequisites: Computer Science 24 with a grade of C or better

desc: Introduction to the theoretical underpinnings of computer   science. Topicsinclude propositional predicate logic,   set theory,   functions   and relations, counting, mathematical induction and   recursion   (generating   functions).
name: Foundations of Computer Science
prequisites: Computer Science 16 with a grade of C or better and Mathematics 4A with a  grade of C or better.

desc: Advanced application programming using a high-level,   virtual-machine-based language.  Topics include generic   programming, exception handling, programming language   implementation; automatic memory management, and application   development, management, and maintenance tools; event   handling, concurrency and threading, and advanced library   use.
name: Advanced Applications Programming
prequisites: Computer Science 24 and 32 with a grade of C or better

desc: Independent studies in computer science for advanced students.
name: Independent Studies in Computer Science

desc: Introduction to computational science, emphasizing basic numerical algorithms and the informed use of mathematical software. Matrix computation, systems of linear and nonlinear equations, interpolation and zero finding, differential equations, numerical integration. Students learn and use the Matlablanguage.
name: Introduction to Computational Science
prequisites: Mathematics 5A or 4B with a grade of C or better; Mathematics 5B or 6A witha grade of C or better;   Computer Science 24 with a grade of C or better.

desc: The study of data structures and their applications. Correctness   proofs and techniques for   the design of correct programs. Internal and external searching.   Hashing and height balanced   trees. Analysis of sorting algorithms. Memory management. Graph   traversal techniques and   their applications.
name: Data Structures and Algorithms I
prequisites: Computer Science 40 with a grade of C or better; Computer Science 32 with agrade of C   or better; PSTAT 120A or ECE 139; open to computer science, computer engineering,   and electrical engineering majors only.

desc: Design and analysis of computer algorithms. Correctness proofs and solutionof   recurrance relations. Design techniques; divide and conquer, greedy strategies,   dynamic programming, branch and bound, backtracking, and local search.   Applications of techniques to problems from several disciplines. NP -   completeness.
name: Data Structures and Algorithms II

desc: Formal languages; finite automata and regular expressions; properties of regular   languages; pushdown automata and   context-free grammars; properties of context-free languages;   introduction to Turing machines and computability.
name: Automata and Formal Languages
prequisites: Computer Science 40 with a grade of C or better; open to Computer Science and   Computer Engineering majors only.

desc: Issues in interfacing computing systems and software to practical I/O interfaces.   Rapid response, real-time events and management of tasks, threads,and   scheduling required for efficient design of embedded software and systems is   discussed. Techniques for highly constrained systems.
name: Hardware/Software Interface
prequisites: Upper division standing in Computer Science, Computer Engineering or Electrical Engineering.

desc: Study of the structure of compilers. Topics include: lexical   analysis; syntax analysis including LL and LR parsers; type   checking; run-time environments; intermediate code generation;   and compiler-construction tools.
name: Translation of Programming Languages
prequisites: Computer Science 64 or Electrical Engineering 154 or Electrical   Engineering 154A; Computer Science 130A; and Computer Science 138; open   to computer science and computer engineering majors only.

desc: Database system architectures, relational data model, relational algebra,  relational calculus, SQL, QBE, query processing, integrity constraints (keyconstraints, referential integrity), database design, ER and object- oriented data   model, functional dependence, lossless join and dependency preserving   decompositions, Boyce-Codd and Third Normal Forms.
name: Fundamentals of Database Systems

desc: Basic concepts in networking, the OSI model, error   detection codes, flow control, routing, medium access control, and high-speed   networks.
name: Introduction to Computer Communication Networks
prequisites: CMPSC 32 with a grade of C or better; PSTAT 120A or ECE 139; open to computer science, electrical   engineering, and computer engineering majors only.

desc: Introduction to the basics of computer security and privacy. Analysis of technical difficulties of producing secure computer information systems that provide guaranteed controlled sharing. Examination and critique of current systems, methods, certification.
name: Computer Security

desc: Overview of OpenGL graphics standard,   OpenGL state  machine, other 3D graphics libraries, 3D   graphics  pipeline, 3D transformations and clipping, color  model, shading model, shadow algorithms,   texturing,  curves and curved surfaces, graphics   hardware,  interaction devices and techniques
name: Computer Graphics
prequisites: Computer Science 130A or consent of instructor.

desc: An introduction to programming mobile computing devices.   Students   will learn about and study the shift   in software development from desktop to mobile device   applications.   Topics will include software   engineering and design practices, advances in programming   practice, and support tools for mobile   application development and testing. Students will   develop and   deploy mobile applications as part of   their course work.
name: Mobile Application Development

desc: Student groups design a significant computer-based project.   Multiple groups may cooperate toward one large project. Each   group works independently; interaction among groups is via   interface specifications and informal meetings.   Project for follow-up course may be different.
name: Senior Computer Systems Project
prequisites: Computer Science 56; Senior standing in computer engineering, computer   science, or electrical engineering; consent of instructor.

desc: These variable unit courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science.
name: Special Topics in Computer Science: Information Management

desc: These variable unit courses provide for the study of topics of current interest in computer science.
name: Special Topics in Computer Science: General

desc: Projects in computer science for advanced undergraduate   students.
name: Projects in Computer Science

desc: Special projects for selected students. Offered in conjunction with selected industrial and research firms and under direct faculty supervision. Written proposal and final report required.
name: Internship in Industry
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair.

desc: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. Students will be expected to giveregular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
name: Undergraduate Research
prequisites: Students must: (1) have attained upper-division standing (2) have a minimum3.0 grade-point average for preceding three quarters, (3) have consent of instructor.

desc: Independent studies in computer science for advanced students.
name: Independent Studies in Computer Science
prequisites: Upper-division standing; students must have completed at least two upper-  division courses in computer science. May be repeated with consent of chair.

desc: Introduction to computer science, programming, algorithms   and data structures.
instructors: CONRAD P T, WANG R K
name: Computer Programming and Organization I

desc: Laboratory offering hands on Unix and other operating   system experience. Small to large scale software   development projects.
name: Programming Laboratory
prequisites: Consent of instructor. Concurrent enrollment in Creative Studies-Computer  Science 1A or 1B.

desc: Mathematical foundations of computer science, including   sets, relations, functions, logic and combinatorics.
name: Foundations of Computer Science

desc: Introduction to computer science, programming, algorithms   and data structures.
name: Computer Programming and Organization I

desc: Laboratory offering hands on Unix and other operating   system experience. Small to large scale software   development projects.
name: Programming Laboratory
prequisites: Consent of instructor. Concurrent enrollment in Creative Studies-Computer  Science 1A or 1B.

desc: Mathematical foundations of computer science, including   sets, relations, functions, logic and combinatorics.
name: Foundations of Computer Science

desc: Student works with research team to develop or conduct an on-going researchstudy. Focus on learning the process of planning and carrying out a research program.
instructors: BARNETT M L, CONOLEY C W, CONSOLI A J, DOWDY E T, FELIX E D, ISRAEL T, JIMERSON S R, KIA-KEATING M, KOEGEL R L, MORGAN M L, QUIRK M P, SHARKEY J D, VERNON T W, YANG C
name: Research Practicum I

desc: Theory and research regarding processes/dimensions of human development (e.g., cognitive, social, emotional, individual processes, interpersonal processes, the self and gender roles). Special attention is given to social relationships and their developmental significance.
name: Human Development

desc: Explores issues related to professional training and practice in scientific-professional psychology. Topics include internship, graduate training models, history of scientific-professional psychology, professional organizations, credentialing, licensure and employment settings.
name: Professional Organizations

desc: Course examines scientific and professional ethics in applied psychology. In addition to reviewing existing standards, the course focuses on a range of ethical and legal issues such as confidentiality, dual relationships, andclient rights.
name: Ethical Standards in Professional Psychology

desc: Acquaints students with the social and cultural bases of diversity and to enhance multicultural competence. Designed to enhance awareness, knowledge, and skills for providing culturally relevant, sensitive, and effective services to diverse populations.
name: Social and Cultural Bases of Diversity

desc: Provides in-depth coverage of the Wechsler series, the Stanford Binet (4th ed) and other major tests of cognitive ability. A general approach to test administration and interpretation is stressed. General issues in test bias are   used to guide class discussion.
name: Cognitive Assessment in Professional Psychology

desc: Develops an understanding and appreciation of the major philosophies and theories in the field of professional psychology. Special attention directed toward examination of applicability of theories and inherent techniques to racial/ethnic minority populations.
name: Theories of Counseling and Psychotherapy

desc: An overview of theory and research on (a) the process and outcomes of supervision of professional psychologists and (b) consultation models in appliedpsychology.
name: Supervision and Consultation in Applied Psychology

desc: Course involves supervised work with adults, children, adolescents, and families in the Hosford Clinic. Supervised work includes intakes, assessment, counseling & psychotherapy.  Related readings, case notes, written case conceptualizations, and other written assignments and clinic responsibilities are required.
instructors: KIA-KEATING M, CONOLEY C W, DOWDY E T
name: Advanced Fieldwork: General

desc: CCSP students see 1-4 community clients on a weekly basis for psychotherapyin the Gevirtz Graduate School of Education Hosford Counseling Clinic. Students are supervised by clinic supervisors and professionals from the field.
name: Advanced Practicum: Psychology Assessment Center
prequisites: Consent of instructor; limited to CCSP students only.

desc: Advanced supervised fieldwork in an approved counseling setting under the supervision of a licensed psychologist. A minimum of two full days each weekin an approved setting is required.
name: Advanced Fieldwork: Counseling Psychology
prequisites: Three quarters of CNCSP 270; consent of instructor.

desc: Advanced supervised fieldwork in an approved clinical setting under the supervision of a licensed psychologist. A minimum of two full days each week in an approved setting is required.
name: Advanced Fieldwork: Clinical Psychology

desc: Introduction to the school's instructional setting. Core instructional features and pro-social prevention efforts are operationalized and examined in schools. Students learn to identify system-level intervention targets.
name: Assessment and Data-Based Decision-Making in the Schools: School PsychologyPracticum
prequisites: Enrollment in the school psychology credential program; consent of instructor.

desc: Advanced internship in school psychology in a setting approved by faculty. Twenty to forty hours weekly of fieldwork under the supervision of a credentialed school psychologist are required.
name: Internship in School Psychology

desc: Advanced fieldwork internship in an approved setting. Twenty to fourty hours weekly (minimum of 1500 hours) of fieldwork under supervision of a licensed psychologist. Setting must be approved by CCSP faculty.
name: Internship in Professional Psychology
prequisites: Consent of instructor and advancement to candidacy.

desc: Preparation in teaching psychological concepts and skills in   college-level courses.  The content includes course   development, lectures, cooperative learning, grading, teaching   to diverse audiences, and ethics.  Studentswill gain teaching   experience as group leaders for sections of CNCSP 101.
name: Pedagogy in Applied Psychology

desc: Individual tutorial in doctoral and masters' degree subprogram special fields.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Preparation for master's or Ph.D. comprehensive examinations.
name: Individual Study for Comprehensive Examinations

desc: Supervised research and writing of dissertation in doctoral degree.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: Study of special problems in various fields of Applied   Psychology.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance

desc: Introduces students to research in applied   psychology, including approaches to survey, experimental,   and qualitative investigation. Students will be exposed to   current research in applied psychology through journal   articles, presentations, and participation in research   studies.
name: Research in Applied Psychology

desc: An overview of the theories and concepts involved in career decision making. Develop working   knowledge of career information and field survey techniques for understanding the job market   in relation to economic trends.
instructors: SHELTZER J M, CHOI A Y
name: Introduction to Educational and Vocational Guidance

desc: Topics vary by instructor.
instructors: JIMERSON S R, DOWDY E T
name: Special Topics in Applied Psychology

desc: Study of special problems in various fields of Applied   Psychology.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance

desc: Further study of basic elements of ballet.
name: Continuing Ballet

desc: Analysis and exploration of technical and expressive elements   of the ballet. For dance majors.
name: Ballet I

desc: Further analysis and exploration of technical and expressive   elements of ballet. For dance majors.
name: Ballet II

desc: The fundamental exploration of movement potential with particular focus on the individual and group dynamics.
name: Improvisation

desc: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement   as an expressive medium. For dance majors.
name: Modern Dance I

desc: Analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of movement   as an expressive medium at the intermediate level. For dance   majors.
name: Modern Dance II

desc: Group studies in selected areas of emphasis.
name: Group Studies for Lower-Division Dance Students

desc: Independent study in dance. Projects in pedagogy, choreography or dance   research.
name: Independent Study in Dance
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department; completion of lower-division dance history course.

desc: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical and   expressive elements of ballet. For dance majors. Open to non   majors by audition.
name: Ballet III

desc: Further analysis and exploration of the technical and expressive elements of   ballet.
name: Ballet IV

desc: Basic pointe work, including barre and center practice. For dance majors.
name: Ballet: Pointe

desc: Projects in performance, production, choreography, and directing.
name: Dance Workshop

desc: Analysis of the elements of choreographic form; styles and   trends; experience in development of dance studies; theory   and technique of advanced group choreography.
name: Choreography

desc: Advanced analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of   dance as anexpressive medium. For dance majors. Open to non   majors by audition.
name: Modern Dance III

desc: Further analysis and exploration of the technical aspects of   dance as an expressive medium.
name: Modern Dance IV

desc: Further analysis of the theory and practice of teaching dance, including function and esthetics in the development of movement vocabulary, applicationof anatomy, kinetics and musicality. Includes practical experience teachingdance classes.
name: Pedagogy II

desc: Exploration of the process of collaboration between dance choreographers and theatre designers in the development of designs for dance productions. Final project will be a public performance of the choreographers' and designers' work.
name: Dance Production

desc: Selected students work as dancers in the UCSB Dance Company, studying and analyzing choreography and performance. The company performs locally and/or on tour. Students experience the integral workings of a company.
name: UCSB Dance Company

desc: Choreographic or performance project produced as the culmininating presentation for the B.F.A. degree. Course includes detailed documentation of the procedure followed during the creation of the final project.
name: Senior Project

desc: Senior honors project. Advanced thesis project in either academic research or creative activity, supervised by a faculty advisor. Students successfully completing the project, as evaluated by a three-person committee, will graduate with distinction in the major.
name: Senior Honors Project

desc: Independent study in dance. Projects in choreography or dance research.
name: Independent Study in Dance
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Dance.

desc: Students receiving credit will present talks in their field on material arranged in consultation with the instructor. Credit assigned by the instructor will reflect the extent and quality of participation.
name: Art Colloquium

desc: Emphasis on the practice and development of making paintings and drawings.
name: Drawing and Painting

desc: Drawing and painting in sequences, and according to themes.
name: Themes

desc: The study and practice of the book arts; artists' books; typography;   letterpress printing; both traditional and experimental uses of the   printing press.
name: Book Arts

desc: Non-studio emphasis on historical, theoretical, and contemporary ideas and issues. A range of concepts will be discussed, from various approaches,according to the particular interests of faculty and students.
name: History, Theory, and Criticism

desc: This special studies course allows faculty to design and execute courses that reflect their particular research and teaching.
name: Special Topics

desc: Research seminar for special interest groups in dynamical   neuroscience.
name: Special Interest Group Research Seminar
