prequisites: Only students in the Dynamical Neuroscience Program may register for this  course. Other students interested in registering must have prior approval  of   the chair.

desc: Provides supervised experience in experimental design and   laboratory procedures on selected topics, including the   formulation of experimental problems, discussion of relevant   literature and the analysis and interpretation of experimental   results.
name: Directed Reading and Research in Dynamical Neuroscience

desc: Empirical and theoretical investigations of special problems   in dynamicalneuroscience in relation to dissertation   research.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Survey of major topics in geophysics at an elementary level; the figure of the earth, its gravitational and magnetic fields, seismology and the deep structure of the earth, heat flow, methods of geophysical exploration. The geophysical basis of plate tectonics and sea floor spreading. Term paper.
name: Introduction to Geophysics

desc: Field, laboratory, and analytical projects serve as an introduction to diverse research foci and techniques in Earth Science.
name: Graduate Research and Field Seminar

desc: Course will develop isotopic systems as tracers of Earth   processes, with a particular focus placed on developing   radiogenic isotopic systems. The isotopic tools will be used   to establish the chronology of the earliest terrestrial   events and the formation and evolution of different   reservoirs in the Earth. Applications of isotopic systems to   solid Earth evolution, petrology, paleoclimate and ocean   chemistry will be explored.
name: Isotope Geochemistry

desc: Presentation and discussion of current research, and reviews of the literature on selected geologic concepts. Students present material reflecting their interests in geology for critical appraisal, of both content and manner of presentation, by selected members of the seminar. Emphasis is placed on assisting students in developing professional speaking style.
name: Seminar in Geology

desc: Presentation of research topics to meeting of Geology 260.
name: Seminar in Geology-Presentation

desc: Review and discussion of a current problem in geology.   Content is variable and depends on student interest.
instructors: VALENTINE D L, MATOZA R S
name: Seminar in Geologic Problems

desc: Morphology, formation, and evolution of ocean basins; crustal structure andcomposition of ocean margins; source and composition of marine sediments; marine sediment as repository of paleoclimate and paleo-ocean circulation records.  Paleoceanographic changes in relation to tectonics and changes in orbital parameters, links between changes in ocean circulation and climate changes.
name: Geological Oceanography

desc: Studies in marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of seafloor mapping usingbottom photography, marine bio/geochemical sampling, and methods of data reduction and sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples collected.    Lecture, 3 hours;  lab, up to 7 hours;  field, up to 6 weeks.
name: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry

desc: Practical experience in teaching in geological sciences. Student will have responsibility for one or more laboratory and/or discussion sections. Evaluations will be made by both staff and class.
name: Practicum in Instruction

desc: Orientation and workshop in professional conduct and responsibilities. Course will involve observation of student in teaching situation (faculty visits or videotaping) and follow-up conferences, evaluations, and follow-up.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Practical experience in research in the geological sciences, under supervision of faculty member.
name: Practicum in Research

desc: Individual tutorial. Written proposal for each tutorial must be approved bythe instructor and the department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.

desc: Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of the committee.
name: Individual Study for Master's and Ph.D. Examinations
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.

desc: Instructor normally should be chair of the student's thesis committee. Onlyfor research underlying the thesis, writing the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.

desc: Instructor normally should be chair of thestudent's doctoral committee. Only for research underlying thedissertation, writing the dissertation. Limited to terminal preparation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate adviser.

desc: Introduction to the science of the Earth; properties and   processes of itssurface and interior, including plate   tectonics, volcanism, earthquakes, glaciation, mountain   building, formation of rocks, minerals, and the structural   basis of landforms. Lab and lecture.
instructors: AWRAMIK S M, LETTS A W, WILLHITE L N, MOREL D L, MAHER S
name: Principles of Physical Geology

desc: An introduction to oceanography covering the major physical, chemical, and geological features of the oceans, their role in earth history, and potential use as a natural resource. Lab and lecture.
instructors: PAUL B G, LIU N, ARRINGTON E C, AUSTIN A K
name: Introduction to Oceanography

desc: The origin and diversification of dinosaurs, including birds. Survey of evolutionary relationships within the group, and between the major groups of vertebrates. Broad introduction including anatomy, geography, climate, and vertebrate contemporaries.
instructors: EVERETT C J, COX D D, BUBE C M, SHAHBOL N, SU I, MUNSON J C, MCGRATH A J, PETROFSKY E H, WANG JIONG
name: Dinosaurs

desc: The interrelations of the physical and biological   environments   on the continent Antarctica; Antarctica as an earth system.   Included are studies of tectonic history, global warming,   ozone depletion, mineral resources, and the history of   scientific exploration of the continent.
instructors: COTTLE J, SPRATT R M, RAND D S, LOVE C R, RONEY D L
name: Antarctica: The Last Place on Earth

desc: Four to five day field trip, fall and/or spring quarters.   Field studies under guidance of two or three staff members   introducing the geology of California.
name: Field Studies in Geological Sciences

desc: Course deals with geologic catastrophes, e.g., earthquakes, vocanic eruptions, tsunamis, and landslides. Students will learn the basic physicalcauses of these naturally occurring events and discuss the consequences.
instructors: STRUTNER M A, DE-NEGRI LEIV, PRESCOTT A J, ENG R, ADAMS M N, HARRICHHAUSEN
name: Geological Catastrophes

desc: Critical reviews and discussions of selected geological subjects.
name: Readings in Geological Sciences

desc: Independent research conducted under guidance of Earth Science faculty. Topic and scope varies, to be specified by student and supervisory faculty member prior to registration.
name: Independent Studies

desc: Survey of major topics in geophysics at an elementary   level; the figure of the earth, its gravitational and   magnetic fields, seismology and the deep structure of the   earth, heat flow, methods of geophysical exploration.The   geophysical basis of plate tectonics and sea floor   spreading.
name: Introduction to Geophysics
prequisites: Mathematics 3C or Mathematics 4A and 4B; Physics 1, 2, and 3 (may be taken concurrently), or Physics 6A-B-C (may be taken concurrently).

desc: Introduction to the occurrence, associations, tectonics, and   petrogenesisof plutonic and volcanic rocks. Introduction to   the physical chemistry ofmagma systems; magmatic   crystallization and differentiation; pluton emplacement,   volcanic eruption mechanisms. Lecture and lab.
instructors: RIOUX M E, SCRUGGS M A
name: Petrology of Igneous Rocks
prequisites: Mathematics 3A; and, Earth 114 and 115 with a grade of C or better.

desc: Introduction to the methods of geological observations and interpretations,with an emphasis on understanding earth processes in the field and reconstructing the physical history of the earth; the stratigraphic, petrologic, and structural relations of rocks. Geologic report writing.
instructors: GANS P B, BUTCHER L A JUNKIN W D NEWMANN J R

timeslots.instructor: BUTCHER L A JUNKIN W D NEWMANN J R

name: Field Studies in Geological Methods

desc: Examination of geomaterials at atomic level. Atomic   structure,   states of matter, bonding, elementary phase equilibria.    Composition and structure of atmosphere, hydrosphere, crust,   mantle and core. Structure and composition of important   geochemical compounds emphasizing rock-forming minerals.
instructors: RUDNICK R L, JOHNSON T A, MONROE E B, PRICE A A, ADAMS J V, ANDERSON O E
name: Geomaterials

desc: Introduction to the theory of landscape evolution and the   study of the processes that create and modify landforms.
instructors: KELLER E A, ALESSIO P A
name: Earth Surface Processes and Landforms

desc: Transport/depositional processes, sedimentary textures and structures.   Sedimentary environments, using facies models for observation &   prediction.Principles of lithostratigraphy, biostratigraphy,   chronostratigraphy, andmagnetostratigraphy. Seismic stratigraphy and   sequence stratigraphic principles. Controls of tectonics, sediment   supply and eustacy on sedimentation. Lab and Lecture.
instructors: REYNOLDS L C, ZURBUCHEN J M
name: Sedimentation and Stratigraphy: Processes and Products
prequisites: Earth 2; and Earth 3; and Earth 104A; and Earth 114.  Field trip   required.

desc: Introduction to general field techniques used in   hydrology including   methods to determine river discharge, basic well and   spring sampling,   well water level measurements, and soil hydraulic   characterization.    The ~2 week class takes place at Sagehen Creek Field   Station (north of   Truckee, CA) in the eastern Sierra prior to the start of   the Fall   quarter.
instructors: CLARK J DE JONG M T

timeslots.instructor: CLARK J DE JONG M T

name: FIELD METHODS IN HYDROLOGY
prequisites: Earth 104A; and either Earth 173 or Geography 116 or consent of   instructor.

desc: Introduction to the scientific and societal issues surrounding   global climate change. Includes introduction to physical   climatology, greenhouse effect, climate history, anthropogenic   changes, and future predictions. Student discussion and debate   on the potential societal scenarios available to mitigate   future climate change.
instructors: LEA D W MCCOMB S H

timeslots.instructor: LEA D W MCCOMB S H

name: Global Warming - Science and Society

desc: Basic principles in geophysics from elasticity theory, fluid dynamics, gravity,   magnetism, and heat flow. Their applications to various processes inthe earth.
name: Principles of Geophysics
prequisites: Mathematics 3A-B-C or 3A-B and 4A-B; and Mathematics 5A or 5C or 6A (may betaken concurrently); and, Physics 1 and 2, or Physics 6A-B-C.

desc: Important topics in paleobiology are discussed in the context   of the evolutionary history of invertebrate animal life.   These include macroevolutionary theory, diversification and   extinction events, ecological and geobiological interactions   through time, and the incompleteness of the fossil record.
name: Invertebrate Paleobiology
prequisites: MCDB 1A & MCDB 1B & EEMB 2 & EEMB 3 or Earth 3 or 30 or 111 (all with a minimum grade of C- or   better)

desc: Attendance at departmental "journal club" (Earth 260, seminar   in geology)and brief written evaluations of the three papers   which, in the student'sjudgement, were the best of the   quarter.
name: Seminar in Geology

desc: Marine bio/geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea   or into the field on land. Lectures cover techniques of sea-  floor mapping using bottom photography, marine   bio/geochemical sampling, and method of data reduction and   sample analysis. Labs include analysis of data/samples   collected.    Lecture, 3 hours; labs, up to 7 hours; field, up to 6 weeks.
name: Field Studies in Marine Bio/Geochemistry

desc: Students will assist instructors in teaching course in which   the student previously received a grade of A- or better.   Activities will be determined in consultation with the   instructor and may include assisting in laboratories,   tutorials, discussion sections and field trips.

prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Undergraduate seminar in advanced paleobiology involving   reading and group discussion of current literature. Option to   (with faculty consent) write research papers of varying length or equivalent.

desc: Individualized practical approaches to problems in   geological sciences byworking under faculty supervision as interns with local,   state or federalagencies   or private organizations.  To receive credit student must   turnin an experiential   journal, end of quarter evaluation, and complete the  internship hours.  Units are   determined by the number to be completed at the end of the   quarter.
name: Internship in Geological Sciences
prequisites: Proposal form must be submitted by the end of the 2nd week of the quarter. Applicant must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.70.  Student that does not  meet this requirement may submit a GPA waiver.

desc: Field work in selected areas under the direction of a faculty   member. Final report required.
name: Honors Field Studies
prequisites: Earth Science majors only; honors standing; consent of instructor.

desc: Three quarter individual research project under the direction   of a faculty member. Oral defense of written thesis as   required by the sponsoring faculty advisor.
name: Senior Honors Thesis
prequisites: Earth Science majors only; consent of instructor; honors standing (minimum overall and major GPA of 3.2).

desc: Critical reviews and discussions of selected geological subjects.
name: Readings in the Geological Sciences
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of the instructor and the department chair

desc: Course consists of academic research supervised by a faculty   member. Thiscourse is not intended for internship honors, or   Senior Thesis credit.

instructors: LOVELL J M, LEE L H, ERDENE-OCHIR, LAMBELET P G
name: Zen Buddhism

name: Biological Oceanography

desc: An examination of ecological aspects of lakes, wetlands and their physical coupling and population and community ecology. Applications of remote sensing and ecological models; human-caused impacts and their management.
instructors: MELACK J M MACINTYRE S, COHEN A P
name: Ecology of Lakes and Wetlands
prequisites: EEMB 142B; and, EEMB 142A or EEMB 120 or equivalent.

desc: Participation as a member of the scientific part on Scripps institution (UCSD), NMFS, and UCSB oceanographic cruises. Cruise duration is variable (7 to 60 days), and course units will vary with cruise duration. Supervision byscientific party leader. Report required.
name: Field Work in Oceanography
prequisites: Upper-division courses in aquatic biology and/or geology.

desc: Seminar explores current topics in restoration ecology including model projects, techniques, structured research, performance criteria, political and philosophical issues and may include site visits.
name: Restoration Ecology Seminar

desc: Presentation and discussion of current EEMB faculty research. Informal discussions follow weekly faculty member research presentations. This seminar exposes graduate students to the breadth of departmental research, facilitates graduate-faculty interaction, and offers an intellectual setting for student interaction.
name: Introduction to Faculty Research
prequisites: Strongly encouraged for all first year graduate students; open to continuingraduate students. Undergraduates by consent of instructor.

desc: General orientation regarding the University of California and the Santa Barbara campus; various pertinent regulations, officials and their functions,staff and functions; services available to teaching assistants and to students. Prospective teaching assistants are encouraged to take this course during the fall quarter prior to their employment.
name: Teaching Assistant Orientation

desc: Practical experience in teaching within specified areas of biology. Students will have responsibility for one or more laboratory and/or discussion sections. Staff will periodically observe teaching assistants in actual teaching situations. Evaluation forms will be completed by members of the class sections.
name: Practicum in Instruction

desc: Basic procedures and methods of research in a specific area as determined by consultation between the supervising faculty member and the research assistant. Includes weekly meetings and consultations, and formal evaluations.
name: Research Practium in Biology

desc: This is the first in a set of two advanced courses in   ecology and evolution, and includes modules on adaptation   and organismal function, life history theory and fitness,   and population dynamics.
instructors: SWEET S S PROULX S R ELIASON PARSO, SWEET S S OONO R

timeslots.instructor: SWEET S S PROULX S R ELIASON PARSO

name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: M.A. (thesis) candidate and consent of committee chair.

desc: For writing of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: Introduction to the major groups of microbes, plants, and animals.
instructors: MAZER S J LATTO J G SCHOOLER N K

timeslots.instructor: MAZER S J LATTO J G SCHOOLER N K

name: Introductory Biology III

desc: Designed for transfer students who have completed part of EEMB 3 through transfer work. Topics will be selected by the department, as appropriate, to fulfill the introductory biology requirement at UCSB.
instructors: LATTO J G MAZER S J

timeslots.instructor: LATTO J G MAZER S J

name: Selected Topics from EEMB 3

desc: Introduction to the principles of evolution as a   foundation for understanding  topics such as adaptation,   physiology and ecology. Focuses on areasof biology that   encompass important political, economic, social, and   philosophical issues. Examines   perspectives on currently relevant, and biologically   based topics such as evolution   / scientific creationism, sociobiology, biotechnology,   right to life issues, animal rights, AIDS and other   epidemics, and overpopulation. (S)
instructors: EVEN T J, TOOTHMAN M H
name: Concepts and Controversies in the Biological Sciences

desc: Uses topical examples of emerging and resurgent diseases to illustrate key principles in ecology and epidemiology.  Examines how changing disease   ecology influences disease prevalence and how such changing patterns of   disease have influenced human history.
instructors: LATTO J G, DOWDY K L, GARCIA VEDREN
name: Ecology of Infectious Disease

desc: Opportunity to obtain practical biological-related research   experience byworking under faculty direction as an intern   with local, state, federal, or private agencies. A written   report will be submitted for evaluation.
name: Internship in Biological Sciences
prequisites: Lower-division standing; instructor and departmental approval required.

desc: Introduction to curation of natural history collections including vertebrate,   plants, algae and lichen. Learn to collect, prepare, catalog, and preserve   specimens via lectures, hands-on activities, and field trips. Collection focus   changes quarterly. Internships available at conclusion of the course.
name: Introduction to Curation of Natural History Collections

desc: Special readings on selected topics in biology. Individual conferences one one hour every week. Designed to broaden the out look and experience of advanced lower-division students. Hours and credit by arrangement with any member of the staff.
name: Readings in Biological Sciences

desc: Laboratory or field experience for advanced lower-division students. Hours and credit by arrangement with any member of the staff.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: The evolution, systematics, biogeography, and ecology of   fishes.
name: Biology of Fishes
prequisites: EEMB 2; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: An introduction to the classification, structure, life histories, and habits of the major phyla of invertebrate animals (excluding annelids and arthropods), with emphasis on marine fauna of Santa Barbara area.

prequisites: EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: Evolutionary and ecological principles as demonstrated by   amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals; competition and   other species interactions; diversity and systematics with   special emphasis on speciation theory.
instructors: MCCAULEY D J YOUNG H S TARN J S

prequisites: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed   prerequisites with a grade of C-   or better.

desc: Explore ecological processes in California habitats and the   challenges oftheir management through field trips,   discussions with land managers, lectures and readings. Focus   on regional habitats including specialized habitats such as   coastal salt marsh and vernal pools, and more widespread such   as oak savanna and chaparral.
name: Ecology and Management of California Wildlands
prequisites: Environmental Studies 100 or EEMB 120 or EEMB 168.

desc: Major concepts in population and evolutionary ecology. Theoretical, experimental, and field studies pertaining to population growth and regulation, competition, predation, diversity, adaptation and life history strategies.
instructors: MORTON D N BROOKS A J, PEACH K, ROSSINGTON N, KOENIGS C J

name: Introduction to Ecology
prequisites: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: The consequences of Mendelian principles in diploid   populations, including quantitative genetics; genetic   correlations, gene frequency, change under selection, the   effects of mutation on populations, gene interactions in   fitness, and ecological genetics.
instructors: TURNER T L, SHAHANDEH M P
name: Population Genetics
prequisites: MCDB 1A, 1B, EEMB 2 and EEMB 3 all with a grade of C- or better.

desc: A survey of the patterns of distribution, diversity, an abundance of species in marine and freshwater communities, with an emphasis on the dynamic interactions which shape these patterns. Applied aspects: fisheries, mariculture.
instructors: DAVIS S L EVEN T J, KOZAL L C, PETERS J

timeslots.instructor: DAVIS S L EVEN T J

name: Aquatic Communities
prequisites: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: Experience in the field techniques of aquatic community ecology.
instructors: SCHMITT R J EVEN T J, RICE M M, VALDEZ-SCHULZ

timeslots.instructor: SCHMITT R J EVEN T J
SCHMITT R J EVEN T J

name: Methods in Aquatic Community Ecology

desc: Exploration of evolution, ecology, biochemistry, and genetics of marine bacteria. Topics include: historical perspective, molecular approaches in microbial ecology, trophic interactions/biogeochemistry, physiological adaptations, and biochemistry and genetics of selected systems bioluminescence, deep-sea adaptations, cell-surface interactions, starvation survival).
instructors: CARLSON C A SANTORO A E, LAPERRIERE S

timeslots.instructor: CARLSON C A SANTORO A E

name: Marine Microbiology
prequisites: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: A laboratory survey of the diversity, physiology and ecology of marine prokaryotes, and methods used to identify, quantify and measure their activities.
instructors: CARLSON C A SANTORO A E LAPERRIERE S

timeslots.instructor: CARLSON C A SANTORO A E LAPERRIERE S

name: Marine Microbiology Lab
prequisites: MCDB 1A, EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; concurrent enrollment in EEMB 144 or 142B; Completion of all listed prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: Exploration of the diversity of archaea, bacteria, and   fungi   associatedwith humans, animals, plants, and extreme   terrestrial   environments. Topics include ecology, evolution,   genetics,   systematics, and physiology with special focus on species   interactions among microbes or between hostsand   microbes.
name: Terrestrial Microbiology
prequisites: MCDB 1A, MCDB 1B, EEMB 2, and EEMB 3 all with a grade of C- or better

desc: An examination of ecological aspects of lakes, wetlands, and   their catchments integrating biogeochemical processes,   biological-physical coupling, and population and community   ecology. Applications of remote sensing and ecological models;   human-caused impacts and their management.
instructors: MELACK J M MACINTYRE S, COHEN A P
name: Ecology of Lakes and Wetlands
prequisites: EEMB 142B; and, EEMB 142A or EEMB 120; Completion of all listed prerequisites   with a grade of C- or better.

desc: An analysis of processes fundamental to the functioning of   cells, using actual examples from the protista. These   processes include, but are not limited to, membrane structure   and function, motility, metabolite transport, protein   trafficking, energy acquisition and utilization.
instructors: THOMASSON K M, FREEDMAN R M
name: Cell Physiology
prequisites: MCDB 1A, and EEMB 2 and MCDB 1B, and EEMB 3; Completion of all listed   prerequisites with a grade of C- or better.

desc: An examination of the key processes that regulate ecosystem productivity and function in terrestrial ecosystems. Specific foci include: plant- soil linkages including decomposition and nutrient supply, and the role of above- and below-ground community composition on element cycles.
instructors: SCHIMEL J P, HAGERTY S B
name: Ecosystem Processes
prequisites: Environmental Studies 100 or EEMB 2 or MCDB 1B.

desc: Opportunity to obtain practical biological related experience by working under faculty direction as an intern with local, state, federal, or private agencies. A written report will be submitted for evaluation.
name: Internship in Biological Sciences

desc: Participation as a member of a scientific party on Scripps Institution (UCSD), NMFS, and UCSB oceanographic cruises. Cruise duration is variable (7 to60 days), and course units will vary with cruise duration. Supervision by scientific party leader. Report required.
name: Field Work in Oceanography

desc: Seminar explores current topics in conservation biology and restoration ecology including basic and applied questions related to the conservation, restoration and management of populations,communities and ecosystems. Presentations and discussions may include model ecosystem studies, hands on restoration or conservation projects & lessons learned, and political, economic and philosophical issues.
name: Conservation and Restoration Seminar

desc: Exposes students to current research topics in ecology and   evolutionary biology. Students will attend the EEMB departmental seminar   each week and participate in a discussion of the seminar research,   critiquing the presentation and the content, and drawing parallels with topics   from other courses. Students will write a term paper describing and   critiquing one seminar.
instructors: PRUITT J N YOUNG H S

timeslots.instructor: PRUITT J N YOUNG H S

name: EEMB Colloquium

desc: Special topics of current importance in biological sciences. Course contentwill vary. Information may be obtained from the department office.
name: Special Topics in Biological Sciences
prequisites: Upper-division standing in EEMB or MCDB and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
name: Community Ecology
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
instructors: SCHIMEL J P D'ANTONIO C M OONO R

timeslots.instructor: SCHIMEL J P D'ANTONIO C M OONO R

name: Plant Ecology
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.

prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
instructors: TURNER T L HODGES S A OAKLEY T H

name: Evolutionary Biology
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

name: Reproductive Ecology and Evolution
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
name: Group Studies for Advanced Students
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
name: Parasitology
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Oral reports by students.
instructors: BRIGGS C J PROULX S R

timeslots.instructor: BRIGGS C J PROULX S R

name: Theoretical Ecology and Evolution
prequisites: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Hours and credit by arrangement with any faculty member.
name: Directed Studies
prequisites: EEMB major; consent of department; upper-division standing; completion of  two upper-division courses in MCDB or EEMB; and a 2.5 GPA in upper-divisionmajor courses.

desc: Individual conferences one hour every two weeks. Special readings designed to broaden the outlook of students and to knit into a cohesive whole the basic principles underlying the major disciplines in the field.
name: Directed Readings
prequisites: EEMB major; consent of department; upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in MCDB or EEMB.

desc: Hours and credit by arrangement with any faculty member. Laboratory or field.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: EEMB majors only; consent of instructor and department; upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in MCDB or EEMB.

desc: Introduction to modern macroeconomics. Study of economic growth and dynamicoptimization. Representative agent, overlapping generations and monetary models will be covered.
name: Macroeconomic Theory

desc: Course covers: traditional asset pricing by deriving   basic asset pricing model from representative agent model under the   assumption of complete   markets (Consumption based CAPM). Also discussed will be   its empirical fit,   the puzzles it raises and touch briefly on estimation   using GMM. This   general model will be applied to models used in practice:   factor capital   asset pricing model (CAPM), Fama-French 3-factor model,   extensions to C-  CAPM related to habit formation and Epstein-Zin recursive   preferences, and   incomplete markets.
name: Modern Asset Pricing
prequisites: Second year Ph.D. in Economics graduate student standing.

desc: Elements of probability and statistics for econometrics. Probability density functions, moment-generating functions, central limit theorems, method ofmaximum likelihood.
name: Econometrics

desc: The logic and structure of empirical work. In order: How to   quantify theory; sources of data; methods of estimation;   informative reporting of results.
name: Econometric Theory
prequisites: Economics 241C and Second year and above Ph.D. Graduate standing.

desc: An introduction to the dynamic optimization techniques of the calculus of variations and optimal control theory. Focus on continuous time planning problems in a deterministic setting. Applications include natural resource extraction, energy production, human capital accumulation, and insurance.
name: Dynamic Optimization

desc: Course examines the determinants of population change and   demographic   behavior including household formation and dissolution,   marriage and   decision-making within households, child bearing and   rearing, mortality   (including infant mortality) and key forms of human   capital investment   including schooling and migration. We’ll apply   theoretical and empirical   tools to investigate the sources and consequences of   demographic transitions   including recent phenomena such as population aging, the   emergence of lowest   low fertility, and consider the role of policy   instruments inchanging   demographic behavior.
name: Population Economics
prequisites: Second year Ph.D. graduate student standing.

desc: Capital theory and welfare economics applied to the primarily dynamic questions concerning the uses of nonrenewable resources such as minerals, the use of renewable resources such as fisheries and forests, and the preservation of species and natural environments.
name: Natural Resources

desc: Research methodology in experimental economics. The main   lectures introduce conceptual, statistical and practical   tools   used in the design and conduct of economics experiments.   Students present and prepare reviews of important recent   papers in the field and, for a final project, complete anew   experimental design.
name: Experimental Economics I
prequisites: Completion of first year of Economics Ph.D. program and 2nd year   Economics Ph.D. Graduate student standing.

desc: Students present and discuss their original research papers.
name: Third Year Graduate Seminar

desc: Current topics in microeconomics.
name: Microeconomics Seminar

desc: Group study directed toward Experimental Economics and   Behavioral Economics research topics.
name: Special Topics in Economics - Experimental and Behavioral   Economics
prequisites: Second year and above Ph.D. Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Group study directed toward econometric research topics.
name: Special Topics in Economics

desc: Seminar and group study directed toward Human Capital and   Education Economics research topics.
name: Special Topics in Economics - Human Capital and Education
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Group study directed toward Environmental Economics research   topics.
name: Special Topics in Economics - Environmental and Natural   Resource Economics
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Group study directed toward Labor Economics research topics.
name: Special Topics in Economics - Labor Economics
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Special seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics in Economics
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: Individual study for the three Ph.D. level Preliminary   Examinations in either Microeconomics, Macroeconomics   and/or Econometrics. Instructor should be the Economics   department Director of Graduate Studies.
name: Individual study for the Ph.D. Comprehensive Examinations.
prequisites: Ph.D. in Economics graduate student standing and consent of Director of   Graduate Studies.

desc: Only for research underlying the dissertation, writing the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor.

desc: An introduction to microeconomic analysis. Economic theory   related to demand, production, competitive and non-  competitive product markets, input markets, and welfare.   Applications of microeconomic theory including its use in   evaluating and forming public policy.
instructors: GARRATT R J, OSAKI T T, XIAO H, LEI Z, OZYILMAZ H, ALSHAIKHMUBAR, JEON W, LIU YIZHOU, JIANG X, BAO K Q, GRIFFY B S, WANG ZHENG
name: Principles of Economics-Micro

desc: A two-quarter series providing an introduction to the purposes, conceptual framework, measurement principles and reporting issues of accounting. Particular emphasis will be placed on the links between accounting, economics, and finance.
instructors: ANDERSON R W, HSIAO M, ADEDEJI T A, HESS S B, WINTHROP K A, HARMON C J, KEATON E J, DUFFY R B, BAR NIR H
name: Financial Accounting

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Financial Accounting - Honors

desc: A broad survey of economic principles, including both   microeconomics and macroeconomics.
instructors: BENELLI C A, HERNANDEZ COR, KAAPCKE L N, GRIMES N G, FITZGERALD M
name: Introduction to Economics

desc: Economic theory relating to demand, production, and   competitive product markets with emphasis on applications of   theory.
instructors: HARTMAN J L, MALLOY C J, MEI G, DEEB A, URSU J C, WANG DI, STRAUSS C K, NGUYEN H X, DESCHENES O, SCHWARZ M C, STUART C, MARKS L, YU L
name: Intermediate Microeconomic Theory

desc: Economic thought from antiquity through John Stuart Mill. Economic thought in   the   Bible, Greece, Rome, India, and China through the classical economists--  Thomas   Hobbes, John Locke, Adam Smith, Jeremy Bentham, Thomas Malthus, David   Ricardo,   and John Stuart Mill. Emphasis on both economic activity and economic   thought,   including discussion of feudal and mercantilist societies. The economic roles of   women and slavery are presented.
name: History of Economics

desc: The antitrust treatment of monopoly and monopolization,   including both horizontal and vertical market arrangements and   controls, and in-depth analysis of major antitrust decisions.
name: Antitrust Economics

desc: Application of economic analysis to the law. Includes an introduction to common law, constitutional law, and legal processes. Topics may include property law, contract law, and tort law.
name: Law and Economics I

desc: An economic analysis of financial statements in a   macroeconomic environment. Topics include evaluation of short   term and long term liquidity, profitability, capital structure and the   forecast of earnings and financial position using financial and   economic models.
name: Financial Accounting Analysis and Planning

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Financial Accounting Analysis and Planning - Honors

desc: Fiscal theory and policy. Incidence and effects of taxation, government expenditure programs, and benefit cost analysis.
name: Public Finance

desc: Developing an understanding of concepts and practices for   audits of financial statements. Studying professional   standards, ethics, and legal liability. The audit process   is covered in-depth: planning, internal control, audit   risk, materiality, evidence, program design, sampling,   completingthe audit, and reporting.
name: Auditing

desc: Discounting of certain future cash flows. Principles of evaluation of investment projects. Demand and supply of investment funds. Risk and the valuation of asset prices. Analysis of a firm's debt and dividend policies;the effect of taxes and inflation on these policies.
instructors: HARTMAN J L, CAO YUAN, HELO SARMIENT, ROBERTSON E N
name: Financial Management

desc: Survey of monetary theory, the banking system and the supply of money, monetary policy, and current issues.
name: Monetary Economics

desc: An in-depth analysis of recognition, measurement,   classification, and valuation issues in financial reporting   within the framework of generally accepted accounting   principles. Case studies and microcomputer analysis   software will be integrated into the course.
instructors: KULPER D E, VITIELLO S T, GRAY L A, LI M Q
name: Intermediate Accounting

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
instructors: GRAY L A, KULPER D E
name: Intermediate Accounting - Honors

desc: An in-depth analysis of recognition, measurement, classification, and valuation issues in financial reporting within the framework of generally accepted accounting principles. Case studies and microcomputer analysis software will be integrated into the course.
instructors: HULME J L, HARMON C J
name: Intermediate Accounting

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Intermediate Accounting - Honors

desc: A two quarter series covering the theory and application of   managerial accounting concepts. The course investigates the   interaction between economic theory, financial accounting,   and management decision making for planning and control.
instructors: MAASS L E, TUCK K G, JAIN RASHI, DOWNUM A J
name: Managerial Accounting
prequisites: Economics 3B, one of 10A or 100A, and one of PStat 5E or 109.

desc: An introduction to taxation. The basic theories, concepts, and general rules of federal income tax and their   interrelationships with personal, business, and financial   transactions. The course provides an understanding of tax   policies and the interrelationship between tax and financial   decisions.
name: Income Taxation
prequisites: Economics 3B, and 10A or 100A, and PStat 5E or 109.

desc: Accounting for business combinations and preparation of consolidated financial statements, principles of fund accounting (governmental and non-profit entities), foreign currency translation and transactions, partnership formation, operation, and liquidation.
name: Advanced Accounting

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar.  Intended   for highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Advanced Accounting - Honors

desc: Estimation and hypothesis testing in classical linear   regression models as well as violations of each classical   assumption. Discrete dependent variable models and   systems of simultaneous equation are also covered.
instructors: STARTZ R, YILDIZ S, MCQUILKIN A J, WEI Z, KIM YONGWOOK, BANA S H, STEIGERWALD D, CULLEN D J
name: Introduction to Econometrics
prequisites: Economics 10A or 100A or 104A, and PStat 5E or 109 or 120A.

desc: Studies the allocation and pricing of labor within firms.   Topics covered include employee selection, design of   optimal piece rates, advantages anddisadvantages of   seniority-based pay, tournaments and promotions, and   incentives in team production.
instructors: KUHN P J, COOPER M T
name: Personnel Economics

desc: Application of economic and statistical principles to health and health services. Topics may include the determinate of health, demand for health careand health insurance, competition and monopoly in health care and insuranceof health care, HMOs and managed care plans, public policy and international comparisons.
name: Health Economics

desc: A rigorous study of strategic interaction. Topics include normal and extensive form games, existence and uniqueness of equilibrium, randomization, minimax, dynamics and equilibrium selection, auctions and bargaining, principle-agent incentives, voting, private contributions to public goods, oligopoly competition, market entry and burning money, wars of attrition.
name: Introduction to Game Theory

desc: International money and capital markets and their impact on the domestic and world economies; international financial institutions and policies.
name: International Finance

desc: Provides a basic understanding of ethics and the legal   framework within which U.S. businesses operate. Includes a   broad overview of court procedures and in-depth coverage of   selected topics including contracts, securities, and property   rights.
name: Business Law and Ethics in Accounting
prequisites: Economics 3B and 10A or 100A or 104A; PStat 5E or 109.

desc: Students receive one unit for the honors seminar. Intended for   highly motivated and well prepared students.
name: Business Law and Ethics - Honors

desc: Course enables students to obtain credit for economics-related internship experience. An eight to ten page written report is required and evaluated for credit.
name: Internship in Economics

desc: Students undertake independent research project(s) under direction of faculty member. The research results are presented as an honors paper at the endof the second term (196B).
name: Senior Honors Seminar
prequisites: 3.5 GPA in Economics 10A or 100A or 104A, and 100B or 104B, and 101 or 105 and 140A.

desc: Coursework shall consist of academic research supervised by a   faculty member. This course is not intended for internships.
name: Independent Studies in Economics
prequisites: Upper-division standing in the major; 3.0 UD major GPA and 3.0 GPA in   preceding 3 quarters; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Economics;   consent of department and instructor.

desc: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research.
name: Independent Research in Economics
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Economics;   consent of instructor and department.

desc: Special research in Roman and late antique architecture.
name: Seminar: Topics in Roman Architecture and Urbanism
prequisites: Graduate standing or senior art history majors with consent of instructor.

desc: Special research in northern Renaissance figurative arts of the fifteenth and/or sixteenth centuries.
name: Seminar: Topics in 15th & 16th C. Art in Northern Europe

desc: Special research in twentieth-century art.
name: Seminar: Topics in European Art of the Twentieth Century

desc: Source readings for graduate students. Independent reading and research in connection with an undergraduate lecture course.
name: Seminar: Advanced Readings in Art History
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: For teaching assistants, course includes directed readings, instruction in use of visual aids, pedagogical techniques, design of materials for discussion sections, and methodological analyses. Attendance at lectures inthe course to which the T.A. is assigned is a requirement.
name: Apprentice Teaching
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal must be approved by the department chair.
name: Independent Study
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: Preparation for terminal M.A. or for Ph.D. Minor and Major exams.
name: Reading for Examination
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: Master's Thesis research and preparation.
name: Master's Thesis Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: Dissertation research and preparation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor; department approval.

desc: Introduction to both graduate student life and research in   Education. Includes information   about campus resources, trainings in campus requirements,   and an introduction to the basic   principles of qualitative and quantitative research in   Education.
name: Education Proseminar

desc: In-depth consideration of emerging topics in research   methodology in education.
instructors: NYLUND K L, MAUL A E
name: Issues in Research Methodology

desc: Issues of writing assessment from micro (student papers) to macro (large-scale assessment: NAEP, UC Subject A Examinations), and writing program assessment. Exploration of different research paradigms in writing assessment: empirical and hermeneutic are also discussed.
name: Assessment of Writing

desc: Seminar for students engaged in the conceptualization, conduct, or analysisof research on child and adolescent development.
name: Research Seminar in Human Development

desc: Survey of contemporary theoretical approaches and empirical findings in theareas of learning, instruction, cognitive processes, situated cognition, cultural models of education,  and innovative applications of information technology.
name: Advances in the Learning Sciences and Education

desc: In-depth consideration of emerging topics in cultural perspectives of education.
instructors: CHUN D M, ARYA D J
name: Seminar in Cultural Perspectives of Education

desc: Examination of founding theoretical texts of sociocultural theory of learning in both Russia and the West and their application to current issues in education.
name: Foundations of Sociocultural Learning Theory

desc: Theoretical bases and empirical findings on the development of children from conception through pre-school age across various areas of competency; such as social, language, moral, cognitive, and motor.
name: Development: Infancy and Early Childhood

desc: Required course for students in the Interdisciplinary Quantitative Methods in the Social Science emphasis.
name: Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences Colloquium

desc: Introduction to the application of descriptive and and basic inferential statistics in educational research. Topics include experimental and survey design principles, measures of central tendency and variability, elementary probability concepts, basic hypothesis testing, and procedures for testing the difference between two means.
name: Introductory Statistics

desc: The theory and application of multivariate statistics, including multivariate analysis of variance, discriminant analysis, and canonical correlation. Instruction in the necessary matrix algebra will be provided.
name: Advanced Multivariate Statistics

desc: Provides an introduction to qualitative research methods,   including techniques for data collection and analysis   within   various disciplinary perspectives, experience participating   in field research methods, and qualitative data analysis   programs.
name: Introduction to Qualitative Research Methods

desc: Examines the concurrent design of learning contexts and   research on learning. Combines many different research   methods. The readings and topics are subject to change   based on students' interest.
name: Design-Based Research and Research-Based Design

desc: Overview of the historical, social, and legislative foundations of the education of the exceptional pupil. Survey of the range and nature of disabilities requiring special education.
name: Introduction to Exceptional Children

desc: Theory, practice, effectiveness and controversy. Two of the major research-based approaches to teaching academic skills to students with learning disabilities are covered.
name: Direct Instruction and Strategy Instruction

desc: Supervised field-based practicum in instruction and management of special education programs for severely handicapped pupils.
name: Practicum in Special Education Programs for Severely Handicapped Pupils

desc: Students read research and best practice studies, discuss current work in practicum placements, and develop documentation of performance and knowledgecompetencies.
name: Applied Systematic Instruction and Assessment
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Education 229C or Education E392; consent of instructor.

desc: Systematic analysis of the antecedents and consequences of administrator behavior in a variety of educational settings.
name: Educational Leadership

desc: A seminar for post-comprehensive exam students with the   intent of helpingto define areas, problems, specific   questions, and methodologies for doctoral research. Topics   and instructors may vary from quarter to quarter.
instructors: GOTTFRIED M A, BECK L M
name: Doctoral Seminar in Policy and Leadership

desc: In-depth consideration of emerging topics in teaching and learning. Course content may vary.
name: Seminar in Teaching and Learning

desc: An introduction to teacher inquiry for professional growth.   Topics include: the relationship between teacher inquiry and   classroom practice, systematic data analysis, visual   representation of findings and writing for research purposes.
instructors: SCALZO J N, OXELSON E M, SINGER G H S
name: Foundation of Teacher Inquiry
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple or Single Subject Credential   Program.

desc: Overview of linguistic, psychological, cognitive, and sociocultural approaches to second language acquisition. Students will critically review past and current SLA theories and research and develop an understanding of how language proficiency is conceptualized and assessed.
name: Second Langage Learning in Educational Contexts

desc: Course will provide a discussion of different models of education and theirimpact on changing societies and educational needs. This is a research seminar and will serve as an introduction for new students to the emphasis on Cultural perspective of Education and Comparative Education.
name: Global Education, Local Issues: Traditional and Western Education: conflictor complement?

desc: Discussion of current research, literature, and theoretical and methodological issues in language and social interaction.
name: Proseminar in Language, Interaction and Social Organization

desc: Prepares teacher candidates to create a supportive and healthy learning   environment for student learning. Helps candidates learn how personal, family,   school, community, and other contexts are related to student's academic,   physical, emotional, and social well-being.
name: Context for Child Development and Learning
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple or Single Subject   Credential Program.

desc: Prepares teacher candidates to create a supportive and healthy learning   environment for student learning. Helps candidates learn how personal, family,   school, community, and other contexts are related to student's academic,   physical, emotional, and social well-being.
name: Context for Adolescent Development and Learning
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: The application of research and theory to classroom practice in the teaching of   mathematics.
name: Elementary Mathematics Teaching Methods
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: This course is designed to provide ESC and MST credential candidate with the   knowledge and skills necessary to design and enact comprehensive English   Language Arts instruction in self-contained, integrated and inclusive K-14   classrooms.
instructors: LIPPINCOTT A WHITAKER D R, WHITAKER D R LIPPINCOTT A
name: Elementary Reading and Language Arts Teaching Methods
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Development of pedagogical content knowledge, methods,   curriculum design,research, and theory related to teaching   and learning English Language Arts at the secondary level.
name: Secondary English/Language Arts Methods
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: Development of pedagogical content knowledge, methods,   curriculum design,research, and theory related to teaching   and learning History/Social Science at the secondary level.
instructors: MULLIN C D ESTABROOK J A

timeslots.instructor: MULLIN C D ESTABROOK J A

name: Secondary History/Social Science Methods
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Development of pedagogical content knowledge, methods,   curriculum design,research, and theory related to teaching   and learning Mathematics at the secondary level.
name: Secondary Mathematics Methods
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Development of pedagogical content knowledge, methods,   curriculum design,research, and theory related to teaching   and learning Science at the secondary level.
name: Secondary Science Methods
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: This course is designed to provide credential candidates with the knowledgeand   skills necessary to design and enact comprehensive English Language Arts   instruction in self-contained, integrated and inclusive K-14 classrooms.
name: Reading and Writing in Content
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Introduces teacher candidates to concepts of effective   curriculum development including lesson design and   assessment as part of the teach-assess-reflect cycles. Also   prepares and supports candidates for the Performance Assessment of California Teachers (PACT).
name: Instructional Design for Secondary Teachers
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: Exploration of issues related to use of computer-based technologies in schools,    including their access, use and control in a democratic society; their use for   development of problem solving, critical thinking, and creativity; and their   integration into the school curriculum.
name: Instructional Technology: Elementary
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple or Single Subject   Credential Program.

desc: Exploration of issues related to use of computer-based technologies in schools,   including those of their access, use, and control in a democratic society; use for   development of problem solving, critical thinking, and creativity; and integration   into the school curriculum.
name: Instructional Technology: Secondary
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: Supervised fieldwork and student teaching in elementary schools (grades K-6)
name: Student Teaching: Elementary Schools
prequisites: Admission to the Multiple Subject Credential Program.

desc: Supervised fieldwork and student teaching in secondary English/Language Arts classrooms (grades 7-12).
name: Student Teaching: English/Language Arts Secondary
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of instructor.

desc: Supervised fieldwork in secondary History/Social Science classrooms (grades7-12).
name: Student Teaching: History/Social Science Secondary
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Supervised fieldwork in secondary Mathematics classrooms (grades 7-12).
name: Student Teaching: Mathematics Secondary
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Supervised fieldwork and student teaching in secondary Science classrooms (grades 7-12).
name: Student Teaching: Science Secondary
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of instructor.

desc: Supervised field experience of teaching content reading skills in multicultural settings for secondary teacher candidates.
name: Multicultural Reading Field Experiences
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Goal is to prepare educators who can articulately advocate   for and enact effective educational practices to ensure   English Language proficiency and academic progress for   student who are designated as English Learners.
name: ELD/SDAIE Methods and Procedures
prequisites: Enrollment in Multiple Subject or Special Education Teaching Credential   Program.

desc: A survey course in special education for students preparing   to teach at the elementary school level. Topics include   educational policy, instructional modifications and the role   of the teaching in supporting children with special needs.
name: Exceptional Children, Inclusive Classrooms
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple or Single Subject   Credential Program.

desc: A survey course in special education for students preparing   to teach at the high school level. Topics include   educational policy, instructional modification, and the   role of the teacher in supporting adolescents with special   needs.
name: Exceptional Adolescents, Inclusive Classrooms
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple or Single Subject   Credential Program.

desc: This seminar focuses on practice-based issues linked to   student teaching and includes such topics as classroom   environmental, assessment centered teaching, lesson design,   integration of the arts, and uses around school policy.   Topics differ each quarter, building on student teachers   developing expertise.
instructors: CARLYLE A M, WHITAKER D R, MEYER M N, BUMBY A K, OXELSON E M, MORALES E L
name: Professional Seminar in Teaching: Elementary
prequisites: Graduate Standing and enrollment in the Multiple Credential Program.

desc: Seminar in which teacher candidates in English/Language Arts share and discuss   their field experience, explore further avenues of teaching content, and   investigate more effective ways of engaging and supporting students.
name: Professional Issues in Teaching English/Language Arts:   Secondary
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: Seminar in which secondary teacher candidates in history/social science share   and discuss their field experience, explore further avenues of teaching content,   and investigate more effective ways of engaging and supportingstudents.
instructors: ESTABROOK J A MULLIN C D

timeslots.instructor: ESTABROOK J A MULLIN C D

name: Professional Issues in Teaching History/Social Science:   Secondary
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Seminar in which secondary teacher candidates in mathematics share and   discuss their field experience, explore further avenues of teaching content, and   investigate more effective ways of engaging and supporting students.
name: Professional Issues in Teaching Mathematics: Secondary
prequisites: Graduate standing and enrollment in The Teacher Education Program.

desc: Seminar in which teacher candidates in Science share and   discuss their field   experience, explore further avenues of teaching content,   and investigate more   effective ways of engaging and supporting students.
name: Professional Issues in Teaching Science: Secondary
prequisites: Admission to Single Subject Teaching Credential Program; and consent of   instructor.

desc: Individual tutorial in doctoral and masters' degree subprogram special fields.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Preparation for master's or Ph.D. comprehensive examinations.
name: Individual Study for Comprehensive Examinations

desc: Supervised research and writing of the thesis in doctoral and masters' degree subprograms.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Supervised research and writing of dissertation in doctoral degree subprograms.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: Designed to introduce first year students to the research   university. Topics include: the university as a community of   scholars, student subculture, student rights, university and   community, university as policy, and personal growth in   college.
name: Introduction to the University Experience

desc: Study of special problems in various fields of education   and/or faculty  supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Studies

desc: An introductory course on the development of children from infancy to adolescence. Examines developmental changes and basic developmental theories (e.g., Piaget, Vygotsky) in four general areas: cognitive, social, language, and physical development. Fulfills TEP developmental course prerequisite or Education minor.
name: Introduction to Child and Adolescent Development

desc: Introduces new transfer students to the mission of the research university,the role of higher education in society and their role, as students, withinthe community of scholars.  Topics cover academic, social and personal issues relevant to college students, specifically transfer students.
name: The Research University and The Transfer Student Experience
prequisites: Consent of instructor; must be a new transfer student.

desc: Designed for outstanding students who intern as course assistants for INT 20. Students learn a variety of issues affiliated with higher edudation inlcuding student development theories, different pedagogical techniques, and assessing learning outcomes. Students gain experience creating lesson plans,facilitating discussion, grading assignments and fostering positive learning environments.
name: Practicum in Teaching in Higher Education

desc: An examination of culturally constructed beliefs, attitudes, and values. Course examines how culture shapes human development, behavior, and interpersonal relations in culturally pluralistic environments, with an emphasis on educational settings.
name: Culture, Development, and Education

desc: A study of the relationship between school and society.   Social and political influences on education historically   and currently are examined as well as schools as complex   organizations and their unique roles in society.
name: Schooling in the U.S.

desc: Introduction to learning and teaching mathematics in grades   K-8.  The course requires attending a weekly on-campus   seminar and participating in 15hours of field placement in   a   local school.
name: CalTeach, Elementary Mathematics Education

desc: Introduction to learning and teaching mathematics in grades   7-12.  The course requires attending a weekly on-campus   seminar and participating in 15 hours of field placement in a   local school.
name: CalTeach, Secondary Mathematics Education

desc: Introduction to learning and teaching science in grade 7-12.    The course requires attending a weekly on-campus seminar and   participating in 15 hours of field placement in a local   school.
name: CalTeach, Secondary Science Education

desc: This course is an overview of theoretical constructs and practical applications of leadership. Through lectures, readings, discussions, and projects, the course will assist students in developing individual approaches to effective leadership.
name: Introduction to Leadership Development

desc: Explores how personal, family, school, community and environmental factors are related to academic, physical, emotional and social well-being. Topics include physiological and sociological effects of mental health, nutrition;sexual health; relationships; alcohol, tobacco, drug abuse. Covers childrenthrough emerging adults.
name: Health and Well-Being

desc: Study of special problems in various fields of education.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in   Education; and/or consent of   department.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in   Education; and/or consent of   department.

desc: Basic concepts in electromagnetic theory, energy power, plane waves, guidedwaves, dielectric and metallic waveguides, radiation, uniqueness, image theory,   reciprocity, duality, equivalence principle, induction theorem.
name: Electromagnetic Theory I

desc: Graduate level-matrix theory with introduction to matrix computations. SVD's, pseudoinverses, variational characterization of eigenvalues, perturbation theory, direct and iterative methods for matrix computations.
name: Matrix Analysis and Computation

desc: Weighted residual and finite element methods for the solution of hyperbolic, parabolic and elliptic partial differential equations, with application to problems in science and engineering. Error estimates. Standard and discontinuous Galerkin methods.
name: Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations--Finite Element Methods

desc: RF/Microwave circuits. Transistor, transmission-line, and passive element  characteristics. Transmission-line theory and impedance matching.  Amplifier   design for maximum available gain. Amplifier stability. Gain compression and   power limits. Introduction to noise figure, and to intermodulation distortion.
name: Communication Electronics

desc: Intensive theoretical and laboratory instruction in solid-state device and integrated circuit fabrication. Topics include 1) semiconductor material   properties and characterization; 2) phase diagrams; 3) diffusion; 4) thermal   oxidation; 5) vacuum processes; 6) thin-film deposition; 7) scanning electron   microscopy. Both gallium arsenide and silicon technologies are presented.
name: Semiconductor Device Processing

desc: Introduction to high-performance digital circuit design techniques.  Basicsof   device physics including deep submicron effects; device sizing and logical effort;   Circuit design styles; clocking & timing issues; memory & datapath design; Low-  power design; VLSI design flows and associated EDA tools.
name: High-Performance Digital Circuit Design
prequisites: ECE 2A-B-C with a minimum grade of C- in all.

desc: Review of semiconductor physics, growth technology, and   materials properties;   double-heterostructure and quantum-well laser structures;   carrier and photon   rate equations; light vs. current characteristics;   scattering and transmission   matrices; compound cavity, distributed bragg reflector,   and distributed   feedback lasers.
name: Semiconductor Lasers I
prequisites: ECE 162A-B-C, or MATRL 162A-B and ECE 162C, or ECE 144.

desc: Optical fiber structures and guided modes. Effect of dispersion, attenuation and fiber, nonlinearities. Basic transmission design including loss and rise time budgets. Optical transmission system essentials and requirements. Introduction to WDM and TDM components and technologies.
name: Fiber Optic Communications

desc: Internal and external descriptions. Solution of state equations. Controllability and observability realizations. Pole assignment, observers;modern compensator design. Disturbance localization and decoupling. Least-squares control. Least-squares estimation; kalman filters; smoothing,the separation theorem; LQG compensator design. Computational considerations. Selected additional topics.
name: Linear Systems I

desc: A first-year graduate course in Stochas TIC processes, including: review ofbasic   probability; gaussian, poisson, and Weiner processes; wide-sense stationary   processes; covariance function and power spectral density; linear systems   driven   by random inputs; basic Wiener and Kalman filter theory.
name: Stochastic Processes in Engineering

desc: Review of probability and random waveforms, optimum receiver principles, efficient signaling, bounds on error probability, convolutional coding, channel capacity; emphasis on geometric approach to signal description.
name: Digital Communication Theory

desc: Design and application of embedded computing systems, particular attention paid to computation system design in highly constrained environments. System   synthesis and modeling techniques including partitioning, scheduling, control   and data flow analysis and functional representation. Embedded project design.
name: Embedded System Design

desc: Design and application aspects of high-performance uniprocessors and sharedmemory multiprocessors. Memory design issues: cache memories, address   translation, shared memory buses and switches, transactional memory.   Processor design issues: instruction sets, pipelining, vector processing,   superscalar instruction dispatch, speculative execution, multicore processors.
name: Advanced Computer Architecture: Processor Design

desc: Calculus of variations and Gateaux and Frechet derivatives. Optimization indynamic systems and Pontryagin’s principle. Invariant Imbedding and   deterministic and stochastic Dynamic Programming.  Numerical solutions of   optimal control problems. Min-max problems and differential games.  Extensive  treatment of Linear Quadratic Problems.
name: Optimal Control of Dynamic Systems

desc: Two-dimensional signals and systems. Two-dimension al fourier and z-  transforms. Discrete fourier transform, two-dimensional digital filters. Image  processing basics, image enhancement and restoration. Special image   processing software available for laboratory experimentation.
name: Digital Image Processing

desc: Principles and techniques for combating channel errors in   data   transmission or   storage. Introduction to galois fields. Linear blockcodes   (particularly   hamming,   BCH, reed-solomon). Convolutional codes. Encoding anddecoding   algorithms   (including spectral methods, maximum likelihood andviterbi decoding.)
name: Error Correcting Codes

desc: Dynamic modeling and control methods for robotic systems.   LaGrangian method   for   deriving equations of motion, introduction to the   Jacobian,   and modeling and   control of forces and contact dynamics at a robotic end effector. Laboratories   encourage a problem-solving approach to control.
name: INTRODUCTION TO ROBOTICS: DYNAMICS AND CONTROL
prequisites: ECE 130A or ME 155A (may be taken concurrently).

desc: A series of weekly lectures given by university staff and outside experts in the fields of control systems, dynamical systems, and computation.
name: Group Studies: Controls, Dynamical Systems, and Computation

desc: Special projects for selected students. Offered in conjunction with engineering practice in selected industrial and research firms, under direct faculty supervision.
name: Internship in Industry
prequisites: Prior departmental approval needed. ECE majors only.

desc: Procedures and techniques for teaching electrical engineering or computer engineering gained through actual teaching of lecture courses, leading discussion sections, and/or teaching engineering laboratories. Meetings will be held as needed to discuss problems, methods, and procedures.
name: Teaching of Electrical and Computer Engineering

desc: Instruction in these variable unit courses may be carried out by lecture, by   laboratory, or by a combination of these. These courses provide a studyof   topics of current interest in various areas of electrical and computerengineering.
name: Nanotechnology
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate standing.

desc: Instruction in research group meetings carried out by lecture, by laboratory, or by a combination of the two. Courses provide a critical review of research in various areas of electrical and computer engineering. C. communication systems.
instructors: ROSE K, SHYNK J J, LEE H, BOWERS J E, COLDREN L, MAREK-SADOWSK, MANJUNATH B S
name: Group Studies in Electrical and Computer Engineering

desc: Instruction in research group meetings carried out by lecture, by laboratory, or by a combination of the two. These courses provide critical review ofresearch in various areas of electrical and computer engineering.
name: Group Studies in Electrical and Computer Engineering: Scientific Computation

desc: Research, either experimental or theoretical; may be undertaken by properlyqualified graduate students under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Directed Research

desc: Individual studies for M.S. comprehensive examinations and Ph.D. examinations.
name: Individual Studies for M.S. Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations

desc: For research underlying the thesis and writing of the thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Research and preparation of dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of chair of student's doctoral committee.

desc: The objective of the course is to establish the   foundations   of analog and digital circuits. The course will introduce   the student to the power of abstraction, resistive   networks, network analysis, nonlinear analysis and the   digital abstraction.
name: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits & Systems
prequisites: Mathematics 3A-B or Mathematics 3AH-BH, and Mathematics 4A or 4AI or 3C   with a minimum grade of C; and, Math 4B or 4BI or 5A with a minimum   grade of C (may be taken concurrently); Physics 3 or 23 (may be taken   concurrently); open only to electrical engineering and computer   engineering majors.

desc: The goal of 10AL is to provide the student with a hands-on   application ofthe concepts discussed in ECE 10A. The lab   will introduce the use of microcontrollers as a data   acquisition system, network analysis, resistors, nonlinear   analysis and digital abstraction.
name: Foundations of Analog and Digital Circuits and Systems Lab
prequisites: ECE 10A (may be taken concurrently) with a C- or better grade.

desc: Introduction to CMOS digital VLSI design: CMOS devices and   manufacturing technology; transistor level design of static   and dynamic logic gates andcomponents and interconnections;   circuit characterization: delay, noise  margins, and power dissipation; combinational and sequential   circuits; arithmetic operations and memories.
name: VLSI Principles
prequisites: ECE 152A with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Introduction to high-performance digital circuit design techniques.   Basics of   device physics including deep submicron effects; device sizing and  logical   effort; Circuit design styles; clocking & timing issues; memory &datapath   design; Low-power design; VLSI design flows and associated EDA  tools.
name: High-Performance Digital Circuit Design
prequisites: ECE 10A-B-C and ECE 10AL-10BL-10CL or ECE 2A-B-C with a minimum grade of   C- in each of those courses; open to both electrical engineering and   computer engineering majors only.

desc: Analysis of continuous time linear systems in the time and frequency   domains.   Superposition and convolution. Bilateral and unilateral Laplace   transforms.   Fourier series and Fourier transforms. Filtering, modulation, and   feedback.
name: Signal Analysis and Processing
prequisites: Mathematics 4B or 5A with a minimum of grade of C and ECE 2B or ECE 10B & ECE 10BL   with a minimum grade of C- in each course; open to EE and computer engineering majors   only.

desc: Electrons and holes in semiconductors; doping (P and N); state   occupationstatistics, transport properties of electrons and holes; P-N junction   diodes; I-V,   C-V, and switching properties of P-N junctions; introduction ofbipolar   transitors, MOSFET's and JFET's.
name: Introduction to Solid-State Electronic Devices
prequisites: Physics 4 or 24 with a minimum grade of C-; Mathematics 4B or 5A with a   minimum grade of C; and ECE 10A-B and ECE 10AL-10BL or ECE 2A-B (may be   taken concurrently) with a minimum grade of C- in each; open to EE and   computer engineering majors only.

desc: Introduction to applied electromagnetics and wave   phenomena in high   frequency   electron circuits and systems. Waves on transmission-  lines, elements of   electrostatics and magnetostatics and applications, plane   waves,   examples and   applications to RF, microwave, and optical systems.
name: Introduction to Fields and Waves
prequisites: Physics 3 or 23 with a minimum grade of C-; Mathematics 4B or 4BI or 5A   and Mathematics 5B or 6A or 6AI with a minimum grade of C in each; and   Mathematics 5C or 6B with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE   and computer engineering majors only.

desc: RF/Microwave circuits. Transistor, transmission-line, and passive element  characteristics. Transmission-line theory and impedance matching.  Amplifier   design for maximum available gain. Amplifier stability. Gain compression and   power limits. Introduction to noise figure, and to intermodulation distortion.
name: Communication Electronics
prequisites: ECE 137A-B with a minimum grade of C- in both.

desc: Communication signals and systems; channel modeling and transceiver signal processing in complex baseband; analog communication techniques, including amplitude and angle modulation, superheterodyne reception, and phase lockedloops; digital modulation, including bandwidth-efficient linear modulation and orthogonal modulation.
name: Communication Systems
prequisites: ECE 130A-B with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE majors only.

desc: Feedback systems design, specifications in time and   frequency domains. Analysis and synthesis of closed loope   systems. Computer aided analysis anddesign.
