name: Feedback Control Systems - Theory and Design
prequisites: ECE 130A-B with a minimum grade of C- in each; open to electrical   engineering and computer engineering majors only.

desc: Design of synchronous digital systems: timing diagrams, propagation   delay, latches and flip-  flops, shift registers and counters, Mealy/Moore finite state   machines, Verilog, 2-phase   clocking, timing analysis, CMOS implementation, S-RAM, RAM-based   designs, ASM charts, state   minimization.
name: Digital Design Principles
prequisites: ECE 15A and ECE 2A or ECE 10A & ECE 10AL with a minimum grade of C- in eachcourse;   or   Computer Science 30 or 64 with a minimum grade of C- in eachcourse; open to   electrical   engineering, computer engineering, and computer science majors only.

desc: Issues in interfacing computing systems and software to   practical I/O interfaces.   Rapid response, real-time events and management of tasks,   threads, and   scheduling required for efficient design of embedded   software and systems is   discussed. Techniques for highly constrained systems.
name: Hardware/Software Interface
prequisites: Upper division standing in Computer Engineering, Computer Science and   Electrical Engineering.

desc: Instruction-set architecture (ISA) and computer performance;   Machine instructions, assembly, addressing modes; Memory   map,arrays, pointers; Procedure calls; Number formats;   Simple ALUs; Data path,control, microprogram; Buses, I/O   programming, interrupts; Pipelined data paths and control schemes.
name: Introduction to Computer Architecture
prequisites: ECE 152A with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE and CMPEN majors only.

desc: Introduction to VHDL basic elements. VHDL simulation concepts. VHDL concurrent statements with examples and applications. VHDL subprograms, packages, libraries and design units. Writing vhdl for synthesis. Writing VHDL for finite state machines. Design case study.
name: Digital Design With VHDL and Synthesis
prequisites: ECE 152A with a minimum grade of C-.

desc: Discrete signals and systems, convolution, Z-transforms, discrete fourier transforms, digital filters.
name: Digital Signal Processing
prequisites: ECE 130A-B with a minimum grade of C-; open to EE majors only.

desc: Electrons as particles and waves, Schrodinger's equation and illustrative solutions.   Tunnelling. Atomic structure, the exclusion principle and the periodic table. Bonds.   Free   electrons in metals, periodic potentials andenergy bands.
name: The Quantum Description of Electronic Materials
prequisites: ECE 130A-B and 134 with a minimum grade of C- in all; open to EE, seniors  in the BS/MS program and Materials graduate students only.

desc: Basic concepts in image and video processing. Topics include image formation and sampling, image transforms, image enhancement, and image and video compression including JPEG and MPEG coding standards.
name: Introduction to Digital Image and Video Processing
prequisites: Open to electrical engineering, computer engineering, and computer science majors with upper-division standing.

desc: Dynamic modeling and control methods for robotic systems.  LaGrangian   method for deriving equations of motion, introduction to the Jacobian, and   modeling and control of forces and contact dynamics at a robotic end effector.    Laboratories encourage a problem-solving approach to control.
name: INTRODUCTION TO ROBOTICS: DYNAMICS AND CONTROL
prequisites: ECE 130A or ME 155A (may be taken concurrently).

desc: Student groups design a significant project based on the   knowledge and skills acquired in earlier coursework and   integrate their technical knowledge through a practical   design experience. The project is evaluated through written   reports, oral presentations, and demonstrations of   performance.
name: Senior Electrical Engineering Project

desc: Student groups design a significant computer-based project.   Groups work independently with interaction among groups via   interface specifications and informal meetings.
name: Senior Computer Systems Project
prequisites: ECE 153B; senior standing in Computer Engineering, Computer Science or EE.

desc: Projects in electrical and computer engineering for advanced undergraduate students.
name: Projects in Electrical and Computer Engineering

desc: Special projects for selected students. Offered in conjunction with engineering practice in selected industrial and research firms, under direct faculty supervision.
name: Internship in Industry

desc: Research opportunities for undergraduate students. students will be expected to give regular oral presentations, actively participate in a weekly seminar, and prepare at least one written report on their research.
name: Undergraduate Research
prequisites: Students must: (1) have attained upper division standing, (2) have a minimu3.0 grade-point average for preceding three quarters, (3) consent of instructor.

desc: Directed individual study, normally experimental.
name: Independent Studies in Electrical and Computer Engineering
prequisites: Consent of instructor; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-diviscourse in Electrical and Computer Engineering.

desc: Seminar series highlighting current topics and advances   in   bioengineering presented by UCSB faculty or visiting   scientists providing   context and motivation   for bioengineering learning, introducing students to   concepts outside of   their primary research specialty, and promoting   interdisciplinary thinking   and research collaboration.
name: Current Topics in Bioengineering

desc: Seminar series where students present their original   thesis research and also review journal articles that critically analyze   contemporary   bioengineering research. Three quarters of ENGR 230 are   required for the   optional BioE graduate   emphasis. Presentations will be evaluated and feedback   provided.
name: Bioengineering Student Seminar

desc: General philosophy of programming and problem-solving.   Students will   beintroduced to the programming language MATLAB. Specific   areas of   study will   include algorithms,  basic decision structures, arrays,   matrices, and   graphing.
instructors: WU TIE, YANG ZHENYU, ZHANG A, POVERELLI J S, PEREIRA JACOB
name: Introduction to Programming

desc: The nature of moral value, normative judgment and moral reasoning. Theoriesof   moral value. The engineer's role in society. Ethics in professional practice. Safety,   risk, responsibility. Morality and career choice. Code ofethics. Case studies   facilitate the comprehension of the concepts introduced.
instructors: HOUGH K C PENG C, HOUGH K C MELCZER R S

timeslots.instructor: HOUGH K C MELCZER R S

name: Ethics in Engineering

desc: This course allows the coordination of senior students in multiple   departments   while they undertake a multi-departmental capstone design project. Participating students are required to concurrently enroll in their   respective   departmental capstone/senior design project courses (CE 189AB, CS  189AB, EE   188AB, ME 189ABC), and will additionally enroll in 1 unit of this   course for   the Fall, Winter and Spring quarters. By taking this course, students   will   understand practical engineering approaches to collaborate on   complex   multidisciplinary engineering systems.
name: Multidisciplinary Capstone Design

desc: Directed individual study.
name: Independent Studies in Engineering

desc: Course will vary from quarter to quarter.
name: Studies in Restoration and Eighteenth Century Literature

desc: Content of course will vary from quarter to quarter.
name: Studies in Nineteenth-Century Literature

desc: Content of course will vary from quarter to quarter.
name: Studies in Twentieth-Century Literature

desc: Content of course will vary from quarter to quarter.
instructors: WAID C J, DELOMBARD J M
name: Studies in American Literature

desc: Content of course will vary from quarter to quarter.
name: Studies in Literary Criticism and Theory

desc: Graduate tutorial involving regular conferences with instructor and directed research toward seminar paper(s). Attendance at relevant upper-division lectures also required.
name: Graduate Studies

desc: Supervision and instruction of teaching assistants. Teaching assistants must register for this course.
name: Directed Teaching

desc: Course provides support for graduate students when developing their dissertation ideas. Focus on research in the humanities at a practical level.
name: Doctoral Colloquium

desc: Individual tutorial. A written proposal for each tutorial   must be approvedby the graduate adviser.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Instructor should be the student's major professor or chair of   the doctoral committee.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Exams and Ph.D.   Exams

desc: Only for research underlying the dissertation, writing the dissertation.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in English 15 designed to enrich the large lecture experience for the motivated student. Course includes either supplementary reading or more intensive study of the English 15 reading list, as well as supplemental writing.
name: Seminar on Shakespeare
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in English 15; consent of instructor.

desc: Seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in   English 22 designed to enrich the large lecture experience for   the motivated student. Course includes either supplementary   reading or more intensive study of the English 22 reading   list, as well as supplemental writing.
name: Seminar on Literature and the Environment
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in English 22; consent of instructor.

desc: Introduction to research in English. Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional studentsthe opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group.
name: Introduction to Research
prequisites: ENGLISH 10 OR 10AC OR 10EM OR 10LC; MINIMUM 3.0 CUMULATIVE GRADE-POINT AVERAGE; AND CONSENT OF INSTRUCTOR AND DEPARTMENT.

desc: A seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in one of the following courses: English 113AA-ZZ, 114AA-ZZ, 128AA-ZZ, 131-134AA-ZZ, 165AA-ZZ, 182AA-ZZ, and 187AA-ZZ. Designed to enrich the lecture experience for the movtivated student. Course includes either supplementary readings, or more extensive study of the reading lists as well as supplementary writing.
name: Honors Seminar
prequisites: Writing 2 or 50 or 109 or English 10 or upper-division standing; consent ofinstructor.

desc: Seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in English 101 designed to enrich the large lecture experience for the motivated student. Course will include either supplementary readings or more intensive study of English 101 reading list, as well as supplemental writing.
name: Seminar on English Literature from the Medieval Period to 1650
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in English 101; consent of instructor.

desc: Seminar course for a select number of students enrolled in English 103A designed to enrich the large lecture experience for the motivated student. Course will include either supplementary readings or more intensive study of English 103A reading list, as well as supplemental writing.
name: Seminar on American Literature from 1789 to 1900
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in English 103; consent of instructor.

desc: Courses on American writing associated with particular regions such as the South, the West, New England.
instructors: WAID C J, URCAREGUI M J, GERSON S M, DIB N, NORRIS L F
name: Studies in American Regional Literature

desc: Under supervision of English Department faculty, English majors may obtain credit for work without pay in publishing, editing, journalism, or other employment related to English literature. Required are work hours, weekly meeting with professor, and a final paper or journal.
name: Internship in English
prequisites: Upper-division standing; English majors only; consent of department.

desc: For students in the English department's honors program only. English 196, which is taken after English 198H in the honors program, focuses on the writing of a 35+ page senior thesis.
name: Honors English Senior Thesis
prequisites: Writing 2 or upper-division standing; consent of department; successful completion of English 198H.

desc: Reading and conference for students with upper-division standing.
name: Independent Studies in English
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in English; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Independent research assistance in English. Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistant in English
prequisites: Upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in English; consent of instructor; consent of department.

desc: Energy and mass transport as applied to the atmosphere, oceans, and land models of the earth's climate and hydrology.
instructors: DUNNE T DOZIER J C, BRANDT W T, STILLINGER T
name: Earth System Science
prequisites: Geography 3 or equivalent; graduate standing in ESM.

desc: Develop skills and conceptual framework to effectively   use data to solve practical   problems. Topics include descriptive statistics,   hypothesis testing, experimental   design, exploratory data analysis, probability and  uncertainty, time series   analysis, and spatial stats. Emphasis on case studies   from environmental problems.
instructors: HORST A M, HORST A M FITZGERALD S
name: Data Analysis for Environmental Science and Management

desc: Basic elements of the legal system as it specifically   relates to environmental   issues. Study of the different stages and different   institutions involved in   environmental policy making.
name: Environmental Law and Policy
prequisites: GRADUATE STANDING IN ESM OR CONSENT OF INSTRUCTOR.

desc: Microbes are the most abundant organisms on earth and are responsible for most biogeochemical cycling. Who and where are they, what do they do, and how? This course provides an integrated understanding applicable to managing the environment and natural resources.
name: Microbial Processes in the Environment

desc: Introduction to laboratory based tools and techniques for detecting and numerating, and describing what microbes do in natural and polluted samples.
name: Laboratory in Microbial Processes

desc: Integrates environmental science and management to   address   sustainable watershed management. Learn the elements of a   watershed management plan and become familiar with the   planning process that takes into consideration various   issues and concerns and provides concrete actions to   address them. Addresses both water quantity and quality issues in   a   comprehensive approach.
instructors: KELLER A A PARKER N A

timeslots.instructor: KELLER A A PARKER N A
KELLER A A PARKER N A

name: Sustainable Watershed Quality Management

desc: Explores key water policy issues in the context of science,   technology, and the practical management of water systems.   Focuses on the nexus of science, technology, economics,   law, and the role social and political factors play in the   policy process.
name: Water Policy

desc: Introduction to the development, evaluation, interpretation, and presentation of models as applied to environmental problems. Course consists of theory and many practical examples building and interpreting models using computers.
name: Environmental Modeling

desc: Economic principles and policy issues of the use of exhaustible and renewable resources including fossil fuels, water, minerals, fisheries, forests, and biodiversity. Management of resource markets on regional and international scale.
name: Natural Resource Economics and Policy

desc: Economic theory of environmental policy, with special emphasis on the role of cost-benefit analysis. Techniques for estimating economic values for nonmarket environmental resources. Case studies involving ecosystem protection, pollution control, and other topics to illustrate the necessary analytical tools.
instructors: LIBECAP G D SZMURLO D A

timeslots.instructor: LIBECAP G D SZMURLO D A

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis and Nonmarket Valuation

desc: Introduction to entrepreneurship for students interested in   launching a new product or service that offers an   environmental and/or social benefit.Provides an   entrepreneurial perspective and overview of the venture   creation process.  Emphasis on idea generation, opportunity   recognition and initial concept development.
name: Introduction to Entrepreneurship and New Venture Creation

desc: Overview of international, U.S. and California coastal and marine policy and management, including case studies and tools that can be used to inform and shape current and future policy and management actions
name: Coastal Marine Policy & Management

desc: In depth development and analysis of a specific   conservation plan,   fromstart (goal setting) to finish (spatially explicit   recommendations). Practical application of theory and   tools from   ESM270. If appropriate, MESMGroup Project locations can   be used   as the case study.
instructors: LARSEN A E LIU O R

timeslots.instructor: LARSEN A E LIU O R

name: Conservation Planning Practicum

desc: Using the BSI’s PAS 2050, the WRI’s GHG Protocols, and   the   ISO14067, basic skills and knowledge necessary to   establish   corporate carbon accounts and to calculate carbon   footprints will be covered.
name: Carbon footprints and Carbon Accounting

desc: Principles, concepts, and techniques of environmental planning at the state, regional, and local government levels, with emphasis on emerging trends in addressing environmental problems. Green plans, sustainable communities, coastal planning, agricultural land preservation, smart development, new urbanism, and mitigation monitoring.
name: Principles and Practice of Environmental Planning

desc: Covers the main physical principles of energy conversion and the environmental impacts related to it. Also explores the balance between resource availability and demand, and the relationship between energy use and technology.
name: Energy, Technology and the Environment

desc: Advanced topics in environmental law.
name: Advanced Special Topics in Environmental Law

desc: Covers advanced special topics in environmental management.
instructors: WILKINSON R C, FREW J E, GAINES S, POTOSKI M
name: Advanced Special Topics in Environmental Management

desc: Second quarter of a year-long group study of an environmental problem.
instructors: BUNTAINE M T, CAYLOR K K, COSTELLO C J, TAGUE C L, GAINES S, FREW J E, GEYER R, HOLDEN P A, KELLER A A, KENDALL B E, LENIHAN H S, LIBECAP G D, MELACK J M, PLANTINGA A, LARSEN A E, SALZMAN J E
name: Group Project in Environmental Science and Management

desc: Second quarter of a year-long team project to develop a new   environmentalventure.
instructors: SUH S COTTER E E, POTOSKI M COTTER E E, DOZIER J C COTTER E E

timeslots.instructor: DOZIER J C COTTER E E

name: Masters Eco-E Project

desc: Provides the skills to write effectively across academic   and applied genres in the   environmental sciences. A focus on understanding   audience, good writing mechanics,   and the principles of good scientific and analytical   writing will help students   “translate science” effectively. Topics include thesis,   audience, tone,   organization, structure, and citations. Also covers   writing styles and formats   likely encountered in an environmental career, such as   proposals, evaluations,   writing for the public, and professional correspondence.
name: Writing Skills for Environmental Professionals

desc: Hands-on course designed to give students the core skills   needed to conceptualize,   capture, edit, and deliver short-form environmental   documentaries. The basic tools   of film-making --cinematography, lighting, sound, and   editing -- are covered.
name: Intro to Enviro Media Production

desc: Students will learn about interdisciplinary research conducted by Bren School   faculty and will be exposed to diverse perspectives about the process of   conducting interdisciplinary research. Students will attend research seminars   given by four faculty members, read manuscripts or published papers on this   research, and have discussions with the faculty members about their approaches   to research.
name: Faculty Research Speaker Series

desc: Combines two interrelated topics: proposal writing and   research ethics.  Research ethics comprises (1) Plagiarism, falsification   and fabrication; (2)   conflict of interest; and (3) authorship and peer review   process. We will   review historical cases of research misconduct and   institutionalmechanisms at   UCSB for prevention of research misconduct. Proposal   writing covers relevant   funding sources, proposal review processes, strategies,   tips and advice.   Students will prepare a proposal for a pre-doctoralfellowship, to be   evaluated by peers and discussed during class.
name: Conduct & Professional Skills for Interdisciplinary   Research

desc: Course will review psychological, political, and sociological theories and their implications for the environment and public policy issues related to sustainability. Potential topics include message framing, norms and attitude change, culture, and identity. These theoretical foundations will be usedto design and carry out research projects.
name: Psychology, Environment, and Public Policy

desc: A critical review of research in selected fields of   environmental scienceand management.
instructors: TAGUE C L, HOLDEN P A
name: Group Studies

desc: Individualized reading and research. A written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the school.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual study for Ph.D. examinations.
name: Individual Study for Ph.D. Examinations
prequisites: Graduate standing. Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Research toward and writing of dissertation. Instructor should be chair of student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing; consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Architecture is an act of place-making with which man has intertwined ever closer his world with the natural one. The course discusses basic architectural construction methods, discipline-specific terminology, design strategies, and interpretative concepts. Students must keep a visual, architecturaljournal.
instructors: WELTER V W, CHASE M M, LYNCH A P, JAMESON-ELLSM
name: Introduction to Architecture and Environment

desc: Honors section to explore in greater depth topics and   issues covered by ARTHI 5A. Requires concurrent enrollment   in ARTHI 5A.
name: Introduction to Architecture and Environment Honors Section
prequisites: Consent of instructor; Concurrent enrollment in ARTHI 5A

desc: History of western art from its origins to the beginnings of the renaissance.
instructors: MOSER C H, GIMENEZ S L, GREGO MARCH C, GOOD F E, FAUST M R, RAYMOND A C, KAGAN-MOORE H, PARISON A L, WINTER R E, MORRIS S C, COBRA LIMA L
name: Art Survey I: Ancient-Medieval Art

desc: A selective and chronological survey of architecture and urban design in social and historical context. Individual buildings and urban plans from the past to the present will be used as examples.
instructors: WITTMAN R K, BANE S N, BOLLI C M
name: Survey: Architecture and Planning

desc: A survey of Islamic art and architecture.
instructors: KHOURY N N, FATHI S, FREIHERR VON
name: Survey: Islamic Art and Architecture

desc: This course explores the soaring cathedrals, monstrous sculptures, and   marvelous images that inspired The Lord of the Rings and Game of Thrones.   Beginning with the fourth-century rise of Christian images and ending with the   advent of print, it traces how images developed new roles – and reinvented old   ones – over the course of the Middle Ages. Investigating architecture,   sculpture, and manuscripts in their historical contexts, it asks why medieval   objects look the way the do and how viewers saw them.
name: Introduction to Medieval Art and Architecture

desc: Examines the life and work of Gianlorenzo Bernini, best known as a brilliant and innovative sculptor, in their historical context. Also considered is the international influence that Bernini exerted on seventeenth- and eighteeth-century art.
name: Bernini and the Age of the Baroque

desc: Special topics in twentieth-century modern art.
name: Special Topics in Twentieth-Century Modern Art

desc: Painting, sculpture, architecture and decorative arts in the original 13 colonies, through the formation of the United States, to the crisis of the Civil War. Particular attention paid to environmental and social issues.
name: American Art from Revolution to Civil War: 1700-1860

desc: The relationship of art to life in sub-Saharan Africa. A   cross-cultural survey of types, styles, history, and values of   arts ranging from personaldecoration to the state festival,   stressing Ashanti, Ife, Benin, Yoruba, Cameroon.
name: African Art I

desc: Beginning with the Islamic Medieval and Renaissance arts of Spain, this course will chart their influence and transformation in the sixteenth and seventeenth century arts of the new world. Special emphasis on the creativeinteraction of the European and indigenous traditions in colonial arts of the Americans.
name: The Arts of Spain and New Spain

desc: An introduction to the development of Manga (Japanese comics) in relation to other world-wide graphic narrative traditions, with special emphasis on  visual analysis and historical context.
name: Understanding Manga

desc: Course examines history and theory of sustainable and "green" architecture since the   early twentieth century. Emphasis is placed on the critical analysis of a distinct   "green" architectural aesthetic; the scope is global.
name: Sustainable Architecture: History and Aesthetics

desc: Between 1770 and 1871, the German speaking lands of Europe experienced bothpolitical unification and an astounding cultural rebirth (Kant, Hegel, Goethe, Beethoven, Brahms, Wagner, Marx, Nietzsche...). This blossoming extended to architecture and town planning as well, as the region transformed itself into one of Europe's most vibrant laboratories for theory and design. This course will examine this remarkable period of change by examining architecture, town planning, and some architectural theory (in translation) in their larger cultural and political contexts.
name: Architecture and Theory in Germany and Austria (1770-1870)

desc: Under supervision of art history faculty, students may obtain   credit for work in a museum, gallery, or art related business.   Three hours per week per unit (total 30 hours/unit)   internship, plus regular meetings and final evaluation   session. Written report required.
name: Internship
prequisites: Not open to freshmen; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Under supervision of art history faculty, students may obtain credit for work in   the University Art Museum, three hours per week per unit (total 30 hours/unit)   internship, plus weekly meetings and final evaluation session. Written report   required.
instructors: ROBERTSON E B GOORAY M N

timeslots.instructor: ROBERTSON E B GOORAY M N

name: University Art Museum Internship
prequisites: Not open to freshmen; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Under supervision of Art History faculty, student may obtain   credit for work in the Architecture and Design Collection,   three hours per week per unit (total 30 hours/unit), plus   meetings and final evaluation session, written report   required.
instructors: ROBERTSON E B GOORAY M N

timeslots.instructor: ROBERTSON E B GOORAY M N

name: Architecture and Design Collection Internship

desc: Introduction to Russian art and aesthetic theory from the   beginning to the present. Readings and lectures in English.
name: Russian Art

desc: Special topics in the history of art and architecture.
name: Special topics in Art History

desc: Examines a range of issues—art historical, cultural,   political, practical, and theoretical—that conditioned the   development of museums and collections, primarily in   Europe, from the Renaissance to the present day. Topics and   format will vary.
name: Museums in Transition: From the Early Modern to the Modern   Period

desc: Advanced individual problems.    Each unit requires 30 hours per quarter ofwork from the   student.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; two upper-division courses in art history; consentof instructor and department.

desc: Examines effective teaching methods and professional conduct and responsibilities. Emphasis on teaching aids, examination preparation, and grading. Includes general orientation regarding the University of California and UCSB campus; various pertinent regulations; and services available to teaching assistants and to students.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Students gain practical experience in teaching while coordinating one or more discussion/lab sections. Responsibilities include analyses of course texts/materials, discussion/lab sections, and formulation of topics/ questionsfor papers and examinations. Evaluations are completed by members of the class sections.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum
prequisites: Concurrent appointment as a teaching assistant in environmental studies.

desc: Individual tutorial. Hours and credit by arrangement with an individual faculty member in environmental studies. Written proposal for each tutorial must be approved by the instructor and the department chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Enrolled graduate student at UCSB; consent of instructor and department.

desc: "Environmental Studies" requires insights from many disciplines, including the social as well as biophysical science and the humanities. This introduction offers an overview of the field, examining both our planet and the ways in which we humans depend on it.
instructors: HIROYASU E H, CRAWFORD V D, MILJANICH C P, HARDESTY MOOR, WELCH Z S, COLBY J C
name: Introduction to Environmental Studies

desc: Economic processes underlie many of the environmental   problems facing   humanity, but can also play an important   role in solving those challenges.This course introduces   key theories from   micro- and macroeconomics, andapplies   them to a variety of environmental problems. Topics   covered include   individual preferences, efficiency,   valuation, market failures andpolicy analysis.
name: Introduction to Environmental Economics

desc: Visit local natural areas to gain hands-on experience in   facets of ecological restoration including project planning,   site assessment, invasive species management, plant   identification and propagation, vegetation and water quality   monitoring, and wildlife observation.  Internships available at conclusion of course.
name: Introduction to Ecological Restoration Field Skills

desc: Introduction to curation of natural history collections including vertebrate,   plants, algae and lichen. Learn to collect, prepare, catalog, and preserve   specimens via lectures, hands-on activities, and field trips. Collection focus   changes quarterly. Internships available at conclusion of the course.
name: Introduction to Curation of Natural History Collections

desc: Directed study under the guidance of an environmental studies faculty   member. Course offers motivated students an opportunity to undertake   independent or collaborative research for faculty-directed research   projects. Topic and scope varies, to be specified by student and   supervisory faculty member prior to registration.
name: Introduction to Research

desc: A study of principles of ecology and their implications   for analyzing   environmental problems. Focus on understanding the   processes controlling the   dynamics of populations,communities and ecosystems.   Specific examples   emphasize the application of these concepts to the   management of natural   resources.
instructors: BENNETT M K, BRIGLIO T L, MA S A, LONG R W
name: Environmental Ecology
prequisites: Environmental Studies 2; and Environmental Studies 1 or 3; and MCDB 20 or  EEMB 22 or MCDB 1A and EEMB 2. OR MCDB 1A and MCDB 1B and EEMB 2 and EEMB  3.

desc: An in-depth examination of critical thinking in environmental   contexts. Identification of   deceptive methods of environmental critique and debate in policy and   public matters.   Comprehension of approaches to environmental solutions as well as   common thinking traps   in developing such solutions. Emphasis on reasoning patterns and   leverage points of   environmental arguments, systems thinking about environmental   problems and solutions,exploration of common errors in scientific reasoning, and framing   scientific and   environmental issues for clarity and effective communication.
instructors: BRECK J L, STIEFEL M S
name: Critical Thinking About Human-Environment Problems and   Solutions
prequisites: Environmental Studies 1 and 3 and upper-division standing.

desc: Explores the turbulent, contested, and colorful history of   human interactions with wild animals in North America from  the Pleistocene to the present.  Readings will explore   historical changes in science, politics, law, management,   and cultural ideas about nature.
name: Wildlife in America

desc: Introduction to the chemical, hydrological, and biological characteristics of soils, their global distribution, and  response to management. Field andlaboratory projects provide an understanding of soil-landscape distribution, soil morphology, and the physical and chemical properties that influence management decisions.
instructors: VOSS K A, CHADWICK O A
name: Soil Science

desc: Industrial Ecology is a philosophical and methodical framework interwoven with concepts in ecology and economics used to aid in understanding of how industrial systems interact with the environment. Capital, energy, and material flows are examined and viewed in cultural context.
name: Industrial Ecology: Designing for the Environment

desc: Explore ecological processes in California habitats and the   challenges oftheir management through field trips,   discussions with land managers, lectures and readings. Focus   on regional habitats including specialized habitats such as   coastal salt marsh and vernal pools, and more widespread such   as oak savanna and chaparral.
name: Ecology and Management of California Wildlands
prequisites: Environmental Studies 100 or EEMB 120 or EEMB 168.

desc: Effects and implications for the future of introducing toxins into the biosphere.   Examination of physiological and biochemical effects and the mechanisms of action   of the potential toxins. Discussion of methodological approaches and legal   ramifications of studies in environmental toxicology.
name: Toxics in the Environment
prequisites: Environmental Studies 2; MCDB 20 or EEMB 22 or MCDB 1A-AL and EEMB 2;   Chemistry 1A and 1B or Environmental Studies 15A and 15B.

desc: Course explores the theories and practices of psychologists, educators, andothers whose work is focused on the connections between "inner" human nature and "outer" nature within which humans experience themselves and the restof the world.
name: Ecopsychology

desc: Examines human dimensions of global environmental change in developing   countries from an interdisciplinary social science perspective.  Compares andcontrasts alternative conceptual and analytical models of dynamic, interrelated   human-environmental systems and presents recent approaches to   understanding risk, vulnerability, resilience, and disasters.
name: Coupled Human and Natural Systems: Risks, Vulnerability, Resilience, and   Disasters

desc: Course examines history and theory of sustainable and "green"   architecture since the early twentieth century. Emphasis is placed   on the critical analysis of a distinct "green" architectural   aesthetic; the scope is global.
name: Sustainable Architecture: History and Aesthetics

desc: Analysis of the practices of environmentally responsible firms   and of thedrivers of business greening at the level of   individual firms, particularindustries, and of the economy as   a whole.
name: Business and Environment

desc: An exploration of the ethical issues which arise when humans interact with other animals, and an examination of conflicting attitudes toward the valueof animal life in such specific areas as food production, recreational activities, research and environmental protection.
name: Animals in Human Society: Ethical Issues of Animal Use

desc: Types, sources, effects, and control of air pollution. Topics include   gaseous pollutants particulates, toxic contaminants, atmospheric   dispersion,photochemical smog, acid rain control measures, the clean   air act and regulatory trends, indoor air.
name: Air Quality and the Environment
prequisites: Mathematics 3A or 34A or Environmental Studies 25; and, Chemistry 1A and 1B, or   Environmental Studies 15A and 15B.

desc: Evolution, current status, and alternative futures of agriculture, food andpopulation worldwide. Achieving environmentally, socially, and economicallysustainable food systems; soil, water, crops, energy and labor; diversity, stability   and ecosystems management; farmer and scientist knowledge and collaboration;   common property management.
name: World Agriculture, Food, and Population

desc: Analyzes the historical and theoretical approaches to environmental assessment methodology and procedures for preparing and reviewing environmental impact reports. Explores strengths and weaknesses of current public policy context.
name: Environmental Impact Analysis

desc: An examination of the key processes that regulate ecosystem productivity and function in terrestrial ecosystems. Specific foci include: plant- soil linkages including decomposition and nutrient supply, and the role of above- and below-ground community composition on element cycles.
name: Ecosystem Processes
prequisites: Environmental Studies 100 or EEMB 2 or MCDB 1B.

desc: Overview of policy, technology, and economic dimensions of   managing wastes in the twenty-first century.  Covers the   emergence of product stewardship, domestic and international   recycling, composting of organic materials, conversion of   organic materials to renewable energy, waste incinerationand land filling.
name: Waste Management: Product Stewardship, Recycling and Renewable   Energy

desc: Traces the history of American attitudes and behavior toward nature. Focus on wilderness, the conservation movement, and modern forms of environmentalism.
name: American Environmental History

desc: Course is structured around the major issues in environmental politics, forexample: global warming, nuclear waste, deforestation, and chemical pollution. The roles of economics, technology and social organization are each considered as explanatory variables for understanding environmental problems.
instructors: MILDENBERGER, HENDERSON G L, HUNNICUTT P L
name: Comparative Environmental Politics

desc: Examines historical and contemporary environmental and human rights   movements around the world. Subject matter includes: policy-  driven/reformist environmental movements, radical underground and   militant  movements, indigenous peoples’ movements, environmental   movements in the Global South, and coalitions and transnational   advocacy networks focused on confronting climate change and   resource extraction associated with industrial agriculture, mining, timber   harvesting, hydroelectric dam construction, fracking, oil and tarsands,   and the international hazardous waste trade. Studentslearn theories   and concepts from the social sciences and environmental humanities.
name: Global Environmental Movements

desc: A series of weekly lectures by distinguished guest   speakers designed   tooffer insight into current research and issues in the   diverse   intellectual fields that constitute environmental   studies. Colloquium   themes vary quarter to quarter. Regular attendance and a   brief written   evaluationof each lecture is required.
name: Colloquium On Current Topics In Environmental Studies

desc: Opportunities to learn about practical approaches to   environmental   problem solving by working under faculty direction as   interns with local,   state, and federal agencies, non-governmental   organizations, or private   business concerned with the environment. Periodic and   final reports will be part of the internship.
name: Internships In Environmental Studies
prequisites: Minimum sophomore standing, 2.75 overall G.P.A., and be declared an   Environmental Studies or Hydrologic Sciences major; or consent by   department.

desc: A one-time course focusing on a special area of interest in environmental studies. ENVS 193PL   explores the remarkable and controversial policies, politics, history, law, science and ethics of   public lands and waters in the USA, including the examination of past, current and future problems   andsolutions. Readings, interactive class lectures, guest speakers and small group projects study   how America's vast and significant public lands and waters are managed, created, modified,   celebrated, and threatened.
name: America's Public Lands and Waters - Law and Policy

desc: Directed group reading, study, and research on specific subject in   environmental studies. Admission by arrangement with the   Environmental Studies chair or instructor. ENVS 194GB will focus on   introduction to Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)   tools and practice. Students conduct a real LEED certification for an   existing building on campus throughout the academic year. Using the   university as a living laboratory, course helps define green building best   practices while furthering campus sustainability goals and preparing   students for LEED accreditation.
name: Green Building LEED Living Lab
prequisites: Upper-division status and consent of instructor.

desc: Students assist instructor in teaching course in which the   student previously received a grade of A- or better.   Activities determined in consultation with the instructor   and may include assisting in laboratories, tutorials,   discussion sections and field trips.
name: Introduction to Teaching in Environmental Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers qualified students the opportunity to undertake research or work in a topic related to the characteristics and problems in the environment.
name: Independent Investigation in Environmental Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in environmental studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Environmental Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in environmental studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Introduces the most widely used abusive drugs: alcohol, nicotine, cannabis,hallucinogens, stimulants and performance enhancing substances. Theories ofaddiction, pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics are also explored.
name: Substance Abuse

desc: An examination of the interdependent relationships between   diet, health, and disease. Basic nutrition principles, food   selection, proper diet, andlifetime health habits are   emphasized.
name: Nutrition For Health

desc: A progressive series of classes designed to provide a basic   understandingof health and fitness. Theoretical frameworks   and fitness related activities are pursued at each course   level.
name: Life Fitness

desc: Examines lifestyle factors and influences which decrease   the possibility of premature disease and death and promote   a longer and healthier life. Emphasis is placed on   understanding the practices which have the most profound   impact on health.
name: Principles of Health Promotion

desc: Designed to provide students with the opportunity to obtain   practical experience in the field. Fieldwork may be   completed in public or private agencies whose focus in   exercise science, physical education or sport.
name: Fieldwork in Exercise Science, Physical Education and Sport

desc: Critical review and discussion of selected subjects within exercise science,   physical education, and sport.
name: Readings: Exercise Science, Physical Education, and Sport

desc: An introduction to the basic principals and problems of   administering (planning, organizing, leading, and   evaluating) athletic and recreational sports programs at   the community, high school, collegiate, and   professionallevels.
name: Sport Administration

desc: The scientific study of people and their behavior in sport and exercise settings.   Examination of individual and group performance enhancement strategies through   application of data, knowledge and skills from psychologicaland related fields.   An overview of the evolving field of sport and exercise psychology is presented.
name: Sport and Exercise Psychology

desc: An overview of professional sport management in North   America. The political, historical, social, economic, and   cultural impacts will be explored.Topics include team   management, organizational administration, legal issues,   public, and facility management.
name: Sport Management

desc: Investigates contemporary sport management issues with   emphasis on the administrative principles of planning,   organizing, leading and evaluating. Facilities construction   and maintenance, financial concerns and the structure and   function of the NCAA are studied.
instructors: ORLANDO M D, HATCHER K L
name: Current Issues in Sport Management

desc: Under the direction of selected instructors, students   assist in teaching a course in which the student has   received a B or better. Activities are determined by the   instructor and may include leading discussions, labs, and   research or grading assignments.
name: Introduction to Teaching in Exercise Science, Physical   Education, and Sport

desc: Designed to provide students in the minor with practical   experience by working under expert supervision in the   field. Internships may be completedin public or private   agencies whose focus is exercise, physical education, or   sport.
name: Internship in Exercise Science, Physical Education, and   Sport

desc: Provides an opportunity for students in the minor to pursue   a particular area of interest under the guidance of a   selected faculty member. Course culminates in a report   summarizing the inquiry.
name: Independent Studies in Exercise Science, Physical Education   and Sport
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of instructor; completion of 2 upper-  division courses in Exercise Studies.

desc: The course provides students the opportunity to compete, improve their physical condition, and refine their skills through vigorous training and neuromuscular development.
name: Intercollegiate Baseball

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
name: Elementary Badminton

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
name: Intermediate Badminton

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
instructors: HATCHER K L, COLSON G W
name: Elementary Basketball

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
instructors: HATCHER K L, COLSON G W
name: Intermediate Basketball

desc: Provides students with the opportunity to improve their basic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gain recreational skills.
instructors: HATCHER K L, COLSON G W
name: Advanced Basketball

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
name: Elementary Boating and Sailing

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
name: Intermediate Boating & Sailing

desc: A course designed to provide students with the opportunity to improve theirbasic physical condition, secure useful neuromuscular development, and gainrecreational skills.
name: Elementary Bowling

desc: Introduction to fitness training techniques that address aerobic conditioning, muscular endurance, muscular strength and flexibility.
name: Elementary Aerobic and Fitness Conditioning

desc: Presentation and practice of variety of fitness training techniques (high/low impact, step and resistance training) addressing aerobic conditioning, muscular strength and muscular endurance.
name: Intermediate Aerobic and Fitness Conditioning

desc: An advanced level course including high/low impact, step, resistance and anaerobic training techniques. cross-training, injury prevention and body alignment priciples will be accentuated.
name: Advanced Aerobic and Fitness Conditioning

desc: The course provides students the opportunity to compete, improve their physical condition, and refine their skills through vigorous training and neuromuscular development.
name: Intercollegiate Basketball

desc: Introduction to the basic concepts of indoor cycling. The relationship between indoor cycling and cardiovasular fitness is explored. Appropriate for individuals of all levels of fitness and experience.
name: Indoor Cycling

desc: The objective of this course is to obtain the basic techniques and theory fundamental to fencing. Satisfactory progress will allow advancement to the intermediate class.
name: Elementary Fencing

desc: The course provides students the opportunity to compete, improve their physical condition, and refine their skills through vigorous training and neuromuscular development.
name: Intercollegiate Cross Country

desc: Introduction to a variety of movement skills and sequences necessary to perform the foxtrot, swing, tango, waltz, mambo, salsa, and other popular social dances.
instructors: OTA S K, SILVA M M
name: Elementary Ballroom Dance
