name: Lifetime Activities Interest Class

desc: Students will receive faculty supervision as they lead discussion sections,assist in the preparation and evaluation of exams, and advise on written assignments. Attention will be given to the challenges posed by multidisciplinary materials and perspectives. Weekly meetings with instructor required.
name: Apprentice Teaching in Women's Studies

desc: Colloquium series in which Feminist Studies PhD students attend lectures and   engage in discussion of topics central to the discipline and participate in   professional development activities, such as presenting papers, evaluating   arguments, and advancing interdisciplinary knowledge.
name: Conversations for Change

desc: Individual tutorial relevant to M.A. or Ph.D projects. Plan of   study mustbe approved by program chair.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Independent study for PhD Examinations
name: Independent Study for PhD Examinations

desc: Open to graduate students conducting master's research.
name: M.A. Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Open to graduate students conducting doctoral research.
name: PhD Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: Introduction to central concepts and issues in feminist   studies from the perspective of the social sciences.   Explores   the construction of genderand sexuality and the lives of   diverse groups of women in the contemporary U.S. within a   global context.
instructors: SORIANO K M, WALD A P, SENCAN G, PINKERTON S J
name: Gender and Power: Introduction to Feminist Studies

desc: Examines cultural representations of diverse women's lives   from a humanities perspective. The focus is on women as   cultural producers, subjects, and critics in literature, film,   the visual arts, and music.  Includes mandatory weekly film   screening.
instructors: THOMPSON A M, DEL CASTILLO, SPERLING J L, TANNER L C
name: Women, Representation, and Cultural Production

desc: Examination of the interlocking dynamics and politics of gender, race, sexuality, class, and culture in the experience of U.S. women of color. Readings focus on oppositional consciousness and resistance to oppression in the scholarship and literature by women of color.
instructors: RESTREPO I C, HAI J, KURGAN S
name: Women of Color: Race, Class, and Ethnicity

desc: Research under the direction of a faculty member. Students are offered an opportunity to conduct independent or collaborative research or to act as interns for faculty-directed research projects.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Feminist Studies 10 or 20 or 40; consent of instructor and department chair.

desc: Students design, research, write, and present original work on a topic of choice under supervision of a Women's Studies faculty mentor. Emphasis is ondata gathering and organization.
name: Senior Honors Project

desc: Directed readings in women's studies under the guidance of a faculty memberin the program. Students wishing to enroll should prepare a short written plan of study.
name: Readings in Women's Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in FeministStudies.

desc: Independent research and writing under the guidance of a faculty member in the program. students wishing to enroll should prepare a short written planof study.
name: Independent Studies in Women's Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in FeministStudies.

desc: Research assistance or independent project under the guidance   of a faculty member. Students must prepare a written plan with   a faculty advisor. For P/NP credit only.
name: Research Assistance and Projects in Feminist Studies

desc: Explores various models for the close analysis of film and   media texts and the critical frameworks these models   explicitly or implicitly employ.
name: Textual Analysis

desc: Close examination of a topic in film and/or media history.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media History

desc: Close examination of a topic in cultural studies.
name: Special Topics in Cultural Studies

desc: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in   the media industry.
name: Professional Internship
prequisites: Consent of department; film studies majors only; must be in good standing.

desc: Designed to accommodate graduate students who serve as   teaching assistants. Includes analyses of texts and materials,   discussion section teaching techniques, formulation of topics   and questions for papers and examinations, and grading papers   and examinations under instructor supervision.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum

desc: Examines issues related to curation, including the construction of canons, cultural value, and economies of prestige. Students work with the CWC director in curating programs for the Pollock Theater and related research events. Class discusses readings, screen media, research potential guests, writes questions for Q&A sessions with invited guests, and writes program notes for the CWC’s website and Pollock programs. Students register for one unit per quarter. If taken for elective credit toward the Ph.D., it must be taken for three terms in a row, one unit in each of the first two terms, and two in the third term. Students taking the course for two units would complete a capstone project for the course.
name: Programming and Curation Practicum

desc: A seminar on research subjects of current interest.
name: Special Topics in Film and Media

desc: Provides guidance, training, a forum, and a common center for   various research endeavors.
name: Group Studies

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Master's Oral Exam and PhD Qualifying Exam preparation.
name: MA Orals and PhD Exam Preparation

desc: Only for the research and writing of dissertation. Instructor   should be chair of the student's doctoral committee.
name: Dissertation Research and Writing

desc: An introduction to the study of film as an aesthetic and   social phenomenon, and to various methods of critical   analysis.
instructors: PENABELLA M A, STEENLAND J M, HUSER B J, TEJEDA A, MOORE J S
name: Introduction to Cinema

desc: Students receive one unit credit for the honors seminar.   Intended for highly motivated Letters and Science Honors   students.
name: Introduction to Cinema - Honors
prequisites: Must be taken concurrently with Film and Media Studies 46.

desc: Designed for Film and Media Studies majors and students   contemplating a major   or concentration in film. An intensive introduction to the   study of film and to   various methods of critical analysis.
name: Major Seminar
prequisites: Concurrent enrollment in Film and Media Studies 46.

desc: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in the film or  television industry. Required are approximately 100 hours of work per quarter, a   final five-page report, and a supervisor's letter of verification.
name: Internship in Film/Television
prequisites: Film and Media Studies majors only.

desc: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Independent Studies.

desc: International film history from the camera obscura to the   close of the silent era in the late 1920's. Historical   accounts of film as an aesthetic form, a social force, an   economic institution, and a technology are considered.
instructors: LERNER S E, BALL R C
name: History of Cinema: The Silent Film
prequisites: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a minimum grade of C; open to Film and   Media Studies majors only.

desc: International history of electronic media and broadcasting   from telegraphy to early television. Historical accounts of   telegraphy, radio, and early television as cultural forms,   communications technologies, and social political and   economic institutions are considered.
instructors: HAN L Y, NIEHUSEN K P
name: History of Electronic Media: Telegraphy to Early Television
prequisites: Film and Media Studies 46 and 70 with a grade of C or better.

desc: This lecture-based course addresses the fundamentals of   moving image production and technology from the   perspective of television and video practices. Historical   and contemporary methods and breakthroughs are examined. Students get hands-on training with weekly workshops and   short film projects. Areas covered include the basics of   camera, sound and editing.
name: Production Technology
prequisites: Film and Media Studies 46; open to film and media majors only.

desc: Addresses film, television and/or digital media from a   variety of theoretical perspectives; topics will vary   depending on instructor. Critical analytical papers will be   required. Emphases have included classical, contemporary and   comparative theories of film and media.
instructors: STROBEL N E, KILEY J T
name: Topics in Film and Media Theory
prequisites: Film and Media 96 with a grade of C or better.

desc: An opportunity for training, career sampling, and contacts in   the film ortelevision industry. Required are approximately   100 hours of work a quarter, a final five-page report, and a   supervisor's letter of verification.
instructors: PALLADINO J N, T B A
name: Internship in Film/Television
prequisites: Upper-division standing; open to film studies majors only; consent of   department.

desc: Students gain professional skills, including writing event   proposals, marketing, and theater operations. Over three quarters, this class emphasizes different aspects of broadcast production, which include Q&As/talk shows, sitcoms, and directing. May be taken up to three times.
name: Pollock Theater Event and Production Internship

desc: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in film   studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Course work shall consist of faculty supervised research   assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistnace in Film Studies
prequisites: Upper-division staning; completion of 2 upper-division courses in film   studies; consent of instructor and department.

desc: How was Paris deployed and dramatized, metamorphosed, and transfigured in the nineteenth century? Focus on panoramic literature, the invention of "theeveryday" and of modern life, the expository spirit and world exhibitions, vision and spectatorship, commodities and consumer desires.
name: Modernity and the City

desc: Includes orientation week, weekly meetings with supervisor, preparation of examinations, class visitations and discussions, and occasional workshops.
name: Apprentice Teaching

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor is usually student's thesis advisor. Students doing initial research on the doctoral dissertation may sign up for thiscourse.
name: Directed Reading and Research

desc: Individual research projects, supervised by a faculty member. Requires permission of graduate adviser to enroll.
name: Independent Study

desc: Reserved for writing of the doctoral dissertation once the student has advanced to candidacy. Instructor should be chair of student's doctoral committee. A progress report must be turned in in order to receive a satisfactory grade for the course.
name: Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: A continuation of French 1. Targets students' developing knowledge of the fundamentals of French language, focusing on speaking, reading, and writing abilities through a focus on French and Francophone culture. Meets four days a week; in French.
instructors: VIVIAN D A ROBERTS S C, LABATUT M A, BASILE R G

timeslots.instructor: VIVIAN D A ROBERTS S C

name: Elementary French

desc: First in the three-quarter intermediate French series. Builds on foundationestablished in first-year and includes thorough review of French grammar. Speaking and writing skills developed through exposure to French and Francophone culture, literature, and film. Four days a week; in French.
instructors: BASILE R G, TUDISCO J J ROBERTS S C, LABATUT M A

timeslots.instructor: TUDISCO J J ROBERTS S C

name: Intermediate French

desc: Individual research project, supervised by a faculty member.
name: Independent Study
prequisites: French 3 with a minimum grade of B.

desc: Transitional course between lower-division language and upper-division   literature/advanced culture courses. Students develop their writing and   speaking skills through the study of contemporary French and Francophone   literature, art and film. Includes a review of grammar. Prerequisite to all   other upper-division courses taught in French.
name: Advanced Composition

desc: An introductory, interdisciplinary approach to literary analysis through anexamination of the cultural history and aesthetic movements of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. Readings of poetry, drama, and fiction. Focus on advanced discussion and writing in French.
instructors: BROWN C J, SKENAZI E C
name: Introduction to Literary and Cultural Analysis

desc: A study of one or more major medieval works in translation   such as The Song of Roland, the romances of Chretien de   Troyes, the Lais of Marie de France,or The Romance of the   Rose.
name: Studies in Medieval Literature

desc: Individual investigations in literary or linguistics fields in   fulfillment of Senior Honors Thesis for French Major.
name: Honors Independent Studies in French
prequisites: Upper-division standing; 24 upper-division units in French.

desc: Individual investigations in literary or linguistics fields.
name: Independent Studies in French
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in French.

desc: Independent research, under the supervision of a consenting faculty member.
name: Independent Research Assistance
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in French; consent of instructor.

desc: Presentation and discussion by department faculty of research areas in the department. Systematic and technique areas of emphasis will be presented, as well as department facilities and research collaborations with other institutions.
name: Introduction to Geographic Research

desc: A series of seminars on diverse problems in human and physical geography, and   geographic techniques, by current and visiting faculty and researchers.
name: Seminar in Geography

desc: Quantitative methods (operations research, applied mathematics and statistics,   numerical simulation) are used to analyze and synthesize complex water   resources systems. Topics include economic analysis, hydropower, flood control,   groundwater management, and reservoirs.
name: Water Resource Systems Analysis

desc: Introduction to analytical methods for geography research.  Topics include:calculus, differential equations and linear algebra. Emphasis is placed on solving geographically relevant problems and their documentation.
name: Analytical Methods in Geography I

desc: Issues, problems, technologies, policies, plans, and the  transportation-environment relationship. Transportation systems simulation, data collection,and model building.  Applications in planning, design, and operations. Lab:Critically examine transportation plans and programs and explore travel surveys.
name: Transportation Planning & Modeling

desc: Fundamentals in atmospheric processes that are important for understanding the role of the atmosphere in earth's climate and biogeochemistry. Graduate-level introduction to radiation, dynamics, clouds, chemistry, and how theyinteract.
name: Introduction to Atmospheric Sciences

desc: Course for new teaching assistants to examine geographic   teaching methodsand classroom procedures. Emphasis on use   of equipment and facilities in the department, teaching   aids, lectures, exams, grading, student advising, and   special problems. Repeatable.
name: Teaching Assistant Training

desc: Individual tutorial. Instructor is usually student's major professor.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Instructor should be student's major professor or chair of the doctoral committee.
name: Individual Study for Ph.D. Examinations
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Research toward and writing of thesis.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Research toward and writing of dissertation. Instructor should be chair of student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: Consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Introduction to the oceans and atmosphere and their role in the Earth's climate   and its weather patterns. Focus on the flows of solar energy throughthe ocean   and atmosphere systems. Human impacts of the Earth's climate are also   introduced.
instructors: MONTINI T L, KRELL N T, KIRKBY J M, AVERY R B, RUBIO-VELAZQU
name: Oceans and Atmosphere

desc: Study of the interactions among water, landforms, soil, and vegetation thatcreate and modify the surface of the Earth. Impacts of physical environmenton   human societies and humans as agents of environmental change.
instructors: CHADWICK O A, DORSEY J E, GOTO E A, ROMICH T L
name: Land, Water and Life

desc: Survey of spatial differentiation and organization of human activity and   interaction with the Earth's biophysical systems. Sample topics include human   spatial decision-making behavior, migration, population growth, economic   development, industrial location, urbanization, and human impacts on the   natural environment.
instructors: MONTELLO D R, BAE C J, UPPAL A, CHENG YOU, PARDO-RODRIGU
name: People, Place, and Environment

desc: Surveys properties of maps, emphasizing map use and   interpretation. Lecture topics include map abstraction,   generalization, map projections, and symbolization. Special   purpose maps, thematic maps, and the display of quantitative   and qualitative information is considered.
instructors: CLARKE K, JOHNSON M, PHILLIPS D W, ETTELSON D R, WANG JIAN, TAYLOR-BURNS, VAHEDI TORGHA, SUAREZ A M
name: Maps and Spatial Reasoning

desc: Introduction to transportation problems involving energy, the environment, congestion, infrastructure, and future trends.  Historical perspective on transportation innovations and their impacts on urban form. Reviews current problems, including the movement of freight and the development of transit-oriented neighborhoods.
instructors: DEUTSCH K E, DAVIS A W, XU JING
name: Transportation Futures

desc: Issues, problems, technologies, policies, plans, programs, and the transportation-environment relationship. Transportation systems simulation, trip-based and activity data collection and modeling. Applications in planning, design and operations. Lab: Critically examine transportation plans and programs; explore and analyze travel surveys.
name: Transportation Planning and Modeling

desc: Analysis of the water cycle with emphasis on land-atmosphere interactions, precipitation-runoff, flood, snow melt, and infiltration processes.
name: Environmental Hydrology

desc: Introduction to the chemical, hydrological, and biological characteristics of soils, their global distribution, and response to management. Field and laboratory projects provide an understanding of soil-landscape distribution, soil morphology, and the physical and chemical properties that influence management decisions.
instructors: CHADWICK O A, BINGHAM N L, VOSS K A
name: Soil Science

desc: Introduction to theory and methods of aerial photography and   satellite remote sensing for studying Earth’s environment,   from natural vegetation tourban areas. Lab develops   fundamental skills in the acquisition, interpretation, and   analysis of digital remote sensing imagery.
instructors: KIBLER C L, MILLER D L, ALLEN M, DE FIGUEIREDO
name: Remote Sensing of the Environment 1

desc: Overview of orographic weather patterns with focus on orographic precipitation and circulation, mountain waves, cloudiness, snowfall and avalanches, fire weather, air   pollution and dispersion. Human impacts on mountain environments and climate change in   mountain areas are introduced.
instructors: DE CARVALHO L, ZIGNER K M
name: Mountain Weather and Climate
prequisites: Geography 3A or 3B; or consent of instructor.

desc: A survey of the source and fate of pollutants in the coastal ocean,   focusing specifically on the physical processes that govern the transport   of nutrients, sediment, hydrocarbons, and human pathogens in coastal   ecosystems. Material includes readings from scientific papers, grey   literature, and news media in order to develop intuition for how transport   phenomena frame both pollution issues and solutions.
instructors: NIDZIEKO N J, TUHOLSKE C P
name: Coastal Pollution

desc: Description of tropical atmosphere. High and low frequency variability: hurricanes, monsoon, El Nino, satellite observations, and modeling.
name: Tropical Meteorology
prequisites: Geography 110 with a grade of C or better.

desc: Various geographic dimensions of human population dynamics: fertility,   mortality, and migration. The concepts and language of demography are   introduced. The causes and consequences of population dynamics are   investigated, including links among population, environment, and development.
name: Population Geography

desc: Evolution, current status, and alternative futures of   agriculture, food and population worldwide. Achieving   environmentally, socially, and economically sustainable   food systems; soil, water, crops, energy and labor;   diversity, stability and ecosystems management; farmer   and scientist knowledge and collaboration; common   property management.
name: World Agriculture, Food, and Population

desc: Statistical analysis of geographical data. Topics include spatial auto-correlation, multiple regression in spatial context, and introductory methods for analyzing point, area (lattice), and continuous spatial data. Lab includes the use of statistical software for analyzing various spatial data types.
instructors: MURRAY A, FENG X, PLUDOW B A
name: Intermediate Geographical Data Analysis
prequisites: Statistics and Applied Probability 5AA-ZZ or Ecology, Evolution & Marine Biology 30 or Psychology 5 or Communication 87.

desc: Comprehensive overview of Geographic Information Systems   and Science. Topics span the nature of geographic   information and the procedures for operating GIS. Labs   provide hands-on experience with GIS and related software.
instructors: KUHN W, YE H, XIAO J, MILLER ANNALI
name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems and Science

desc: Practical experience and research on geographical problems under faculty direction as interns with local, state, and federal agencies, with private research and development firms, and with other business organizations. Periodic and final reports required.
name: Internship in Geography
prequisites: Upper-division standing in geography; consent of department.

desc: Designed to provide in-depth directed inquiry into a topic of interest to the   student.
name: Readings in Geography
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in geography; consent of   instructor.

desc: Independent geographical research conducted under the guidance of Geographyfaculty. Topic and scope varies, as specified by student and supervisory faculty member prior to registration.
name: Independent Studies in Geography
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in geography; consent of instructor.

desc: Selected research under the direction of a faculty member.
name: Independent Research Assistance in Geography
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in geography; consent of instructor.

desc: Subject oriented, designed to relate directly to the teaching of a particular course in progress, to improve the skills and effectiveness of the department's teaching assistants.
name: Practicum for Teaching Assistants

desc: Individualized instruction. A written proposa must be approved by department chair, to include a description of the course content and a reading list.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: German 210A-B or equivalent. Graduate standing; consent of instructor, graduate adviser and department chair.

desc: Instructor should normally be the student's major professor or chair of thedoctoral committee. Enrollment must be approved by graduate adviser.
name: Individual Study for Master's Comprehensive Examinations and Ph.D. Examinations
prequisites: German 201A-B or equivalent. Graduate standing; consent of graduate adviser

desc: Instructor should be chair of student's thesis committee.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Only for preparation of the dissertation. Instructor should be the chair ofthe student's doctoral committee.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation
prequisites: German 201A-B or equivalent. Advancement to candidacy; consent of graduate adviser.

desc: Speaking, listening, reading, and writing on an advanced level, while   exploring   contemporary German culture. Systematic review of grammar material.   Additional focus   on vocabulary building. Written and oral discussionsbased on newspaper   articles,   literary texts, German films, and websites. Topics will vary by quarter.
instructors: WHITE K D, REDER E R
name: Advanced German

desc: Focus on the development of advanced reading and writing skills in   German.   In particular, we will draw on a variety of authentic materials to develop   students’ ability to analyze and produce a range of genres; enhance  students’ awareness of pre-, during- and post-reading strategies and how   to   apply them to different styles of writing; improve use of strategies to help   students become more autonomous readers/writers; and develop critical   skills   for reading, comprehending, and writing different types of texts.
name: Advanced Reading and Writing Skills

desc: In-depth study of special topics in literary texts of   German-speaking traditions.   Topics will vary by instructor. Topics may include:   "Science in German Literature," "Literature and human   rights," "Animals in literature," "Literature and the   environment." Taught in German.
name: Special Topics in German Literature

desc: Telegraph, telephone, phonograph, and film are techniques that have engendered new forms of representation, communication, and thinking. Course studies the impact of these transformations in literature and on literature. Taught in English.
name: Mediatechnology

desc: An independent study course (one to three quarters) directed by a faculty member with a carefully chosen topic and bibliography which will result in adocumented project or a senior thesis.
name: Senior Honors Project
prequisites: Open to senior majors only; consent of instructor.

desc: Independent studies in German. Individual investigations in literary fields. Readings in German.
name: Readings in German
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in German.

desc: Individual investigations in literary fields.
name: Independent Studies in German
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in German.

desc: Coursework shall consist of faculty supervised research assistance.
name: Independent Research Assistance in German
prequisites: Upper-division standing; completion of 2 courses in upper-division German; consent of instructor and department.

desc: Provides an overview of globalization while at the same time reflecting thespecific concerns and key debates within the participating disciplines.Seminar is led by one participating faculty member responsible for content and continuity but involves faculty from participating disciplines.
name: Gateway Seminar
prequisites: For graduate students doing the Ph.D. emphasis in Global Studies.

desc: Overview of the basic ideas and major writings that have   influenced the field of global and international studies. This   is an interdisciplinary reading seminar intended as a   foundational course for the MA program, required of all first   year students.
name: History and Theory of Globalization

desc: This seminar focuses on the various dimensions of political,   economic, and social order that arise from transnational   conflict and cooperation, addressing such issues as the   relations among sovereign states, market forces, civil   society, and struggles for global justice.
name: Global Governance, Human Rights, and Civil Society

desc: This seminar, required of all first year students, introduces students to logics of inquiry and epistemologies central to understanding the intersection of the transnational and international, and methodological training in areas such as documentary analysis, interviewing, field methods, and surveys.
name: Research Methods

desc: Analyses of texts and materials, discussion of teaching techniques, conducting discussion sections, formulation of topics and questions for papers andexaminations, and grading papers and examinations under the supervision of the instructor. Designed to meet the needs of the graduate student who serves as a teaching assistant.
name: Teaching Assistant Practicum
prequisites: Appointment as teaching assistant in Global and International Studies.

desc: Individual tutorial. Plan of study must be approved by department chair or MAGIS director.
name: Directed Reading And Research

desc: Individual study for M.A. or Ph.D. examination. Normally   taken with the student's committee chair.
name: Independent Study for M.A. and Ph.D. Examinations

desc: Master's thesis research and preparation.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation

desc: Ph.D. dissertation research and preparation. Normally taken   with the student's committee chair.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Research and Preparation

desc: A survey of the historical processes that have brought different areas of the world into closer contact. Topics include ideologies of nationalism, democracy, and liberalism; international trade and migrations; technological changes; colonialism; the globalization of culture; and the reactions to them.
instructors: MOLAEI A, SOZMEN M M, RABELLO SODRE, ADAM A A
name: Global History, Culture and Ideology

desc: Examination of contemporary social, economic, political, and environmental change in a global context; the emergence of a global economy and new systems of world order; and the debate over "globalization" and whether or not it is desireable.
instructors: LEQUESNE T F, AZERGUN H, GUIRGUIS C M, SNAY H N
name: Global Socioeconomic and Political Processes

desc: Globalization of the world's population through international migrations; the emergence of diasporic cultures and their relationship to the countriesof origin; interactions between immigrant/ethnic cultures and the dominant cultures of the host societies; the nature of transnational identities.
name: Global Diasporas and Cultural Change

desc: Explores connections over the last century between global cultural developments and the quest for normative values on a global level. Topics include the communications revolution, cultural ideologies, international migrationsand diasporas, the human rights movement, and new cosmopolitanisms.
name: Global Culture and Ethics

desc: Deals with conceptions of the world as a unitary political   system and howthese views come into confrontation with one   another. Topics include the nation-state system, political   ideologies, international organizations, global conflict,   and the emergent civil society.
instructors: MANSKI S G, FAUST J M
name: Global Ideologies and World Order

desc: Examines recent theories and perspectives on global political economy and development studies. Topics include, among others, the new global economy, transnational corporations, transnational labor markets, international tradeand finance, social and economic development, and North-South relations.
name: Global Economy and Development

desc: Independent studies in global and international studies. Students must be majors in global and international studies or present justification to the program for diverting from this norm.
name: Independent Studies
prequisites: Upper-division standing; consent of program (department) and instructor.

desc: Advanced reading and study of selections from the Iliad and/or Odyssey.
name: Homer

desc: Individual tutorial.
name: Directed Reading and Research
prequisites: Written proposal approved by department chair and graduate advisor.

desc: Independent research.
name: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
prequisites: Graduate standing and consent of instructor and graduate advisor.

desc: Terminal preparation of the dissertation.
name: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation

desc: The beginning course in classical Greek and first in a three-quarter sequence introducing fundamentals of grammar, syntax, and reading skills. Concepts taught using written exercises. Interesting aspects of Ancient Greek society are introduced.
name: Elementary Greek

desc: Reading and analysis of attic prose writers such as Xenophon and Plato to develop reading skills and introduce study of the style and thought of historical, rhetorical and/or philosophical writers.
name: Introduction To Greek Prose
prequisites: Greek 3 with a grade of C or better.

desc: Reading and study of selections from the Illiad and/or Odyssey.
name: Homer

desc: Independent investigations in Greek language and literature.
name: Independent Studies In Greek.
prequisites: Consent of instructor and department chair; upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Greek.

desc: The beginning course in Hebrew. Starting with the study o the alphabet, thestudent is initiated into the rudiments of the language. Basic grammar, vocabulary, and conversation.
name: Elementary Hebrew

desc: Continuation of Hebrew 3 with emphasis in writing, composition, and readingof Hebrew newspapers. Introduction to modern Hebrew literature: prose and poetry.
name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew
